SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House expresses its deep regret at the death on Monday, 20 March 1989 of the Hon. Nelson Lemmon, a member of the House of Representatives for the division of Forrest from 1943 to 1949 and for the division of St George from 1954 to 1955, and a Minister of the Crown from 1946 to 1949, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to the members of his family in their bereavement.

Nelson Lemmon was born on 22 March 1908 at Williamstown, Victoria. His father, John, held the Victorian State seat of Williamstown for the unbelievably long period of 51 years until 1955. Nelson was educated at Williamstown State School and Longerenong Agricultural College. At the age of 20 he was placed in charge of the Victorian Department of Agriculture sheep stud at Werribee. He then moved to Western Australia, where he became a successful farmer, raising fat lambs and growing wheat on land which had been condemned as useless for settlement. He married Ada Mary Jackel in 1930 and they had a son and a daughter. Before entering Federal Parliament, Nelson Lemmon was active in both local council and farming activities. He was a member of the Wheat Stabilisation Board of Western Australia from 1943 to 1944. John Curtin took an interest in the young farmer, and worked to get him into Parliament.

When Nelson Lemmon entered the Federal Parliament in 1943 Australia was still at war in Europe and the Pacific. His maiden speech reflected a vision for a better Australia, a vision that was the hallmark of the Chifley Government in the post-war reconstruction era. He had a sincere commitment to caring about the poor and unemployed. He stressed the importance of opening tertiary education opportunities to all those with the necessary ability. He saw the importance of restructuring rural industry in the aftermath of the war.

It was, however, in his time as a Minister in the Chifley Government that Nelson Lemmon put his mark indelibly on the history of our nation. As Minister for Works and Housing he was responsible for the commencement of that bold, imaginative and daunting engineering feat, the Snowy Mountains hydro-electric scheme. He also foresaw the importance of environmental protection long before it became a political issue, and sought to minimise ecological damage in the scheme's planning. Perhaps more than any other initiative, the Snowy Mountains scheme showed Australians and the world that we were emerging from the dark years of war not complacently but with a spirit of enthusiasm in the face of challenge. The energy and determination of Nelson Lemmon resulted in a monument worthy of the spirit of those days.

As part of his portfolio responsibilities, Nelson Lemmon also put into operation a plan for the construction of war service homes, again exhibiting his extraordinary organisation abilities. As well as his role as Minister for Works and Housing, Nelson Lemmon assisted the Treasurer from 1946 to 1949. These were difficult times for the Chifley Government in its work to establish a strong post-war economy. It is an indication of the regard in which Nelson Lemmon was held that he was given this important additional role. Nelson Lemmon lost his seat in 1949 when the Chifley Government was defeated. He re-entered Parliament briefly in 1954 as the member for St George, Sydney, amid press speculation that he was a likely contender for the Labor leadership. This was, of course, the period when Labor's political fortunes entered the trough they were to occupy until 1972. Lemmon lost his seat in 1955. He retired from public life at 47 and returned to his property in Robertson, New South Wales, as a horse trainer, breeder and owner.

Despite Nelson Lemmon's relatively short career in public life, he played a pivotal role in Australia's postwar reconstruction. Ben Chifley himself regarded his young ministerial colleague as future leadership material. He was a dedicated member of this House at a most important time in our history and was regarded as one of Labor's best debaters of the time. He was the last surviving member of the Chifley Ministry. In that sense his death marks the end of an era, but his accomplishments live on and will, I hope and trust, provide an enduring example to us. On behalf of the Government, I extend to members of his family our sincere condolences in their bereavement.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the significance of today in relation to the health portfolio?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Forde for the question. Today is indeed a very significant day for the health portfolio because today the Minister for Community Services and Health, Neal Blewett, becomes the longest continuous serving health Minister in Australia's history. He achieves that having served six years and 24 days continuously in the portfolio. The previous record for unbroken service as Minister for Health was held by the late Sir Earle Page, who held the portfolio for six years and 23 days, between 19 December 1949 and 11 January 1956. It is not only the length of time served which makes this record significant; it is also the quality of what has been achieved in the health portfolio during this period under the outstanding direction and leadership of the present Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's record of reform in the health area is outstanding-indeed, it is unparalleled-and, without being exhaustive, I point out that it includes the introduction of Medicare, which is the most successful health insurance scheme in Australia's history and which enfranchised the two million Australians who were without health cover under the previous Government. It involves new emphasis on disease and illness prevention through programs such as the better health program, the national campaign against drug abuse, the national AIDS strategy, and the national campaign against measles. It includes the transformation of nurse education and training from the antediluvian hospital-based system to tertiary education colleges, offering improved career opportunities to nurses as well as a better trained work force for hospitals. It includes the revolutionary changes in general practice recently agreed between the Minister and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, designed to improve the quality of patient care through continuing education and vocational registration.

Those are but some of the important examples of the great achievements of this Government in this area under the leadership of the present Minister. All that has been contributed by the Opposition in this period has been five health spokespersons and six failed health policies to date. I am sure that all honourable members will join with me in congratulating the Minister for Community Services and Health on becoming Australia's longest continuously serving health Minister and for helping to make this country a better place to live in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Defence of his statement of 28 March 1989 in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: National Safety Council of Australia personnel, including the former Chief Executive, did not have access to classified information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I still stand by the statement. Let me go to the basis of that statement, since the honourable member seeks to be regarded seriously on that matter, by quoting a note sent to me today by the Chief of the Air Staff who, of course, has responsibility for these matters. I will read from it:

ANSWER.PARA: NSCA Operations at RAAF Bases

1. We spoke at Tindal about security aspects of NSCA operations from RAAF bases, the more pertinent of these being Townsville, Tindal, Darwin and Williamtown. (All of these are joint civilian/military airfields.) As NSCA operated from the civil tarmac area at Townsville, they did not require entry to the RAAF areas.

2. At Tindal, entry to the `domestic' area was by a long-term visitor's pass, as is the case with other civilian contractors and employees. As is normal on joint-user airfields, they had access to `Base Operations' for flight planning purposes as required, and operated from the Air Movements tarmac, both of these areas being outside the restricted 755SQN area. They did visit 75SQN facilities for briefings on SAR matters, but were escorted in areas containing classified matter. Under the contract NSCA were provided with mess accommodation.

3. At Darwin, NSCA were issued with photographic passes giving entry to the base domestic area, to Flight Planning and to the RAAF helipad tarmac from which they operated. They had access to documents dealing with SAR only.

4. At Williamtown, proof of identity of NSCA personnel was by the production of NSCA photographic ID cards, with NSCA providing a listing of their employees' names. This gave entry to the domestic area, including Flight Planning. NSCA operated from their own separate section of the RAAF tarmac and had access to adjacent RAAF areas only for specific purposes associated with their duties.

5. Mr Friedrich is not known to have visited RAAF Townsville but undoubtedly would have visited the civil facilities from which NSCA operated. He has been an infrequent visitor to the other bases with his arrival and departures being by air and with prior RAAF approval. He would have been escorted during his stay. He had been given a standard unclassified visitor tour and F/A-18 simulator visit at Williamtown. He visited Darwin at the time of Pitchblack 1988 and was at Tindal in September last year.

6. In summary, NSCA personnel were treated no differently from other contractor-employed personnel. They had access to those parts of our bases they needed to conduct their legitimate tasks, none of which required access to sensitive areas or information.

That is the advice to me from the Chief of the Air Staff, which I table. I think there are some misnomers abroad in the general community-perhaps the honourable member shares them-that there is a total prohibition on anybody going towards any sort of sensitive area imposed by the Services unless he goes through what is rightly a very cumbersome security clearance process. The fact of the matter is that that is not so. Plenty of uncleared people have access to those areas. They are escorted when they do so. In this instance, as the Chief of the Air Staff advises me, and I can only go on the advice I get from him, this is the case. I should say that it definitely is not a unique situation. I am advised also that each month about 1,800 of these passes, at Williamtown for example, are given to contractor employees.

Everybody has had great memories of the National Safety Council of Australia (NSCA) in the last week or so and everybody is coming out with grand stories. If people seriously believe that the advice to me from the Chief of the Air Staff and the advice to me from the people who are responsible for organising all of this is incorrect, I would appreciate their presenting to the Australian Federal Police their evidence on these matters so that it can be properly investigated, instead of wandering around the place spouting off at the top of their heads as though the Royal Australian Air Force does not know a thing or two about protecting its own security requirements.

I might also say something about NSCA personnel. NSCA personnel, many of whom are ex-servicemen, to my knowledge have always done their task well and professionally in the very limited contracts they have had with Defence and the much more extensive contracts they have had with other State and Federal operators. As I have said, many of them are ex-service personnel and know the requirements placed on them. The fact that apparently they have been led over the last few years by an alleged embezzler does not go to question their patriotism or capacity in any way.

As far as I can see, from all the advice given to me, the advice I gave the media last week was sound. I repeat that if anybody has any contrary information which suggests that the advice I have received is incorrect, then I invite them to present that advice to the Federal Police or the appropriate body.

—I ask the Prime Minister: What action is the Government taking to assist international efforts to achieve peace between Israel and its neighbours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my belief-I hope it is shared by all members of the House-that there is at this time an historic opportunity presenting itself for a breakthrough in the longstanding Middle East dispute. A number of factors justify that statement being made. Firstly, most obviously and most importantly, there is the easing of tensions between the superpowers. Secondly, there are the significant concessions by the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) in accepting the existence of Israel and in declaring its rejection and condemnation of terrorism. Thirdly, and importantly, there is the renewed activity by the United States Administration in the Middle East peace process, highlighted by the visits to Washington this week by President Mubarak and Prime Minister Shamir. Fourthly, and also very importantly, there is the increased evidence of the willingness of the Soviet Union to play a more constructive role in the search for Middle East peace. All of those developments-each one singly and certainly taking them all together-are important, and the Government welcomes them. At the same time we recognise, as must any reasonable person, the dangers and the difficulties ahead. It needs to be said that the PLO is not homogeneous. It is undoubtedly true that some elements linked with the PLO hold extremist views and continue to favour the use of violence as a means to achieve their goals. We say of the PLO that it must be in a position, as far as we and reasonable people around the world are concerned, to have its words tested against deeds.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government hopes that the new government in Israel will recognise the significance of the recent developments to which I have alluded and will address itself with renewed courage and imagination to the task of coming to terms with its adversaries. A positive response by Israel to the PLO's recent moves would serve to encourage Palestinian moderates, thus promoting Israel's long-term interests. In particular, we endorse President Bush's call for Israel to acknowledge the Palestinians' basic political rights. This has for too long now been an area of tragedy for those immediately and directly involved and a continuing source of potential conflict on a global scale. All men and women of goodwill will recognise the significance of those factors to which I have alluded and will join with me in expressing the hope that all those directly concerned-Israel, the Palestinians and the Arab states-with the more congenial environment in which they now operate, with reduced superpower tension, will pick up the initiatives, will show the courage that in previous and more belligerent circumstances they have shown.

As I have had cause to say, the challenges and the dangers of peace are often in a sense greater than the challenges and the dangers of war. I think that this is the case on this occasion. We hope that all those with responsibility will rise to this occasion so that in the event we can see the emergence of a constructive and durable peace in the region and consequently a reduction in the danger of global conflict which has always been attendant on this long, simmering and dangerous dispute.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. I ask the Minister to inform the House of the benefits, if any, to Australia of decisions taken at the Saving the Ozone Layer conference in London at which he represented Australia. Is Australia making an adequate response to the problems of ozone depletion in the atmosphere which could put many Australians at risk by causing skin cancer, eye disease and other physical defects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Saving the Ozone Layer conference in London was an excellent conference. Full marks should be accorded to Mrs Thatcher for having had the initiative to call it. There were 118 nations present. Its significance was to indicate how far the world had gone since 31 or 32 nations attended the Montreal Convention in 1987. There is universal recognition that the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer is now inadequate and, although it is incorporated in our recent ozone protection legislation, Australia will be one of those countries meeting in Helsinki in a couple of months to say that the timetable set at Montreal is now quite inadequate. The nations at the London conference were looking not for a cut by 50 per cent by the end of the 1990s, but at a total elimination by 1998 or 1999 of the production and use of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and halons.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the most interesting things about the conference I thought was the very frank response from industry. For example, Du Pont Petrochemicals, the biggest producer of CFCs, was there. Du Pont indicated that it was looking for certainty in directions from the international community. If the governments of the world say, `Right, there is to be a total elimination and the development of new substances by 1 January 1993', Du Pont says that industry will be able to meet that. The last thing it wants is a kind of hand wringing exercise where it is told, `Well, try to do the best you can and see how you go'. Industry wants a degree of certainty.

The other encouraging thing about the London conference was the number of nations attending which had not been at Montreal, particularly China, India, Brazil, the Republic of Korea and Thailand-the last two because they see themselves potentially as being both major exporters and very significant users of CFCs. I said in my London speech that we had to recognise that if the ozone problem was to be dealt with internationally it could not be done without pain, particularly as there was a strong risk of appearing to be hypocritical if in Australia, with four million households and four million refrigerators, we are saying to China, India and Brazil, `We think that refrigeration and air-conditioning are excellent for us but we think they would be an environmental disaster for you'. There was a recognition that among the advanced nations of the world there would have to be a very significant contribution in technology transfer in assisting the countries of the Third World to acquire the facilities so that they could have alternatives for packaging, refrigeration, air-conditioning, solvents, and so on.

There is a growing recognition, and the evidence is ever stronger, of the impact of depletion of the ozone layer for skin cancers, cataracts, breakdowns in the immune systems and, very significantly, the reduction in crop yield in a number of very important crops such as soya beans. Certainly, the conference provided the most heartening evidence, outside the experience of the Antarctic Treaty, in getting a global response to a global problem. That said, it must be admitted that solving the problems of ozone depletion is really a bit of a doddle compared with the much more complex problems of coming to grips with the greenhouse phenomenon. The hope is that if we can get that unanimity on ozone to start with it is a very good base to build for then approaching the problems of the greenhouse effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy: Given yesterday's admission by the Minister for Trade Negotiations that Australia's sugar exports to the United States could be reduced to near zero by congressional quota legislation, does the Government still intend to expose the Australian sugar industry to foreign dumping by removal of the sugar embargo from 1 July 1989?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter the Minister for Trade Negotiations was referring to with respect to American imports of sugar has been around for quite some time. The tonnages being imported into the United States under quota have gone down. What the Minister for Trade Negotiations was referring to particularly was the Gibbons Bill, which would make what has been ongoing in the United States for quite some time even more difficult. It has got to the situation now where the amount of imports going into the United States from Australia is getting down to a ship load or two. So that has been around for quite a long time.

ANSWER.PARA: The reality with the world sugar market is that in 1977, under the last Government, we entered into an international sugar agreement with economic provisions. That held us right back. Of course, in our wisdom we would not have the European Community in there. So it went on and now it is exporting about 11 million tonnes of sugar a year. Australia produces about 3 per cent of the world's sugar. We face a situation where the going price on the world market is one that any country can enter into. The industry in Australia lived through prices at one stage down to US2.3c a pound. We lived through that because we have a very resilient and efficient industry. All that holds back the extra efficiency of that industry is the Queensland National Party regulations. The industry could earn, potentially, another half a billion dollars a year if those regulations were lifted from it.

The honourable gentleman asked whether we intend to allow dumping. The short answer to that is no. With the world sugar market we have a better idea of the parameters of various sugar prices. The special Lome arrangements and the Caribbean arrangements, all the various subsidies that apply to European sugar, the new anti-dumping provisions we have in place and what we may be able to get additionally, and the fact that farmers and workers affected can now take out a case if there is any threat of dumping, lead us to believe that there will be no dumping of sugar. —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House on which criteria appointments are made to head up the departments and organisations for which he is responsible?

The Governor of the Reserve Bank was accused last year by the shadow finance Minister of politicising interest rates and the Governor made an unprecedented public rebuttal of those remarks. Now the Opposition mounts a personal attack upon the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Fraser, and then tries to do a Pontius Pilate to escape from the odium of that attack. In each and every case, these attacks are upon career public servants, people who have given their lives in public service and in all cases have been appointed to senior positions by a coalition government. Because there is an inability on that side of the House to debate major economic issues, it starts attacking the personalities.

Let me deal with the recent attack upon the Secretary to the Treasury by the shadow finance spokesman. Because he believed in speculation that I might consider recommending Mr Fraser's appointment as Governor of the Reserve Bank on the retirement of Mr Johnston, he said in a press statement the other day:
. . . the Treasurer's reported inclination to appoint one of his political mates as Bob Johnston's replacement should be a matter of considerable concern.
That is the kind of tawdry remark which has been made. When it is reported, he then rings and attacks journalists for having dared to report it and then puts out a statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have never done that.
—Yes, I do it on the basis of integrity. I do not do it to try to sligther out of remarks which I have made and which can reasonably be reported.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will heed the Chair.
—Then, in a statement released by the shadow finance spokesman two days later, on 2 April, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Contrary to what was implied by Mr Keating, I have not attacked Bernie Fraser as an individual.

He just sought to destroy Mr Fraser's reputation as a career bureaucrat capable of independent thought and action. Let me refer to a speech he made to the Urban Institute on 8 March. Speaking of me, he said:
He remains a total captive of his politicised Department and their jargon.
These are the attacks made upon the Treasury and its Secretary by the shadow finance spokesman.
Let me turn now to his remarks about the Governor of the Reserve Bank. Last week he had the temerity to put out a statement saying:
Governor Johnston's honesty is a refreshing change from Keating's disinformation.

He tried to suggest that some remarks by the Governor were in contrast to what I had said and were a mark of refreshing honesty by him. This occurred after the shadow finance spokesman had written a letter to the editor of the Australian Financial Review on 7 October 1988 about the Reserve Bank, in which he said:
. . . the Reserve Bank has, in the past, responded to political direction as in the case of the August bank holiday situation in 1984.
He went on to say:
Again, interestingly, monetary policy was tightened in April of this year following the NSW election held on 19 March.
In the same letter he said:

I was interested to see that the Governor of the Reserve Bank came out from behind closed doors to defend himself last Thursday on the `Business Today' program . . . None that I saw actually scrutinised what the Governor said on that occasion. None questioned whether he had done so of his own accord, or in response to suggestions by others.
That is, that he was manipulated by me to appear. He went on to say-and listen to the arrogance of this statement:
The thing that particularly struck me about the Governor's performance last week was that he provided no real evidence in his defence.
That is, that the Governor is a politically manipulated person. He went on to say:
. . . his explanation was only a diversionary tactic and loaded with semantics rather than substance.
Finally, in the same letter the honourable member stated:
First, the Reserve Bank was more or less `leant on' by the Treasurer.

In other words, the Reserve Bank Governor is manipulated by me in the interests of tricking up interest rates in election campaigns. That is the charge made against him. But then, on 2 April, the honourable member said that he found the Governor's honesty `a refreshing change'. The Governor came out on television and, in response to that letter to which I have just referred, said:
I find it a very severe slur not only on the Board but also on the staff of the Bank.

In other words, he would have nothing of that from the shadow finance spokesman, who has no respect for his position even though the Governor was appointed by the former Treasurer, the present Leader of the Opposition, and has served governments of both sides well. Finally, we have the honourable member's remarks. Having had his attacks on Mr Fraser and the Governor reported by the press, he made these remarks to journalists at an Institute of Chartered Accountants seminar in Sydney held yesterday and reported in today's Australian Financial Review:

For the journalists present, in view of some recent experiences of mine, might I suggest that you go and sit in the corner and write a thousand times, `I will not misquote John Hewson, I will not misquote John Hewson, I will not misquote John Hewson . . .'
Really! Then we come to the Leader of the Opposition. He said on AM on 26 October:
I think one of the mistakes of the Tax Commissioner is that he buys into political debates.
In other words, the Commissioner of Taxation is stigmatised as well. Then today on the radio he made the most unbelievable statement about Bernie Fraser. He said:
I am not playing the man, I am playing the issue.

In other words, the Liberals will attack Mr Fraser as being a person who is a political mate of the Treasurer even though he also served their Government well. They will attack him on the basis that he should not be appointed to the board of the Reserve Bank of Australia-whether the Government intends to appoint him or not. Then there followed a totally fraudulent line, that the stream of advice that should come to the Government from the Reserve Bank should be different advice from that which should come from the Treasury Secretary; yet, in the same breath, the Leader of the Opposition said that we could have some outsider, some person who has been playing the money market game for a merchant bank or some other financial institution and generally making money at the expense of the public purse by speculating in the system. The Leader of the Opposition suggested that such a person could be appointed to the Reserve Bank, but not a person who had served Australia in the high position of Secretary to the Australian Treasury.

What disingenuousness this all is. It simply boils down to the fact that no public servant is now free from attack by the Opposition; not the Commissioner of Taxation, who presided over a clean up of the tax system which was left to fall into disrepute by the former Treasurer; not the Governor of the central bank, who has presided over the most major reformation ever of a financial system and a terms of trade and currency collapse to boot. He is attacked and called a political stoolie. The Secretary to the Treasury, who has served governments of both sides well, is called a political mate of the Treasurer's.

Then the Leader of the Opposition, instead of having the decency to retract those comments and chastise his shadow spokesman who makes these comments continually about career public servants for whom he has no regard or respect, goes on radio and says, `I am not playing the man; I am playing the issue'. This was on the pathetic defence that the Government of Australia should have a line of advice from the Reserve Bank of Australia which in some way is so vastly different from the Treasury that no Secretary to the Treasury could ever be appointed but some hustler from a merchant bank could, or some hustler from the financial markets could-as if they would know what is fit, proper and right about economic advice, having never given any advice to any government in the past-despite the fact that, on a number of occasions, former coalition governments have appointed Treasury secretaries to the Reserve Bank. There is a most insidious and disturbing trend of attacks on people who serve the public interest in career positions and who cannot defend themselves, by people who have no regard for their independence and their personal and career integrity.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The urgent need for the Government to implement microeconomic policies to prevent the high rate of inflation and high interest rates of inflation and high interest rates further undermining living standards.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance that is before the House today states:

SPEECH.PARA: The urgent need for the Government to implement microeconomic policies to prevent the high rate of inflation and high interest rates further undermining living standards.

Those words could almost have come from the Governor of the Reserve Bank. Last week the Governor of the Reserve Bank-and I have just one newspaper reporting it-in an almost unprecedented set of actions within 24 hours gave two warnings, as the Australian says, that financial markets and the entire economy are `heading for more turbulence and higher interest rates'. The Governor is quoted in a report written by Laura Tingle, and as a substantiation of this discussion of the matter of public importance I will read what he said:
The so-called micro policies of reform-of work practices and the established ways of doing things-have a major role to play in raising productivity.
These are more-not less-urgent when all is not going smoothly at the macro level.

That was the second of the warnings. Regarding the statement that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is to bring down on 12 April, we were told some months ago that it would be just a wage-tax trade-off. Then we were going to have the blueprint for micro-economic reform, which has been delayed since the election of 1987. Then we got another change. The statement was degutted. It was to be simply a wage-tax deal with some dollops-justifiably-for pensioners, some changes in family assistance, and that was it. Why? Because not only has this Government given up on fiscal policy and sold out on wages policy, but also it has been utterly unable to perform on micro-economic policy and turn around the fundamental imbalances that are strangling this economy at present. There is no doubt that the Government members have failed as economic managers, failed on inflation, failed on interest rates, failed on the balance of payments and debt, and failed on living standards-macro policy out, and no micro policy. Those failures are a failure for the nation.

Yesterday the national accounts came out. The Government's economic mismanagement was highlighted yet again with the release of the national accounts for the December quarter. The figures depict an economy ridden with high inflation. Indeed, on a measurement that the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), constantly focuses on, the implicit price deflator, which I spent hours talking with him about-a broader measure, as he is aware, of inflation than the consumer price index-inflation increased by almost 9 per cent in the year to December 1988. The Treasurer, in his speech last September to the Economic Planning Advisory Council, claimed:
The wage tax trade-off we will implement will secure a further fall in inflation to around 3 to 4 per cent in 1990.

Quite clearly, that cannot be delivered-any more than the extent of our balance of payments was to improve. The reality is that the Budget strategy, which within seven weeks the Opposition said was wrong and that we would need a major statement dealing with both macro and micro policies-deferred, however-was predicated on an inflation rate of 4.5 per cent, and it is nearly 8 per cent-if one takes the broader measurement yesterday, it is 9 per cent-on an improving balance of payments situation, which has worsened, and on the continual predictions of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and others that interest rates would go down, and they have gone up.

One of the reasons that the Governor of the Reserve Bank was moved in this unprecedented way to issue the warnings he did last week was that he recognises that he is trapped at the Reserve Bank viewing a government that is pursuing a one-dimensional policy. This one-dimensional policy means continued high interest rates, which not only cast doubt on the sustainability of the recent pick-up in investment, but also savagely attack Australian living standards. I have said it before: Low to middle income Australian families have been taking a hammering under six years of Labor. Yet the Government prefers to jack up interest rates rather than use a more balanced policy mix.

It will dribble out advice from time to time that interest rates will go down. The Treasurer was asked by me today about Westpac's move on its lending rate, lifting it to 18.75 per cent. I asked what the consequence was for the mortgage rate. He said, `This is the prime rate used through the corporate sector' and abused me for linking it in that manner. The only reason in my view-challenge it if you will-why Westpac would not raise its home loan rate after this rise would be political. It is true that the prime lending rate is the rate which applies to corporate enterprises, but if there is upward pressure on the prime rate there will also be upward pressure on home loan rates. To say that those rates are independent defies logic. In short, it is apparent that the prime rate is the leading interest rate and others follow, albeit with a lag. The conditions which are driving the prime rate are quite clearly also driving home loan rates.

No-one on this side of the House has gone around the country talking interest rates up or down. It is the Government side of politics that gets into it, but it will not deal with the conditions that have brought the crippling interest rates in the country today. To plead ignorance or use personal abuse to get out of it does not seem to add up. The Governor of the Reserve Bank has made a public plea. Can anyone in this House recall any previous occasion on which a Governor of the Reserve Bank on two occasions in 24 hours has called into question the policy of the Australian Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —Never before.
—No. It has never happened before. The Governor of the Reserve Bank has been critical of the Government. When the Treasurer was asked about it on Sunday, on the program Face to Face, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Bob-
meaning this time Bob Johnston-
said nothing that I don't agree with.

That is having a bob each way. How could anyone agree with the sort of criticism that the Governor of the Reserve Bank made and take no action in a major statement to be brought down in the course of the next 10 days or so? Only early last month the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) claimed:
A lot of people were thinking that it-
the April statement-
was just going to be an announcement of tax cuts. I think you'll find there'll be more in it than that.

Yet on 22 March the Treasurer announced tht the micro-economic reform had been moved off the agenda. I urge honourable members to note the confluence of dates, to note the message, to note the plea from the Governor of the Reserve Bank, but the Treasurer still announced that microreform had been moved off the agenda. Before the week was out, on two occasions in less than 24 hours the Governor of the Reserve Bank, no less, slated the programs and the policies of the Government. We have listened to the facades, the jargon and the platitudes. This Government strokes its platitudes about the state of the economy until they purr. Not even the Governor of the Reserve Bank will let the Government go with its forthcoming April statement without attacking it in advance, and justifiably so.

We on this side of the House will at least go to the people of Australia with a wide, coordinated agenda for economic reform. The Treasurer screams and tries to say that our fiscal policy is the same as that of the Government; it is not. It will be tighter, and we make no pretence about that. We will also relate wage increases to productivity. With those settings in place we will be able to have a steady monetary policy. We will then have the push on deregulation that the Government has not had the guts to tackle. We can spell out the areas and the changes on microreform, whether it be on the waterfront or in coastal shipping, that the Government has ducked again. It will not mention such changes in its April statement. On top of that, we have produced a schedule of 12 government bodies to privatise. The Government wants to privatise those bodies, but it cannot.

The Government comes in here with a one-dimensional policy, namely, screwing money supply-which has the effect of screwing living standards down for the majority of the Australian people. I do not care what jargon and platitudes are purred out in here. The Government claims it is rethinking and creating a greater and freer Australian economy, but its actions make it abundantly clear that it is only rearranging its prejudices. It will not carry out the reforms that are needed.

The simple test for the future conduct of the economy is who can push on further with deregulation. Can the Government handle labour market deregulation? It cannot. Can it carry out privatisation of government bodies, bearing in mind that Australia has one of the highest proportions of government-owned enterprises competing in the private sector in the whole of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development? The answer is no.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish!
—The honourable member for Calwell should have a talk with the Treasurer.
—That's just wrong.
—Order! The honourable member for Calwell will cease interjecting.
—He hasn't got his facts right.
—I warn the honourable member for Calwell.

—To give the honourable member for Calwell a simple allusion, I hear these constantly stroking statements by the Treasurer about how well the economy is going. It is a bit like the Treasurer standing on the 30th floor of a building and saying to a fellow who has fallen off the 50th floor, as he goes past, `So far you're all right'. There is a certain inevitability in certain indices locked into this economy, just as there is a certain inevitability in the analogy I just used. No amount of smooth talking about the state of the economy will override the reality that the Government is just not able to pursue the reforms that are necessary in this country now.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not care whether it is the privatisation program that the shadow Minister for business and consumer affairs has put around this country so successfully, and I do not care whether it involves the tying up of labour market deregulation through preferential share ownership schemes that offer employees a stake in their own enterprises or whether it involves the contracting out of programs that we have. All of them lead within our coordinated economic programs to giving the taxpayer value for money in the delivery of services. Beyond it all, through the fiscal, wages and monetary settings and the other micro-elements that I have mentioned there is a real ability to get inflation and interest rates down. The Government has given up on that.

Beyond that, on taxation, we have been able to illustrate the sort of real relief and bias towards families that will be given. I have said in here time and again-and the Treasurer has been unable to deny the figure; he tried on one occasion to play with it but that is all he ended up doing-that if we wanted to give back to a person on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children the same amount of disposable income he had in March of 1983, when the honourable member for Blaxland became Treasurer, we would have to give him $58 a week. That is the measure of the task. We would have to give such people a tax cut of $58 a week just to put them back to where they were in March of 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much will they get?

—They will get $20, on average. We do not know the scheduling. The Treasurer, to his credit, like Mandrake comes in and gazumps the media on occasions on these statements. I do not know what else will be in the statement other than the wage-tax trade-off, but it is supposed to be around $20 a week. At present, if that scheduling is right, people will be $38 a week worse off even after the tax cuts. It matters not whether we are discussing macropolicy, micropolicy or all those areas of privatisation that the economy desperately needs. It is not now just the Opposition that is calling and pleading for changes and that has pledged to implement them; in the very week that the Treasurer said he had given up on microreform in his April statement the Governor of the Reserve Bank has come out and, in the words of the headline, said, `Reserve warns economy at risk'. That is searing, brutal stuff. People ignore the warnings of the Reserve Bank at their peril.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a change of tune for the Opposition. The Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia is now put on some pedestal in this debate while for the last two years Opposition spokespersons have attacked him as being a political toady of the Government. The shadow finance spokesman, in particular, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), has attacked him repeatedly and consistently as having politicised the Reserve Bank and the setting of interest rates. Apparently the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), now says people who ignore the warnings of the Reserve Bank Governor will do so at their peril, while week in week out, month in month out, Opposition members have suggested that the whole apparatus of the Reserve Bank is a politicised one which is governed by the Treasurer-me in this case-and that the Governor conspires with me to trick up interest rates in election campaigns. That is the charge against him. Now the disingenuous claim is that his word is holy writ and therefore things which he said last week have to be taken grave notice of. The fact is that things the Governor said last week are entirely in accordance with policy. I endorse everything that he said last week, which the Governor well knows.

SPEECH.PARA: The most extraordinary thing about raising the question of micro-economic reform today is that it is the very day that the Liberal Party of Australia has once again been boxed in on a key micro-economic issue; that is, that under a coalition government wheat deregulation is to be held hostage to the National Party of Australia, a repeat of the years of the Fraser Government. The single greatest impediment to sensible economic reform in this country since 1949 has been the Country Party, now the National Party of Australia. What we have seen is a sham, a shambles, a ruse coming from members of the Opposition today that they will not support wheat deregulation unless there is a concomitant change apparently in a whole range of sectors by the Government. In other words, they do not have the guts to adopt a bit of the deregulation they are actually suggesting the Government ought to adopt itself. When we put it up to them in the area of wheat marketing they run away as they have on each and every occasion. It simply confirms that a coalition government would not be capable of delivering real economic reform to Australia.

In Malcolm Fraser's Prime Ministership and John Howard's Treasurership it was proved that they could not change the financial market structure of this country, they could not deregulate the financial system, they could not float the exchange rate, they could not run a decent monetary policy and they could not have a coherent fiscal policy. This was all vetoed by the National Party. That veto is still there today. In fact, the shadow finance spokesman, the honourable member for Wentworth, has said as much. In commenting on the former Treasurer, he said that he could not get anything through the Cabinet, he was always run over by the farmers. The fact is that members of the Opposition will always be run over by the farmers because they do not have any policy structure. They would not have known what the term `miro-economic reform' was until we started using it in economic debate, and certainly they did none of it. Yet today the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong, talks about more deregulation and the Government adopting a micro-agenda. Apparently he says all this because he believes that the Opposition cannot compete with the Government in micro-economic policy.

Today, a day after the national accounts have been published, the debate is not about macro-economics; it is about micro-economics. It is not only the very day that those opposite cannot face up to a substantial micro-economic issue on wheat deregulation, but the day after the national accounts they cannot come to the macro-economic agenda. In the last sittings of parliament the shadow Treasurer told us that he would adopt the same fiscal policy as the Government. He is now saying today, in what he thinks will be understood as a hairy-chested performance, that he will have a tighter fiscal policy. That means one or two things: that he would not give the tax cuts which the Government is intending to give, that he would hang onto the money and increase the surplus, in which case, all these crocodile tears about living standards are just so much nonsense, or if he gives tax cuts he would have to cut public outlays substantially. Let him say where those public outlays cuts will be. Let him tell us which areas of public policy, whether it is pensions, support for veterans, payments to schools, payments for health or payments to the aged. Let him tell us where the dramatic reduction in public spending is to be to make that fiscal policy tighter. He will not. He has never shown any inclination to do that. The shadow finance spokesman has one job in life; that is to detail cuts in government spending under a coalition government. He has singularly failed to do so. We can only come to the conclusion that on macro-economic policy members of the Opposition are not game to outline an alternative policy, so today they are up to the question of micro-economic reform.

On the way through this collage of views that the shadow Treasurer assembled in the discussion, he started talking about labour market deregulation. We have just been through, and probably are still in, the conditions where, when we last saw these conditions in Australia in 1980-81, the terms of trade rose and economic activity and demand rose. Under a coalition government wages went up by about 16 per cent in nominal terms. That then gave us a wage explosion, double digit inflation, tight interest rates, a recession and high unemployment. Those opposite have not done one bit of conceptual thinking which would change that outcome today. They could not run wages if it were the last thing they were required to do. It is a fact of life that the only political party in this country which can run wages policy is the Australian Labor Party. The party which can run wages policy is the only party which can claim to be able to run the national economy. In this country if a government cannot run the issue, which is wages policy, the principal determinant of costs, it cannot run Australia. We have found that those opposite do not have an incomes policy or a wages policy. If we were to supposedly `adopt' their deregulation of the labour market-that is a free for all where the unions fought it out with companies on an enterprise company by company basis-they know what would happen: companies' profit share would be massacred, there would be lay-offs, we would have high unemployment and very quickly thereafter a recession. That is what would happen. That is why Bert Evans from the Metal Trades Industry Association (MTIA) said last week and on television over the weekend, `We don't want a return to these sorts of policies. We don't want a free for all. We want an income; we want an orderly structure'.

It is a fact of life that the only party in Australia capable of providing an orderly, reasoned wages and cost structure for the economy is the Australian Labor Party under its relationship with the accord, in the accord with the Australian trade union movement and, hence, the work force. According to yesterday's national accounts we have had moderate wages growth. I think we have had 0.1 per cent for the September quarter rise, virtually no drift in face of the tightest labour market conditions in six or seven years and then moderate outcomes over the course of the year which, under a coalition government, would be just skyrocketing wage increases and not bringing any comfort to anybody. What would happen to people is that we would just rip them off in higher double digit inflation which would follow a few months later.

Members of the Opposition have sat there now for six years, going to their seventh year, and not once have they ever thought, `Maybe we have to develop a policy in this area'. The most important area in the micro-economy is wages policy. They do not even have a policy. They are no better equipped today than they were in 1983-84 and yet they come in here talking about the micro-agenda. But then they have this totally phoney appeal on living standards.

We heard the shadow Treasurer get up and talk about living standards and interest rates. Members of the Opposition have opposed every wage increase since 1983-84. Thirty-four per cent of the wages of average weekly earnings would not be there had they had their way. That being the case, on one hand they are crying about payments in interest rates for houses and on the other hand they would rip away 34 per cent of the wages of the average Australian. That is what they have advocated. They advocate this and at the same time they talk about living standards. The fact of the matter is that paying high wage increases-increases that the economy could not afford-would just disrupt the cost structure, lead to double digit inflation and many people would simply be out of work. But they have no basic remedy for that policy. To disguise the fact that they have opposed every wage increase since 1983-84, they are now saying, `We will now have a sort of softer, kinder industrial relations policy. We will now pay on the basis of productivity'. They expect people to say, `Oh well, that is reasonable, yes. If you are productive you get paid, if you are not productive you are not paid. That is fair enough'. What is the trend with productivity in Australia? It is 1 1/2 per cent a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not according to the OECD.

—The honourable member should go and look at his own statistics. What those opposite would pay to people is 1 1/2 per cent a year, not the 6 1/2 per cent to 7 per cent which is being paid under this Government and which will be paid under the accord with increases in after tax income coming from tax cuts. Those opposite will have nothing to do with that. What they will do is go back to the bread line policy if they can. They will make people work for a 1 1/2 per cent wage increase. When we decode productivity-based increases, what that means is an increase that no labour force would accept and there would then be a wages breakout and with it a wage explosion. In other words, those opposite are propagating a policy that they know is completely unachievable and unworkable. Yet they persist with the fiction, the dishonesty and the ruse of suggesting that this is an alternative wages policy. Not one industrial grouping of companies in this country would cop a bar of it-not the Confederation of Australian Industry, not the Business Council of Australia, not the MTIA or the Chambers of Commerce. None of them would have any confidence in the Opposition running the economy. Not one of them would entrust wages growth to the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition thinks it can rattle along saying, `Look, we have much the same sort of macropolicy as the Government and we are looking to the future by steering back to the 1950s with Future Directions. We will just waddle to the poll and people will not know the difference'. Let me tell the Opposition that before it gets to that poll people are going to know one thing, and that is that only Labor can run wages and the economy. Only the Australian Labor Party has a structure for government in Australia. The people will make a choice between a reasoned, orderly structure and the wage chaos and confrontation that the Opposition gave us in the 1970s. The previous Government had a mandate, as no other government had a mandate, in 1975 and 1977, with control of both Houses of Parliament, to reform the Australian economy and it failed singularly, through either ineptitude or downright cowardice. It gave us a wage explosion because it had no wages policy. The confrontation, the industrial disputation, the pitting of employer against employee-all of that strife and upheaval which was a characteristic of the Howard years as Treasurer in the 1970s-would be simply repeated by those opposite in another government. That is why the Opposition has no policy and no structure and why the Labor Party is the only party which can provide certainty, order and continuing structural change in the economy and wages.

The Opposition is talking about micro-economic policy. In the most important area it does not have a policy. In other areas, such as that of tax reform, it has attacked all the things we have done. When we put one thing on its plate and say, `Make a decision about wheat deregulation'-that is a pretty reasonable proposition in a domestic market-what does the Liberal Party do? It runs around like a chook with its head cut off because the National Party is squeezing it again and showing how weak it is. The National Party says `We won't have a bar of it. We will block all sensible economic reform', just as it did through all the years of Fadden, McEwen-particularly McEwen-and then Anthony. All of that thuggery which the National Party brought to economic decision making and which the Liberal Party cowered under would be repeated were those opposite to come to office. They think that somehow demand is higher than it ought to be and that that is spilling over into imports. They say, `Here's our chance, we'll break through here'. No serious person in this country who understands the economic parameters would cop tuppence worth--

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been predicting it for 18 months. None of your Treasury blokes predicted it.

—The shadow finance spokesman, the honourable member for Wentworth, chips in. He advised a former Treasurer. He could not get one micropolicy change. He could not float the dollar or adopt any of the recommendations in the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. He could not run a decent fiscal policy. He left us with a fiscal shambles in 1983-84, but he was advising a former Treasurer. When it all fell over he was out there in the good times setting up restaurants and driving around in the Ferrari. Now he is back looking after living standards, saying that his people are the ones who know. I will tell him this: they are the people who do not know and everyone knows that they do not know. That is why no hollow shambles of an exercise such as today's matter of public importance which has been brought forward by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong-thinking he is getting the jump on the honourable member for Wentworth because he is embarrassed by his runaway lip-will smother the fact that he does not have a policy and it is only the Government that can run not just the macro-economy but the micro-economy as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of satisfaction to be able to second the matter of public importance put forward by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). I am very surprised that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is leaving the chamber. I would have liked to say a few words to him. I agree with the Treasurer that it is only the Australian Labor Party that can be run by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). We have seen that happen with wages policy. In fact, whenever there is anything to be done by the Government the first thing it does is get on the phone to the ACTU saying, `Is that all right? Can we do this?'. Whatever the issue is-the MX missile test, uranium mining, wages policy or fiscal policy-the Treasurer gets on the phone to the ACTU. We are used to that situation, but it is not doing the country much good. I will say a little more about that later.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer remarked on how farmers run over the Liberal Party and the National Party. I say to him that farms produce most of this country's wealth today and without farmers we would all be shot. I think it would pay the Government, in its own interests, to take heed of what the farmers say, because without farmers this country would be in a sorry state.

There is no doubt that the Opposition has opposed wage increases. It has done so on a number of occasions because it knows that with the Government's taxation policy a wage increase is not worth anything to an average family man. The taxation policy does not just take back the wage increase; it does a lot more than that. As the shadow Treasurer said, the income of an average family with two children has dropped by about $58 to $60. If the Government gives a tax cut it will have to go to the people-have an election-because there is no way it can sustain it. Much as the people of Australia require a tax cut because of what has happened, no government could sustain it.

I am pleased to have this opportunity to speak because I get sick and tired of sitting here in the Parliament listening to Government members airing their concerns about people suffering poverty, about the elderly, the Aborigines, the ethnic community, homeless youth as I do not believe they understand the problems confronting those people. If they do understand, they certainly do not have the intestinal fortitude to make the decisions that will assist the poor unfortunates whom they allege they represent. Many of the groups I have mentioned, I must admit, at least obtain lip service from the Government, but the groups whose concern I wish to bring to the Government's attention today comprise the building blocks of this nation-Australian families. Many are middle and low income families. Where do they stand while the Government fiddles about the edges, afraid to make the micro-economic decisions that have to be made to keep this nation and its families together?

The irony of the situation is that, as honourable members may recall, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in his 1984 election policy speech that what concerns the ordinary Australian family is that there should be jobs available for parents and in the future for their children; that they are able to purchase their own homes at a reasonable cost and not have to face crippling interest payments; that their children receive an education which equips them in the best possible ways for their lives ahead; and, above all, that every Australian family should have the opportunity to maintain and improve its standard of living. We all recall the Prime Minister's statement in the 1987 election speech when he said, `By 1990, no Australian child will be living in poverty'.

All honourable members are aware that during its six years in office the Hawke Labor Government has failed abysmally to live up to is commitments to the Australian family. Through its high taxing policies, its continued support for high inflation and high interest rates and its attack on traditional values, the Federal Labor Government has actively jeopardised the continued viability and stability of many families. Those of us who have been married and supported families on low to middle incomes, living only from pay to pay, know how difficult it is to make up a few dollars to try to support the family. We also know the pressures that are placed on families due to money difficulties and worries. No doubt, today, that is partly reflected in the high divorce and separation rates that add further costs to government agencies.

Let us look at what has happened to Australian families since this Government came to office. As I have just said, the Prime Minister stated in 1984 that there should be jobs available for parents and in the future for their children. The Government has failed to help the young unemployed of this country. The figures for January 1989 show a continuing and unacceptably high level of youth unemployment. The overall unemployment rate for January was 7.4 per cent, the highest level since May 1988. The unemployment rate for 15- to 19-year-olds remains at an appalling level. At January 1989 it stood at 19.8 per cent, the same level as it was in March 1988. Of the 477,500 registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service in January 1989, 70,000 were people aged between 15 and 19 looking for their first job.

One of the most important areas in which the Government has failed in economic reform and, therefore, failed to assist the unemployed is in the area of industrial relations. It is not surprising that the youth of today are finding extreme difficulty in obtaining jobs, with our highly centralised, rigid wage fixing system. Only by deregulating the wage fixing system and increasing productivity will employers be able to afford to hire apprentices and young people in general. We know how difficult it is for young people to get jobs. Anyone who has been an apprentice would know the time and effort it takes for a tradesman to teach an apprentice. Most tradesmen today do not have the time or money to teach apprentices. The Government's refusal to make reforms in this area is forcing young people to remain on the unemployment benefit, to live below the poverty line, and it is hampering Australia's ability to increase its productivity and economic prosperity through increased exports. It is not surprising that the unemployment rate in each year of the Hawke Government has exceeded the rate for any other year in Australia's postwar history, apart from the drought year of 1982-83.

The Government argues that job opportunities have increased, but the interesting thing is that half of the jobs have been taken up by married women. Among couples with dependent children, the proportion where the mother works has risen from 46 per cent to 55 per cent. Why is this? Certainly there are many women who wish to leave the home for their own fulfilment or for other reasons, but there are also many situations where mothers wish to stay at home and care for their children but are forced into the work force because they find they cannot survive financially unless they join it.

What about the Prime Minister's statement that Australian children should receive an education which equips them in the best possible ways for their lives ahead? The Government certainly has a long way to go on this one with its cut backs to State governments which have forced the States in turn, particularly New South Wales, to prune their educational expenses. People in rural New South Wales are certainly being discriminated against with the assets test being related to the Austudy payments, but we in rural Australia, while producing most of Australia's wealth, are used to this Government's continued attacks on the bush. We all know that there is no such thing as free education, and the monetary policy presently being practised by the Federal Government, particularly in its cut-backs to the States, will preclude many children from even finishing their secondary education, let alone getting into the tertiary area.

In the private education sector, it is interesting to note that, according to a report to Australia's bishops from a Melbourne parish, Catholic education is now out of the reach of large families. But the greatest let-down for struggling families from the Prime Minister's 1984 policy speech is that, above all, every Australian family should have the opportunity to maintain and improve its standard of living. What a joke that would be if it did not entail so much suffering.

Let us look at the standard of living of Australian families. Most Australians, even those most supportive of the Government, are now realising that they have suffered a drop in living standards since this Government came to office. The tax taken from the people has increased from $40.8 billion in 1982-83 to a massive estimated $82.3 billion in 1988-89, with personal income tax in that year rising 13.8 per cent to be the highest ever. Inflation is now running at 9 per cent. Interest rates are skyrocketing. The Treasurer's macro-economic policies are failing.

But many of these large figures do not mean much to struggling families. Figures that do mean something are in relation to things like family allowances. I can recall being the breadwinner in a single income family trying to make ends meet, like everyone in the neighbourhood and most of Australia at that time. Even though the family allowance was not much then, it was eagerly awaited so that it could buy some shoes, singlets or small clothing items for the children. Since that time the family allowance has declined to less than half the value of that obtained when I was raising a family. In May 1983, the family allowance supplement helped low income families who were not in receipt of a social security pension benefit. It was replaced by the family allowance supplement from December 1987. While the supplement has helped low income families, it has not noticeably reduced poverty levels and does not help average families.

I turn to the cost of interest payments. We hear today that the Westpac Banking Corporation has put up its interest rate to 18.75 per cent, so we can now expect further increases in home loan interest rates. But what did the Government do to overcome the problem? It once again called a talkfest. Why? Because it has learned through experience that perceptions are important because it does not want to do anything to upset its mates. This Government decided to abolish negative gearing right at the time the housing industry was starting to slump, making the situation even worse. Then it decided to bring back negative gearing at a time when the housing industry was starting to pick up. This has now resulted in tremendous pressures on the housing market.

They are the same people who left Labor an inheritance in the year before we took government of 250,000 Australians losing their jobs. They are the same people who brought industrial disputes to an art form. They are the same people who left us with a retention rate in the schools of 36 per cent, a rate which in our six years of government is now close to 60 per cent. They are the same people who in seven years gave us five health schemes and left two million people uncovered for health care. During our six years of office the Opposition has given the nation five health spokesmen and as many proposals for a health scheme, but nothing concrete. SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting to note in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald a report under the heading `The facts of life behind our white picket fences'. The article suggests that the structure of a family in Australia is changing significantly. I quote from the article:

The Liberal Party has renewed recently its `back-to-the-future' message to the electorate but the Census figures show that only 36 per cent of Australia's family homes are occupied by a traditional nuclear family.

That figure is only 36 per cent, and indeed a very significant demographic change is occurring in this country. In considering policies for the future we need also to consider the demographic changes which are occurring. For instance, the number of single parent families is increasing. They are the people who are most at risk when one talks about living standards. They are the people to whom we should be giving most attention, because it is the children of those single parent families who suffer the most.

Let us look at the Liberal Party's record on single parent families. Let us take the example of a sole parent family with two children aged 13 and 8. In 1976 when the Liberal Party was in government that family received $57.75. In 1983 when that Government went out of office that family received $103.25. In December 1988 that family received $191.25. So one sees that under the previous Government the single parent family with two children-those who are the subject of most concern when we consider families-suffered a 7.76 per cent drop in real terms in their standard of living as a result of the coalition's time in government. Under Labor the same family has received a real increase of 24.1 per cent. We find in respect of pensioners a real increase in pension of 10 per cent over the time that we have been in government. Yet Opposition members in this place cry crocodile tears about living standards.
This matter of public importance relates to the:
need to implement microeconomic policies to prevent the high rate of inflation and high interest rates further undermining living standards.

Yet in the areas of education, health and the provision of jobs, Opposition members during their time in government failed completely. What is worse, and what is most disturbing from this side of the House, is that Opposition members are not providing any alternative suggestion. The big panacea today is that micro-economic reform should be introduced. That is the bandaid for this week. It is the thing that will solve the problem all of a sudden! The shadow Treasurer has got into his mind the idea that micro-economic reform is the way to go and that it will suddenly change the position. When we ask Opposition members about their macro-economic policy, we find very little difference between the policy pursued by Labor and that which would be pursued by the Opposition. Opposition members say that they will cut spending but they will not tell us where or how that would impact on living standards. We want to know, as the people of this country deserve to know. Opposition members say that they intend to deregulate wages. They should tell us what they intend to do and how they will do it and what changes will be wrought as a result.

If we look at what this Government in- herited from the coalition Government, we learn some salutary lessons. That Government gave Labor a deficit of nearly $10 billion. Now in this Budget year we are facing a surplus of nearly $5 billion or more-$6 billion perhaps. We do not know the actual figures, but there will be a substantial surplus. For the second time in 35 years we have a surplus on our domestic Budget. Yet Opposition members are trying to tell us that Labor cannot manage the economy.

Let us look at the topic of tax evasion. It was a royal commissioner appointed by the Liberal-National Party coalition who said that Australia's fastest growing industry was that of tax evasion, at a cost of billions of dollars to ordinary Australians. Yet when we came to government we had to pick up a tax system which was in pieces and through which one could drive a truck-there were holes everywhere. There was double taxation on dividends, which hardly encouraged enterprise and profit. Also in existence were the free lunch and fringe benefits available to those who were able to take advantage of them; but nothing for ordinary workers. There were distortions in investment which made speculation popular but gave no inducement for productive investment. We had marginal tax rates which are oppressive. The 60c in the dollar rate had been with us for more than 30 years. Where was the incentive in the taxation policy that the Opposition left us? Who has gone about reforming that system? This Government has. Who overcame the deficit? This Government did.

The Opposition talks about inflation in this motion. We have inflation running at 7 per cent. When we took over it was at 11 per cent or more. The Opposition hardly has the credentials to talk about overcoming inflation. We had an overvalued dollar. We had an unregulated financial structure. Indeed, in many areas this Government has created, through its farsighted macro-economic policies, an environment in which micro-economic reform can take place and in which the substantial micro-economic reforms it has put in place can grow and develop. There have already been many reforms.

The accord, while many on the other side would dispute its success, has been flexible. It is historic that the accord has broken down the automatic cost of living adjustments that were part of our structure previously. Indeed, we have now productive trade-offs and we have award restructuring occurring. These are significant changes which are an incentive to produce and to make a profit rather than the incentive to speculate that previously existed.

We can look at tariffs. We can look at some of the particular industries about which we have been wanting to hear about tariff reform from our opponents. During the Opposition's time in government the tariffs on motor vehicles increased. It is this Government that has cut tariffs. It is this Government that in May cut tariffs on average by 20 per cent in manufacturing areas. If we look at clothing and footwear we find that during the Opposition's time in government clothing and footwear protection increased 1 1/2 times. It is this Government that has turned that around. If we look at the steel industry we again find a consistent approach by this Government to restructuring and applying those criteria that will give that industry the possibility of being successful again.

We can talk about railways. There is concern about the way railways function in this country. If we look at the Federal Government's jurisdiction-at Australian National-we find that for the first time we have a break-even position in freight carriage in this country. So there have been successes. Yet when we talk to the Opposition about deregulating wheat marketing, suddenly we find the Country Party, the National Party of Australia or whatever one wants to call it acting in the old way with all the cloak and dagger stuff in the party room. We find it saying, `Unfortunately we cannot go ahead with deregulation there because it will affect our constituency'. We hear talk about privatisation and what we are going to do about Telecom Australia. We have hairy-chested statements from members of the Opposition time and time again, but when it comes down to the crunch the National Party says, `No, we don't want to cross-subsidise in the country; we have to be careful about what we do with Telecom'. There are many reforms that have already occurred in Telecom.

We hear talk about Australian Airlines. What was the legacy of the previous Government? It was the two-airline agreement which will be in place until next year. My goodness! The record of the Government has been outstanding in this area. We have started to put in place all of those changes that are necessary. We are not suggesting that there is a short term solution, which this motion suggests. We are suggesting that we have put in place things that in the long term will provide for the prosperity of this country. The Opposition's record is one of failure.
