TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the fourth, fifth and sixth reports of the Committee for 1989, relating to the construction of the National Biological Standards Laboratory (NBSL), Symonston, Australian Capital Territory; the site redevelopment of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) laboratories, stage 1, North Ryde, New South Wales; and the construction of a shell filling facility for the St Marys Munitions Filling Factory, New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The reports I have tabled relate to three projects considered by the Committee in December 1988 and bring the number of reports already presented by the Committee this year to six.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the proposal to redevelop facilities at the CSIRO North Ryde site, the Committee has concluded that to support Australia's research performance in the areas of biotechnology, mining and minerals, and energy there is a need to construct new research facilities and to replace existing inadequate structures. The cost of the work is estimated to be $18.5m at August 1988 prices.

CSIRO informed the Committee that the current proposal is the first stage of the redevelopment of the North Ryde site. Future works are expected for the divisions of exploration, geoscience and coal technology and include progressive demolition of 1500 square metres of substandard buildings; refurbishment of 2,000 square metres of existing accommodation; construction of 8,500 square metres of new accommodation; and improvements to roads, site entry, car parks and landscaping. These works are expected to be undertaken over coming years at an estimated cost of some $40m at current prices.

The Committee's final report in relation to the National Biological Standards Laboratory is for the construction of a laboratory complex of some 17,900 square metres and the conversion of an existing laboratory at Symonston, Australian Capital Territory, at an estimated cost of $51.4m at July 1988 prices. The Committee tabled an interim report relating to this project on 30 November 1988 indicating that it would be recommending in its final report the construction of the works in this particular reference.

The Committee's inquiry into the NBSL project is the second time that a proposal to upgrade NBSL accommodation has been examined by the Committee. In its ninth report of 1979 the Committee recommended the construction of a purpose-designed complex for the NBSL at an estimated cost of $26m at June 1979 prices. Preliminary site works were completed but the project did not proceed beyond that stage due to a series of reviews and inquiries into Commonwealth functions, including the NBSL.

Having examined a number of the laboratories occupied by the NBSL in the Canberra area, the Committee has concluded that there is an urgent need for the construction of a single purpose-built complex for the NBSL. The Committee believes that the work is necessary to overcome the problems caused by the poor state of much of NBSL's present accommodation and its dispersed distribution over many sites and buildings which has resulted in a number of operational, managerial and scientific inefficiencies.

The final report I have tabled refers to the construction of a shell filling facility for St Marys Munitions Filling Factory, New South Wales, at an estimated cost of $7.7m at April 1988 prices. The new facility will replace facilities which have been operating since 1958 and have now reached the end of their economic life due to high usage and general wear and corrosion. In addition, fume, dust and noise levels exceed current regulatory standards.

The existing facility also fails to meet North Atlantic Treaty Organisation safety principles, particularly in respect to safety distances to inhabited buildings. The Department of Defence advised the Committee that it expected that urban encroachment in the longer term-that is, beyond 25 years-would require the transfer of the munitions filling factory to another location. This, when it occurs, is estimated to cost about half a billion dollars. Following assurances from the Department of Defence and in view of the excellent safety record of the St Marys Munitions Filling Factory, the Committee is satisfied that safety risks posed by the proposed facility are minimal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1989 and oppose the amendment moved by the Opposition. While the Opposition does not decline to give the Bill passage through the House, it makes two claims. One claim is that the Government is not able to appreciate the special needs for assistance for students from rural areas, and the second claim concerns the so-called turmoil caused by the Government's policies on and administration of assistance for students in higher education institutions. Those two points alone show the barrenness of the Opposition's position in relation to education.

SPEECH.PARA: As a member from part of rural Australia-the electorate of McMillan, in Victoria, takes in a large section of that State-I do not believe it could be argued in that part of the world that this Government's policies do not take account of the special needs for assistance for students from rural areas. We have in my electorate the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education which, under the policies of this Government and the initiatives of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), has in the last three months negotiated an affiliation with Monash University. So Government policies have developed to the point where people in that rural area have a direct link and contact with one of the major universities in Melbourne. Prior to that the Gippsland Institute was, of its own volition, one of the leading institutions in Australia for external studies for students from many parts of rural Victoria and rural Australia. I am positive and very confident that after the final announcements are made this week in relation to this affiliation my electorate, Victoria and Australia will be well serviced by the Gippsland education facility in conjunction with Monash University. It is something that I have been very proud to be associated with. Whilst members of the Opposition may come into this House and talk about this Government not appreciating the special needs for assistance, they are ignoring the reality of what is happening in the real world, and that is that our policies are working and working very effectively.

The second of the Opposition's arguments suggests that our administration of assistance to students is causing turmoil. I question how members of the Opposition would judge turmoil because this was not explained by the shadow spokesman, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), in his speech. Not having heard the speech, I read the Hansard to see what he had to say. He certainly did not develop any evidence of any turmoil or of the problem of administration of students in higher education. He ignored what has happened as a result of Federal Labor Government policies in recent times.

Austudy is one of the platforms of the Australian Labor Party which has been developed over the past four or five years to the point where-and I will just cite some of the figures-the number of students receiving Austudy has increased markedly, from 187,000 in 1986 to 336,000 this year. The only turmoil that could be suggested in relation to that would be that there has perhaps been a lot of paperwork required in bringing this assistance to so many extra students.

This is part of the approach that the Federal Government has adopted in order to turn around the tragic retention rates that existed in Australia upon our coming to government in 1983. About 36 per cent of high school students were continuing to year 12. Today we are aiming at a target of 65 per cent and the retention rate at the present time is well in excess of 50 per cent. Austudy alone has been one of the great methods of assistance to families all over Australia, and students today have a clear choice as opposed to the lack of choices in the policies that we inherited. Under those policies young people who left school could get the unemployment benefit, but if they stayed on at school they could get nothing. That one item alone demonstrated the obvious policy vacuum in the nation's education system under the previous Government, which did not face up to the real issue-that there were problems in relation to keeping our young people on at school, not just educational problems but also economic problems, which had to be tackled very strongly.

This Government has aimed its first effort at the secondary schools. Having succeeded dramatically in lifting the participation rate at the high school level, we now have to move on and create more places in tertiary education, more places and opportunities in technical and further education colleges and in all those areas for these extra students who have been encouraged to stay at school. These students and their families have an expectation that they will be able to go on and obtain that extra education. That does not happen by chance. It will only occur if those extra places are made available. The Government's policy on this matter has been very good. Austudy was designed basically to help lower income families and to keep their children in education.

I will detail some of the changes which will operate in 1989. We are increasing the living allowance rates. We have higher living allowances aligned with unemployment benefit rates, particularly for disadvantaged people aged 21 years and over and for students with dependants. We have reached that point now where there is no disincentive to stay in education, and there is no positive incentive for one to leave education and take one's chances in a work force in which educated people are required. In the past many ex-students found themselves unable to get jobs because of that disincentive. We have changed the living away from home allowances. The maximum living allowance in 1989 ranges from $53.55 a week for students aged between 16 and 17 years and living at home to $116 a week for a special category of students aged 21 years or over, living away from home or independent. As I said earlier, the result of the Government's policies is that we have this massive lift in the number of students eligible for and receiving Austudy, from 187,000 in 1986 to 336,000 this year. Of course, the spending on Austudy in that time has risen from $438m to $840m this year. From the beginning of 1989 an assets test on Austudy recipients will make sure that the neediest students receive assistance.

This matter has been raised in the debate on this issue by our opponents on the other side of the House. A couple of speakers-the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) in particular-seemed to target in on the fact that it was a tragedy that people with great assets would no longer have the freedom to obtain Austudy payments. That may be the position of honourable members opposite but I am sure that, if they were to speak to high school students around Australia, they would find that there has been a deep resentment in the past by many families in Australia which, because of the means test on their incomes, were not eligible for Austudy yet they would see students whom they knew came from wealthy family backgrounds receiving Austudy because their taxation returns, clearly after genuine accounting, were not showing income at the levels related to the assets those families were working with. That measure has been put into place, along with other measures, which has made the system much fairer for those receiving Austudy.

I do not want to take a long time debating this matter. But I believe that education is the major issue in relation to where we are going as a nation. We had those tragic seven years where I believe we did not develop the policies that should have been developed at that time. We are starting from behind now. We are behind the rest of the world in relation to what we are doing in education. That has been accepted because other nations have had much higher retention rates for a longer time. We are moving towards that. As we start to reach the point of matching the position with similar nations we will certainly see the benefit of that in our industries and in our economy. We will certainly see the benefit of that not just in the cities but also in rural Australia.

This Government has put in place policies at the tertiary level. Whilst there has been a lot of discussion of white papers and green papers and comments made by people of different political persuasions, the initiative of the Minister has certainly livened up the debate on education. Amalgamations of many tertiary organisations are taking place now right across Australia. I am very pleased with what has occurred in my part of the world.

I take this opportunity publicly to put on the record my appreciation and the appreciation of every person who lives in my electorate of those people who took the initiative in relation to the opportunities offered by the policies of this Government. People from Monash University and from the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education immediately sat down and talked constructively to each other. People from Monash University came to the Latrobe Valley area where a task force which I established over two years ago is working for the good of the area. Some of the leading people in my community were able to take representatives from Monash University to companies such as the Australian Paper Manufacturers Maryvale mill. At this stage that company has research facilities with Monash University and with rural Australia. We were able to do this with the State Electricity Commission of Victoria which has the same facilities in our area. The Coal Corporation of Victoria and all these bodies were able to see the immediate benefits of the opportunities being put forward by this Government's policies and they publicly reacted positively to them.

I was very pleased to be involved in a series of meetings which took place. People such as Tom Kennedy, the Director of the Gippsland Institute, Crofton Hatswell, the Chairman of the Gippsland Council and Phil Shanahan who is the Regional Commission Director, all put in an enormous amount of work and effort along with the Chancellor of Monash University, Mal Logan, and his people to bring about an affiliation. We had a big day at the Gippsland Institute some weeks ago where that affiliation took place. I was pleased to be able to invite the Minister to come to witness that affiliation. Of course, this week we are expecting announcements in relation to distance education and I am quietly confident that we have done our homework and done it well.

We have put forward our case in relation to what will be happening with this affiliated Gippsland and Monash education structure that we now have. It can only benefit my part of the world, it can be of great benefit to Victorians, but with the new policies I think it can be of great benefit to people all over Australia. I am very proud to have been part of what has taken place in that area and I look forward to the results. To me those results will be clearly seen by our young students-those young people who, had they been in the system 10 years ago under the previous Administration, certainly would not have had anything like the opportunities that they will have today under this Government. I am sure that those people will fully appreciate for many years to come in their working lives that the opportunity that they have had was well worth the effort that has gone into it.

We have heard a lot about the so-called graduate tax; there has been a lot of debate in relation to it. As of today young people can confidently look forward to going into tertiary institutions with no up front costs, other than their own personal costs and their student union costs. No doubt, if they are fortunate enough to benefit from that education and move into the top one-third of income earners in this country they will be asked to contribute to that education. The figures that I have for school retention rates and for people coming back into education institutions show a big growth in the numbers who want to go to the Gippsland Institute and to other education organisations. This clearly indicates that the customers themselves appreciate this Government's policy. They are not boycotting it by any means. They appreciate the fact that they have a great opportunity to reach those higher income levels. That means that they will be able to afford to pay the 20 per cent that is expected and the community and the taxpayers will continue to spend their 80 per cent.

Commonsense has prevailed in this area. I believe that the public of Australia appreciates that. Looking back through the speeches of previous honourable members, in particular the Opposition spokesperson on graduate tax in the education area, the honourable member for Deakin, we see that he said:
We would abolish . . . indexed graduate tax, and replace it with an annual tuition charge of $600 . . .

That will certainly be rejected by those in the community who today can go into those facilities without having to pay money up front, without having to prove their worth and then pay, as against the Liberal policy which is demanding that everybody other than scholarship holders-and we do not know who they will be-will have to fork out $600 the day they walk into a tertiary institution. I strongly support the legislation before the House. I reject the amendment that has been moved by the Opposition. I appreciate having had the opportunity to speak in this debate.

Quite properly, the previous debate on this Bill covered the question of income assistance for students; the question of student fees or-under this Government-taxes; the question of financial and academic autonomy for universities and colleges; and the question of expansion of student places to meet existing and future demand. Notwithstanding the noise of a few self-appointed student spokespersons and their sympathisers in some sections of the media, there is, I believe, a consensus in the community on the question of student assistance and student fees. That consensus is based on a number of views. The first is that any capable person should have the opportunity to go on to higher education, irrespective of socioeconomic background. Second, Australia benefits when its young people and workers go on to higher education. Third, individuals benefit personally and significantly from the community's investment in their intellectual and professional development via a higher degree. Fourth, most of the beneficiaries of this investment have already been beneficiaries of an upbringing in the higher socioeconomic sections of the community.

The fifth point of consensus is that Australia faces severe economic restraints. There are competing social and welfare programs of importance and urgency which are just as great as the provision and expansion of publicly subsidised higher education. Sixth, given those restraints and competing needs and given the salary, status and life opportunity benefits accruing to graduates, there should be some contribution by a student to higher education costs over and above normal tax paid by all citizens. Seventh, in recognition of the benefits to the community, as a result of the skills formation and higher taxation paid from degree-related incomes, the community should contribute the bulk of funds towards higher education. Eighth, scholarships and income assistance are justified in terms of equal opportunity and incentive to study.

That is the consensus which I believe exists today in our community. The problem for the Government has been its inability to embody these principles in legislation in a clear, competent and productive way. The Government's approach has reflected its centralist and levelling philosophies. It has produced unnecessarily high contribution rates for students, a bureaucratic monstrosity to collect that contribution, a reduction in institutional autonomy within the system, and no resources for the current backlog of demand. The coalition policy approach does the exact opposite. It will minimise the student contribution; it will eliminate unnecessary bureaucracy; it will maximise institutional freedom and diversity; it will nurture excellence; and it will provide funding for an immediate expansion of higher education places.

The question may well be asked: How will the coalition Government of the Leader of the Opposition do this? His Government will restore autonomy to all higher education institutions and dismantle the centralised bureaucracy and the unified national system. It will abolish the system of Commonwealth-imposed educational profiles and it will withdraw the arbitrary requirements for amalgamations imposed by the present Government. It will stimulate healthy competition among institutions which will promote excellence of achievement amongst students, staff and institutions. It will modify the Labor Government's policy guidelines for the Australian Research Council to ensure excellence and reduce bureaucratic interference, which is an element that has set the Council back. It will allow State governments more responsibility in planning the future development of higher education in their States. It will maintain, through the rolling 1989-1991 triennial system, the number of places projected in the 1988 Budget by granting national education awards. It will provide institutions with funds to allow the grant of national education scholarships, or free places, to a level no less than 25 per cent of the holders of national education awards. It will abolish the Labor Party's $1,800 indexed higher education contribution scheme, known as the graduate tax, and replace it with a $600 annual tuition charge to be paid by non-scholarship students directly or through a loan scheme.

A Howard government will permit institutions to offer additional places on any basis they see fit. It will facilitate, by government guarantee or other means, commercial loan arrangements for those students who wish to borrow the amount of their obligations to institutions so as to make the payment. It will encourage institutions, corporations, State and local governments, voluntary organisations, statutory authorities, business and individual donors, to provide funds for scholarships and additional places. It will allow institutions to develop new sources of revenue to supplement government funds. It will encourage the establishment of non-government higher education institutions. It will conduct an independent inquiry to ensure that the post-graduate awards system is adequate and it will thoroughly review the rules and administration of Austudy.

The coalition has no major objection to this Bill. However, its comprehensive alternative policy approach and the amendment moved by the honourable member for Deakin highlight the lost opportunity truly to reform our higher education system in the interests of the nation and in particular of the young people whom this Bill represents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have this opportunity to speak in support of the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1989. Although, with regard to the Bill's financial impact, the proposed amendments have no financial implications other than some minor administrative savings, the very fact that we are looking at different aspects of Austudy and policies introduced by this Government puts this Bill in context with an overall forward thrust by the Hawke Government to ensure that there is a linking of economic output with educational outcomes in a program of social reform which I believe is the best program the people of Australia have ever seen.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very proud to be part of the Government which implemented that program. Because of that, I am rather concerned at the tenor of the amendment put forward by the members of the Opposition. One aspect, the need for special assistance to students from rural areas, has been capably addressed by the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham). He is very involved with the rural sector and goes out of his way, in Caucus, in Government meetings, and in every forum, to see that those students' interests are represented, particularly in the areas of employment, education and training.

The second aspect I view as extremely irresponsible, in the context of the serious change which Government members are trying to introduce to the benefit of Australians, is the Opposition's amendment condemning the Government for `the turmoil caused by its policies on, and administration of, assistance for students in higher education institutions'. I reject the implications of the Opposition's amendment, for it is just such irresponsible statements which paint an altogether incorrect picture in the eyes of members of the public, and particularly our student body or some sectors of it.

There have been unfair and ill-based criticisms distorting the Hawke Government's record in supporting Australian students. I would like to put that record straight. I do not know what the root of this distortion is, although the amendment gives me a very good idea, but it is certainly not supported by fact.

The facts show, for example, that since coming to office the Labor Government has more than tripled funding for student income support and more than doubled, in six years, the number of students assisted by the Liberals in their last year of office. I believe that part of the problem has arisen as a result of a distortion or misunderstanding of the factors underlying the imposition of the higher education contribution scheme, the so-called graduate tax. I do not attack our student body for this. I have great admiration for the quality of young Australians, both within the student body and without. There may be students who have not at this stage thought the issue through. I support the contribution scheme because I would rather see more young Australians desirous of gaining education within the student body. I know that I am not alone in this. There are many students like Michelle Healy from Bracken Ridge in my electorate who are willing to meet and desirous of meeting part of the cost of their tertiary education once they are in a decently remunerated job if it means that others can enjoy the same opportunity. I mention Michelle because she is one member of the student body who has publicly stated this opinion in Brisbane newspapers.

I understand the desire of people to retain the benefits of a free education. I certainly give education funding high priority. It is money well spent, money which will come back to the community in a variety of ways, providing higher standards of living for all Australians. But I find no conflict between this stance and the record of my Government in providing education facilities-to the contrary. A government has at last had the fortitude to tackle a domestic deficit and an international debt which has been allowed to burgeon by governments more interested in buying their way into power through the vote than in providing a stable economy for the long term advantage of all Australians. Any commentator or observer who looks at the history of the voting pattern and of promises made at election time would have to agree with that statement.

It is in this context that the Government accepted the Wran recommendations on higher education. In doing so, doors have been closed on no-one. Everyone in Australia who is desirous of entering higher education and who meets certain qualifications can now enter the doors of opportunity to higher education. The number of tertiary education students will increase as a result of the imposition of the higher education contribution scheme. The resultant broadening of access to education will be entirely in keeping with this Government's record in employment, education and training.

I invite all Australians interested in basing their judgment and opinions on factual data to consider some key indicators of just what this Government is about. I refer firstly to our support for schools. Education is mainly a State responsibility. The States are responsible for 80 per cent of education funding. But the Federal Government is able, by targeting funding to schools, to assist in raising the quality of education offered to Australians. In this context, the general recurrent grants program is a crucial part of the national effort to strengthen Australian schools. The program aims better to prepare the nation's young people to undertake education and training after they finish school, to participate successfully in the labour market, and to contribute to and benefit from Australian society.

In 1985, for the first time, the Labor Government started an eight-year funding plan for schools with real annual increases guaranteed in legislation. At the end of the eight-year funding period, 1985 to 1992, per capita grants to government schools will have increased in real terms by 34 per cent for each primary student and by 102 per cent for each secondary student. That is a very large increase, and it is in real terms. Grants to non-government schools will have increased in real terms by up to 40 per cent for each primary student and up to 30 per cent for each secondary student. These facts speak for themselves. They can be checked.

I would like to touch specifically on the way in which this Government has sought and acted to protect Australian students and how we have shown our support in a tangible way. In 1982, under the Fraser Government, less than $200m was expended on student income support-$188.3m, to be exact. Since coming to office, the Labor Government has more than tripled this figure, assisting students in 1988 at a cost of over $720m. Under the Liberals, less than 116 students were assisted in 1982. In only six years the Hawke Government has more than doubled this figure, assisting over 285,000 young people to the end of 1988. Particular attention has been paid to retention rates, that is, encouraging young people to remain in school. School retention rates to year 12 increased from 36 per cent in 1983 to 58 per cent in 1988. These are just figures, but they show the manner in which this Government's policies have succeeded in tapping the great pool of young people who in the past were not staying on at school and who were not able to go on to higher education.

I am somewhat puzzled as to why some people should be opposing, as they are in these stringent economic times, a scheme whereby our young Australians, our young students, are given every opportunity to undertake higher education, which was not free or accessible to them at all under the National-Liberal Government, and why they feel that it will harm not only young people but people of all ages to repay part of the cost to the taxpayer of their education after they have been placed in decently remunerated positions. Certainly, recalling the time when my parents struggled and saved to be able to keep their children at school-I will always appreciate the sacrifices made by them-I cannot see what is so inherently wrong with asking our young Australians to play their part by repaying a portion of their education costs after they have received their qualifications and, hopefully, more highly remunerated jobs-after the taxpayer has paid the $10,000 to $70,000 which is the cost of the degree courses offered in Australia.

I have come across many young people-I would say that this would be a majority feeling-people of strong character, who are very happy to be able to repay some of this cost, given the circumstances of the Government wishing to assist in the payment of Australia's international debt and reduce our domestic deficit, as we have done, rather than have that burden fall on their parents. I am proud of the fact that so many young people feel that way. Having received my schooling at a time when a Labor government was not in power and so many people, myself included, were not able to consider going on to tertiary education, I maintain my support for the provision and maintenance of quality education-a high standard of education-in Australia. I can maintain that belief and very easily link it to the higher education contribution scheme. The concept has been much abused in discussion.

The Government has shown its support for young people in education in a tangible manner. I point again to the Austudy rate. The difference between the Austudy rate and the unemployment benefit is a serious anomaly, considered by the Government to be a disincentive to continuing education. The difference is being addressed progressively. From 1989 Austudy and Abstudy rates for special disadvantaged groups have increased to the equivalent of the single rate unemployment benefit. The special groups include long-term pensioners and people who have been beneficiaries for six out of the last nine months. Aborigines and migrants undertaking special English courses have also benefited. The Government is committed to increasing gradually the level of the Austudy grant until it reaches the level of the unemployment benefit, applying to all students as Budget circumstances permit. This is very much welcomed by me and other members of the Government because we can recall the days when many parents could not afford to keep their children at high school. Austudy had not then been introduced. Those parents allowed their children to leave school to try for jobs that did not exist. That was at a time when employment, education and training programs such as those we are introducing did not exist, either. The unemployment benefit paid to such children enabled those families to meet day to day expenses. I most certainly support the goal to increase gradually the level of the Austudy grant to that of the unemployment benefit.

In the last Budget the Government lifted the parental income threshold from $16,000 to $16,950 and the personal income threshold from $2,000 to $3,000 so that more students could take advantage of maximum benefits. Since the introduction of these changes in the last Budget, there has been an increase of around 27 per cent in the number of recipients of Austudy and 24 per cent more applications were received in 1988 than in 1987. So we are getting there. Decentralisation of Austudy administration to Commonwealth Employment Service offices around the country will ensure greater access to information and assistance, particularly for those living in rural areas.

I mention a couple of other areas in which the Government has been particularly active. One is the special assistance for students program. Under the program, funds are provided to help educational institutions assist needy students who might face financial difficulties while studying. The institutions are responsible for the administration of funds which are distributed to students as low cost loans and grants. Assistance is available to students who demonstrate a genuine need, particularly those who require assistance for accommodation or for other circumstances which may place their continued study in jeopardy.

The joint and integrated programs covering employment, education and training are also starting to bear fruit. The Government has been very concerned about the incidence of teenage unemployment. My home State of Queensland has a particularly bad record in this respect. The proportion of the teenage population looking for full-time work has dropped from 12.2 per cent in 1983 to 6.6 per cent in December 1988. We welcome that drop, but we will not be satisfied until the figure goes right down and all teenagers wanting work are able to get jobs. Meanwhile, we are pleased to see the teenage unemployment rate going in the right direction. In March 1989 the unemployment rate for teenagers descended to its lowest level for more than 10 years. I say that with profound relief.

I am also pleased with what the Government has done for people with specific difficulties. I am referring now to the Aboriginal unemployment, education and training programs. Aboriginal participation in post-compulsory education reflects considerable inequity between Aboriginal people and other Australians. This just is not right in a free country, a democracy. Aboriginal participation in years 11 and 12, technical and further education (TAFE) and higher education is only about one-third of the corresponding participation rates for the community as a whole. However, there have been considerable improvements in recent years. The retention rate of Aboriginal students until year 12 has increased significantly, from about 11 per cent in 1982 to nearly 20 per cent in 1987. Similarly, Aboriginal enrolments in higher education increased from about 700 to 2,400 between 1983 and 1987.

The Aboriginal education policy task force found in 1988 that education participation and retention rates for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students were still proportionately well below those of their non-Aboriginal counterparts. The Government cannot accept these inequities. Of course they are just some of the general inequities suffered by the Aboriginal population over many years. The Government, when looking at employment, education and training policies, will make a special effort to target these injustices to see that they are rectified. Technical and further education is another area in which the Federal Government is supporting the States. The Federal Labor Government is providing more than $180m in direct grants to the States to expand the capacity of TAFE colleges so that they will be able to accept more people for training, particularly in areas of skill shortages, and to strengthen training in areas of new industrial developments.

I have tried to outline some of the areas in which the real concern of members of the Hawke Government has been translated into a tangible effort, by the Government's putting its money where its mouth is in its desire to bring into operation in Australia employment, education and training policies which will bring up to the optimum level the potential of our young Australians, who will be the leaders of the future. I entirely support the efforts of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan). I am very happy to take this opportunity to support publicly our integrated programs of social reform in the areas of employment, education and training.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) has ranged far and wide, canvassing a variety of issues; so, in coming back to the Student Assistance Amendment Bill, I note that it proposes a number of changes to the Student Assistance Act, which gives the statutory basis for Austudy and postgraduate awards. As noted in one part of our recently released and widely acclaimed higher education policy, Austudy has been bedevilled by administrative deficiencies and suffers from continuing allegations of unfairness in the award of benefits. It is a mess, a disgrace, bedevilled by inefficiencies, abuses and inequities. These proposed changes will effect some improvement, but they are by no means far-reaching enough.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to point to this contrast: here we have a Bill before us amending arrangements with respect to Austudy, streamlining it somewhat and, hopefully therefore, improving assistance to students, while on the other hand the Government has just introduced a punitive graduate tax, to which the honourable member for Lilley referred, which will do anything but assist students and particularly will discourage-is discouraging-postgraduate work, postgraduate students. I will come back to that.

More generally, I want to contrast the Government's approach to student assistance and a more effective development of higher education with the Opposition's approach in the recently released policy that I referred to. As I said, even with this Bill the Government has not addressed some of the major difficulties with Austudy and certainly not the difficulties with the funding of postgraduate students and research. We have a government that has little faith in educational institutions, in our leading academics or, for that matter, in our students. Reflecting that, we have a Government which thinks, in a typically socialist approach, that the only way we can run and reform higher education is to centralise control in a Canberra bureaucracy. Particularly in this higher education field it would force institutions to a significant extent to teach what it, the Government, wants them to teach through Commonwealth imposed educational profiles. It is a Government which attempts to amalgamate institutions under the threat and coercion of loss of funds, in the pursuit of some notion of efficiency. It has the effect, of course, that there are fewer of them to deal with, and to manipulate.

Further, the Government has thought it necessary to siphon off research funds and then allocate them via the Australian Research Council in accordance with some inevitably nebulous and rapidly changing Government perception of the national interest-potentially at the cost of excellence and of the flourishing of postgraduate research and, indeed, of the development, nurture, of the next generation of front rank scientists in this country. So it goes on.

I want to contrast that with our Liberal and National Party policy aimed at fostering a strong, dynamic and, in the interest of assisting students, expanding, forward-looking higher education system. Central to that policy is to open up the system and to allow it to react to market forces, with productive competition between institutions and corresponding greater excellence of achievement. We will implement-I am assuming that the election is already over and won-a system of student driven enrolments that gives choice for the student and competition between institutions. As I said, we are aiming at fostering a strong, dynamic, expanding, forward-looking higher education system to the greater benefit of and assistance to students-a system firmly founded on the principles of excellence in academic standards, opportunity on the basis of merit, healthy competition-I stress that again-and responsible autonomy for universities and colleges of advanced education.

In this context a student contribution or a student charge inevitably plays a role. The beginning argument for that is that students who benefit from higher education should be required to make some contribution towards the additional employability and earning power that they have as a result of their higher education. That is a reasonable argument. I believe that most people accept that. I stress that that much at least is common ground between the Government and the Opposition. But a student contribution is important from another standpoint. As the noted commentator Mr P. P. McGuinness once put it:
Pay peanuts, get monkeys.
Or, changing the metaphor and still quoting Mr McGuinness:

If you make education available for nothing, it will be fed to pigs. Moreover, if the producers are paid regardless of quality and know that their product is going to be cast before swine, they will produce a product which is fit for pigs.

In a sense that is putting it a bit strongly, but what is important, looking at the matter from this standpoint, is to ensure, firstly, that higher education is valued by those who receive it and, secondly, that the quality of higher education offered is worthwhile. I submit that that is why, in addition to the beginning argument that I referred to a moment ago, some form of student charge is important. It means that a school leaver or other prospective student looking to tertiary study will have cause to think closely and seriously about what the study is worth, be it in the form of future income or in terms of self-improvement. There is an incentive to study and work hard, complete the course and get an adequate return for the cost. Further, where the student knows that he or she will be paying some significant sum there will also be incentive to seek out an institution and within that institution a course of study and group of lecturers and professors which offer value for money. It is this that promotes the competition between institutions that in our view fosters performance and excellence on their part but, indeed, with responsible autonomy and the minimum of central control.

In this context the Government has come up with the infamous graduate tax, the higher education contribution scheme (HECS), whereas we in the coalition propose a system of awards, scholarships, charges and loans more favourable both to students and institutions and certainly more efficacious in the incentive and competition stimulating role that I have just described. The system we propose is of a student contribution or tuition charge of a much lesser order per annum than the $1,800 or up-front $1,530 of the Labor Party, a student contribution we propose to be paid at the time, of $600 per annum. Such a procedure certainly, I suggest, gives the right signals in the context to which I have been referring. The difficulty with the graduate tax from that standpoint is that while it also is put forward in part with the same objectives, the signals it gives will be muffled and distorted and a poor substitute indeed. In making that point, it is not the only objection to the graduate tax. An important one in my book is the totally obnoxious situation that the student under the graduate tax system becomes in a sense an object of pursuit, via the tax file number, for many years until that tax is paid.

There are certainly other objections, in particular that it provides a very significant disincentive to students particularly from low income families and otherwise disadvantaged backgrounds to enter higher education. A further objection is that that graduate tax burden will in most cases strike graduates when they face the burdens of home purchase and family support. A very important objection is that it will greatly inhibit post-graduate study and research, the scientific research which is so essential in the long run to the economic growth and prosperity of this country. What I have in mind there is the number of years it takes a higher education student to get through to the postgraduate and research level. The obligation that students build up over that period may be as much as $10,000 or $15,000. That will discourage students from going on to postgraduate work and engaging in the research which is so vital to the country and to the training of the next generation of front rank Australian scientists. That is a very important objection, and there are others.

Thus the graduate tax gives no incentive to the individual institutions providing tuition. The money goes to the Government and, therefore, the institution derives no discretionary spending money from it. Further, there is no direct link between the proceeds of the tax and higher education funding in total. Although nominally earmarked in a trust fund, the proceeds form only a small part of total higher education funding, subject to government decision. So on those grounds the so-called graduate tax is not appropriate. I say then that it is proper and appropriate that there be a student contribution, a student charge, and this is best done by way of our suggested procedure.

I contrast the whole Government approach with what the coalition will do, as the shadow Minister for education, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), set out in his speech. In addition to thoroughly recasting Austudy, the coalition, when in government, will restore responsible autonomy to all higher education institutions. We will dismantle the centralised bureaucracy of the so-called unified national system. We will abolish the system of Commonwealth-imposed educational profiles. We will withdraw the requirements for arbitrary amalgamation. As I have suggested, and this is central to our approach, we will stimulate healthy competition between institutions. We will modify the policy of concentrating research funding with the Australian Research Council and we will modify the policy guidelines of the Australian Research Council so as to ensure excellence and reduce bureaucratic interference. Through the 1989-1991 triennial system we will maintain the number of places provided for in the 1988 Budget, involving of the order of 400,000 places. Under our policy these `national education awards' will be made essentially on the basis of merit.

Very importantly in the context of student assistance, which is the issue before the House, we will provide the institutions with funds to allow the grant of `national education scholarships' to no fewer than 25 per cent of the holders of the awards. I would stress in that context that these free places, which will not attract the $600 charge, will be awarded by the institutions themselves on the basis of merit and need as they see fit. In other words, the 25 per cent will be allocated across the institutions and they will award them as they see fit. This is done basically to ensure that all the institutions will have an opportunity to participate in the process of scholarship awards. Otherwise the danger is that the top Higher School Certificate prospective medical and legal students who apply to enter universities in Sydney and Melbourne will tend to win them all. To repeat then, we will abolish the Labor Party's $1,800 a year indexed graduate tax and replace it with an annual student contribution or tuition charge of $600 to be paid by the non-scholarship student directly or through a loans scheme. I quote from page 4 of our policy:

The next Liberal/National Government will facilitate, by Government guarantee or other means, commercial loan arrangements with generous repayment periods for those students who wish to borrow the $600 in order that payment can be made to the institution. This will ensure that no prospective student is denied access to higher education through inability to meet their contribution towards tuition costs.

It is important to stress that. Further, we will permit institutions to offer additional places on any basis they see fit. In sharp contrast to what the Government is doing in terms of discouraging very low income and postgraduate students and centralising control of the higher education system through the unified national system, we would open out the whole system so that there would be broader choice for students, greater excellence in the system, and wider diversity and competition between institutions, leading to the development of the more effective, expanding, dynamic, forward looking higher education system this country needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate to make just a few comments and to point out that I usually follow the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) when we are considering economic matters. I must compliment him once again. Usually he gives a great amount of detail and specific information to the House and to the electorate about the matter before the House. In contrast, however, when the Student Assistance Amendment Bill was last before the House on 9 March, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) spent a great deal of time on irrelevant material and made a weak attempt at political point scoring. Perhaps it was because the honourable member for Deakin had very little of substance to say or was, in fact, unprepared.

SPEECH.PARA: I read the honourable member's speech in detail. He admitted that he had spoken for 12 minutes before he really got into it. On at least six occasions he was pulled up by the Deputy Speaker for being irrelevant to the Bill. One speaker in the debate described his contribution as `brave but revealing his inability to comprehend the complexities of higher education in our nation'. Another speaker said that it was `amusing but erroneous'. I point this out because the honourable member for Deakin is the Opposition spokesman on education and so his speech should be analysed and commented upon. People, students, expect far better than the honourable member for Deakin contributed that night. I suppose he could be excused as it was delivered at 8 o'clock, just after the resumption of the sitting after dinner, and that may have upset his continuity of thought. The amendment he placed before the House was not circulated before the dinner break and maybe he spent that time putting it together. However, on reading the amendment one saw that it suggested no alternative; it suggested nothing specific in its place. The honourable member laboured mightily to produce very little.

When the honourable member talked about the proposed amalgamations of higher education institutions-or, shall we say, further amalgamation, because these did take place under the Fraser Government-he took a very elitist view of tertiary education and dismissed amalgamations as `pedantic and churlish'. I suspect that this elitist view of higher education may come from his own experience, having gone only to universities-Sydney University and Harvard, a private university in the United States. I should put it on record that I have attended a college of advanced education-the Pharmacy College in Melbourne which, incidentally, is soon to be amalgamated with the Melbourne University-and I am a graduate of Melbourne and Monash universities. So I have had experience of both sides of the binary system. The binary system has come under a cloud because it has been overtaken by many developments.

Members of the Opposition, such as the honourable member for Deakin, still think of the colleges of advanced education-the CAEs-as advanced technical schools, forgetting or ignorant of the fact that time and development have led to their having nurse education, economics degrees, arts degrees, engineering, legal studies and so on. It still remains true, as it was in the early days for products of the early CAEs, that employers greatly prefer students who are graduates of CAEs. The CAE students should feel very proud of their achievements and not feel denigrated by deprecatory comments such as those made by the honourable member for Deakin.

Let me deal in a little more detail with the amalgamations themselves. To me, they can make a lot of sense. There should be some questioning as to whether particular amalgamations are proper. However, amalgamations signal the end of the strict binary system. They acknowledge that research is valuable in its pure or applied form. They recognise that some overlapping can be dispensed with. Furthermore, they will ease the transfer between those who have undertaken CAE courses to university courses and vice versa. We should have greater flexibility and interchanges between the different institutions. This will come about more readily through amalgamations, and it is in recognition of the greater equality in the standard of the many courses of the CAEs and universities. When we introduce legislation at State level or Territory level we should be clear that if we are to bring about amalgamation we should protect the unique features of both the CAEs and the universities which are worth protecting. I signal that in a debate later in this House that will become clear when we talk about amalgamations in the Australian Capital Territory.

The honourable member for Deakin pointed out that I was spending a bit more time in the House than he had noticed before. He called it `a concertina of experience'. I would inform the honourable member that I have always been most interested in higher education and in education generally, having been the secretary of a higher education union for five years. However, I point out that since redistribution in Victoria, the honourable member's electorate of Deakin has become a notional Labor seat. Therefore, the squeeze is now on the honourable member for Deakin. One has noticed the troubled music produced by this squeeze box.

The honourable member also talked about abolishing the assets test for isolated students. He said, `We will establish a realistic assets test, including a hardship test'. The electorate becomes very confused because, although Opposition members say that they oppose the assets test which this Government has brought in and they would bring in another, they give not details. There has been not a refutation of what the Government has done, but only wordy rhetoric-just words, but no details. I point out to the electorate and to the House that if there are to be pretenders to government and pretenders to the position of Minister of Education, they should give information, details and a clearly enunciated policy to allow people to make their own judgments.

As the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) pointed out, isolated students, students in the country, will not suffer because of the assets test. It will mean that more funds will be made available to go to those who need financial assistance to leave the country and to come to universities and CAEs, or to the amalgamated bodies which are largely based in the cities but which are increasingly in provincial towns and cities throughout Australia. Through the distance education courses which are being developed through cooperation such as that which has taken place between Monash University and the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education, under the vibrant leadership of the Vice-Chancellor of Monash, Mal Logan, far more educational opportunities will be given to students in the country who cannot attend the institutes of learning.

The honourable member for Deakin attacked Austudy yet failed to point out that under the Liberal Government only 116,000 students were assisted in this way, whereas last year under the present Government 285,000 students were so assisted. Opposition members are never specific on details, or on matters of real political significance. They are always saying that they will produce policies on important matters such as taxation, but as month after month rolls by, we hear nothing from the Opposition. Education is no exception. In this specific case the amendment moved by the honourable member is a mishmash of generalities; it is so vague as to be utterly meaningless. In regard to Austudy the honourable member for Deakin said, `The Liberal and National parties will in government thoroughly review the rules and administration of Austudy to ensure that they are fair to all and that the scheme runs smoothly', but again the Opposition gives no details. This Government is in government because it is prepared to make the system run smoothly and to make it fairer, and it has brought in this legislation to ensure that that happens.

The Government has backed up the system with money. It has tripled the amount of income support for students. Under the Liberal Government in 1982 Austudy was funded at around $188m, and Labor has increased that figure to $840m. Why should the Government increase that amount? It has done so not only to make higher education more accessible, but because more and more secondary students are qualifying for higher education and need to be assisted. In 1983 just over one in three students completed year 12 or secondary school, but now almost 60 per cent finish year 12 successfully and would be able to take up the opportunities of higher education. So Austudy not only has to be more extensive; it is of a higher quality and is better targeted than ever before. I would point to the fact that 42 per cent of tertiary students now get Austudy and 40 per cent of secondary students aged 16 and over also benefit in this way.

The contribution to the debate by the honourable member for Berowra related to the introduction of the higher education contribution scheme, under which students will be required to repay $1,800 a year should they complete a full time year based on their future income and an indexed arrangement will apply. The Opposition would introduce, so it says, a $600 fee. Students would pay this whether or not they could afford to do so. Let us contrast the two systems, and as I have only a minute or so left of my speaking time I shall attempt to put the matter in a nutshell. The Liberals' charge would be on anyone and there is no guarantee of a limit. It is an open-ended policy which could quickly inflate well over the $600 figure, and could well exceed the Government's proposed $1,800. On the other hand, the Government will ask only for those fees or for that charge to be repaid should a student's income rise above $22,000. This does not penalise those who study for self-fulfilment rather than income. It does not penalise pensioners who wish to study, and it does not put off those marginal students who are weighing up whether a decision should be made involving immediate income versus a study outlay. Any student who undertakes higher education under a Liberal coalition, if one can call it that, would pay a minimum of $600 and that could blow out. If Opposition members believe that there has been some outrage over the higher education contribution scheme, then that will pale in comparison with the tumultuous uproar that would ensue over the open-ended Liberal fees to be charged. I reject the amendment and support the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted a couple of matters that I thought were appropriate for me to respond to.
