DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (URANIUM CONCENTRATE EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 March, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before the House amends the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Act 1980 and has other related purposes. The Bill, by way of clause 3, increases the duty on exported uranium concentrate mined in the Alligator Rivers region from $1.02 a kilogram to $1.15 a kilogram. The principal Act was last amended in the 1987 Budget, when the duty was lifted from 80c to $1.02 per kilogram. Between 1980 and 1987, the duty was 11c per kilogram. Allow me to restate those figures because I will be referring to them again during the course of my address. Between 1980 and 1987 the Federal Government imposed a duty of 11c per kilogram on exported uranium concentrate mined in the Alligator Rivers region in the Northern Territory-better known as the Ranger mine. Then in the 1987 Budget the duty was lifted from 80c to $1.02 a kilogram. Now the Government intends to lift it yet again, to $1.15 a kilogram.
—About time.

—`About time' interjects the honourable member for Dunkley. That sort of trite, superficial interjection shows up the ideological bent of this Government. It is going to tax out of existence one of our most important export oriented industries. I will come quickly to the point that I wish to make. This duty now forms about 5 per cent of the operating costs of Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA), the operators of the Ranger mine. This duty meets the bulk of the costs borne by the Commonwealth Government for its environmental monitoring and research activities related to uranium mining in the Alligator Rivers region. These research activities are carried out by the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers region, better known as OSS.

SPEECH.PARA: The financial impact of the proposed duty is that it is expected to raise an additional $800,000 during the 1988-89 financial year. The anticipated recovery for the financial year 1988-89 is $4.5m. The duty is indicative of the Government's strategy of discriminating against productive industries which are struggling to maintain a competitive edge in the world market. How many times does this Government introduce legislation in this House which discriminates against our export oriented industries, whether they be in primary industry or mineral extraction? The fact is that in corrupt world markets our exporters cannot compete because they have one hand tied behind their backs. They are being crushed by heavy government costs and charges. Not only is the duty a heavy disincentive to our uranium export market but also it is discriminatory in that its application falls disproportionately upon one company alone. It is a duty or a levy upon ERA alone. It is even more absurd when it is considered that the levy is imposed on an industry which would undoubtedly contribute to this country's economic well-being.

The levy on uranium oxide is a further example of the Government's damaging and confusing policy approach to uranium as a whole. It is a policy which is founded on the ideological rifts and intraparty fighting within the Australian Labor Party (ALP). It is a policy which makes no good economic sense and one which expresses interests of the Labor Party ahead of and above those of the nation as a whole. Strictly speaking, the purpose of the Bill is to increase the duty on exported uranium concentrate, but the truth is it is a tax raising revenue which may well satisfy some sections of the Government's secret agenda-which is to wipe out the uranium export industry. If the Government cannot do that because of political realities, then it will make sure that the industry slowly bleeds to death. Honourable members should bear in mind that when the previous coalition Government imposed the levy in 1980, as part of the principal Act which is being amended, the duty stood at 11c a kilogram. Now, it is a whopping $1.15 a kilogram. The justification for this price hike, according to the Government's rhetoric in the second reading speech, is to offset the costs of the Commonwealth-funded environmental monitoring and reporting procedures which operate in the Alligator Rivers region of the Northern Territory.

Though, in the past, the Government has claimed that the levy is designed to fund increasingly greater proportions of the operating research costs of the OSS, the pattern of government charges is clear enough. The objective of this levy is to add to Consolidated Revenue. It is an instrument of the Australian Taxation Office used in an arbitrary manner. By and large the levy falls upon the shoulders of one company alone-Energy Resources of Australia, operators of the Ranger mine. It is therefore discriminatory. As the Nabarlek mine owned by Queensland Mines Ltd, also based in the Alligator Rivers region, ceased production as of last year and is now only fulfilling its contracts and dispersing its store of uranium oxide, the present and future burden of the tax falls upon the Ranger mine alone. The tax is clearly punitive upon Ranger.

Between 1980 and 1986, when the levy amounted to 11c per kilogram of uranium export, Ranger paid on average $270,000 during these years, while Nabarlek, the lesser of the two producers in the region, averaged a payment of $93,000 for the same period. So the levy imposed by a coalition government remained at 11c between 1980 and 1986. It is important to remember the drastic price hike that has occurred since 1986. The Government now intends imposing a $1.15 levy on every kilogram. Across 1986-87, when the levy jumped from 11c to 80c per kilogram, Ranger paid $2.237m while Nabarlek was required to hand over to the Government some $1.2m. With the levy at $1.02 since 1987-it jumped from 80c to $1.02 within 12 months-Ranger was taxed $3.7m and Nabarlek $1.2m. The latest increase in the levy to $1.15 will bring the Government over $4 1/2m from Ranger and this is set to rise again in July this year.

Budget Paper No. 1 tells us that the levy will be increased yet again to $1.30 per kilogram which will require Ranger to hand over more than $10m between July this year and June 1991. By contrast, as Nabarlek's stockpile of uranium oxide is depleted by 1990, it will pay only $2.9m-and all of this on the spurious claim that the funding of the OSS at its present exorbitant levels is vital and necessary to the environmental protection of the Alligator Rivers region. Utter bunkum! Anybody who has been up to that area would know that about 50 members of the OSS are standing around with nothing to do. The biggest event for some of them is to go out to the Alligator Rivers, collect some water and test it. It is an absurdity to be maintaining people with such excellent qualifications in such a useless task. The truth of the matter is that the taxation and charges regime under which the uranium industry attempts to operate in the international market is already a sufficient disincentive to international competitiveness by itself without the extra burden of this levy.

Let us look at the tax regime affecting Ranger in 1988. Provision for current income tax was $60.4m-49 per cent on an operating profit of $123m. Twelve million dollars went to Aboriginal interests; $5.3m for rehabilitation fund trust payments; and $3.5m for royalties. All up, Ranger paid roughly $86m in taxes and charges in the last financial year. The levy is even more unreasonable given that Ranger, in effect, is directly subsidising research in the Alligator Rivers region. Ranger has developed its own research laboratories in parallel with those of the OSS. Ranger attempts to carry out that research upon which practical sets of standards might be based. This is the down-to-earth research which can give rise to guidelines which can be applied to the industry in the environmentally sensitive wetland area of the Alligator Rivers region of Kakadu Park. It is also the research that the OSS has failed to come up with.

The extended studies into baseline research by the OSS has its merits but those merits do not extend to practical applications for the industry. Ranger's own environmental department consists of 40 professional, technical and support personnel working within high quality laboratories. For this reason it would be a better idea by far and in the context of the coalition's science policy-the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) who is present for this debate, having been a shadow Minister for science, knows better than anybody else that it is a far better idea-if the more esoteric research functions of the OSS were to be transferred to the Northern Territory college; and Ranger, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation and the Northern Territory Government were left with the prime, although not the sole, responsibility for the oversight of the region.

It is duplication and, at its worst, at a bureaucratic level which can only harm an industry, to maintain the OSS in its present form. The duplication of research which is currently a concern to all parties would also be finally overcome if such a reallocation of research efforts were to be implemented. This is despite the recent disparaging and ill-founded remarks by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) regarding the harmless overspill from the Ranger waste site.

In 1987-88 the research cost to the OSS was $4.7m-75 per cent of its $6m budget. In addition to funding the research not effectively carried out by the OSS, Ranger also subsidises the operations of the OSS as they are applied to the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd gold mine at Coronation Hill. Coronation Hill is not subject to a levy, even though the waste of any sort of mining in a fragile environment can be detrimental to tourism and the environment. Of course, the ecosystem can so easily be affected from the waste from any mining operation. The discriminatory nature of the levy is made clearer in a broader context. The Roxby Downs Olympic Dam mine, although in a dry yet fragile environment, is not subject to any duty on its exports, nor is it intended to impose a duty on the Kintyre mine should the Government have the good sense to allow it to develop. Kintyre, owned by Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd (CRA), is located in the Rudall River National Park on the fringe of Western Australia's Great Sandy Desert. Generally, the reason for these inconsistencies is that the duty is a political decision designed solely to relieve the guilt-ridden consciences of the Left of the ALP. Like the three-mine policy it lacks good economic sense.

I feel very strongly that the levy is inappropriately high and that the role and functions of the OSS have to be called into question, looked at and restructured. Moreover, I believe that the inconsistencies lead to a discriminatory burden being placed upon ERA. I hasten to add that neither I nor any member of the coalition parties would argue for extending the levy to some of the uranium or other mining ventures.

Let us look at the three-mine policy. The market for uranium is set to expand in the 1990s. Australia has the largest reserves of low to medium cost recoverable uranium reserves in the world. It also has mines, such as Jabiluka, which are yet to be permitted to come on stream which have been described by internationally recognised authorities as not just world class mines but mines which are the best in the world. A number of studies show that, although prices for uranium on the international market are depressed for the moment, they are set to peak in the late 1990s. There is then the necessity to move quickly to take advantage of international demand which is now upon us and which is referred to by the Chairman of CRA, Mr John Uhrig, in a recent speech as follows:

We believe the international uranium market is about to undergo a critical transition which presents Australia with a rare opportunity. The current policy of allowing some mines, while disallowing others will cause us to miss that opportunity.

We have missed opportunities in the past. Slowness in capitalising on our natural uranium advantage in the 1970s and 1980s enabled the Canadian uranium mines to develop their operational effectiveness and become a dominant supplier of uranium in the world today. In effect, we have subsidised Canadian living standards at the expense of our own.

Let the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) tell that to the people of Australia. Let his Government explain to them why other countries in the world are growing rich at our expense. Would anybody deny that the Australian standard of living has plummeted in recent years? Let the Minister tell the Australian people why, with only 10 per cent of the world's reserves, Canada has been able to supply 30 per cent of the world's demand. Let him also tell them how it is that Australia possesses 30 per cent of the world's reserves, but the three-mine policy has restricted us to meeting only 10 per cent of the world demand.

We know we are being given another opportunity in the 1990s. The critical time in which to move is now. In 1992-93 the Japanese contracts with the major Ontario buyers will expire. This will mean that if Australian producers are to enter into contract negotiations they must be able to present their tenders as soon as possible. Deliveries will have to start in 1995. The Canadian producers are set to reap the profits once again because of the political paralysis of the ALP. There is demand in the world for uranium. The Energy 2000 report indicates this. The industry is telling us this and is hankering to be let of the leash. It is only the Government which refuses to listen for fear of unleashing the contending forces within its own ranks. It is scared to move for fear of splitting the Party right down the middle; it is prepared to sacrifice the national interest.

Though world prices are currently low, future exports will be written with regard to the then prevailing spot price. In fact, most long-term contracts now being completed are set at between $US20 and $US30 per pound. Even though the current spot price is low, hovering between $US10 and $US11, only about 10 per cent of all contracts are negotiated on this basis. The vast majority of contracts are written on a long-term basis-I stress that-which varies markedly from the more volatile spot price. The only impediment to pricing mechanisms is the Government's retention of a floor price, a protection measure implemented in an earlier period by the coalition to enable the then fledgling Ranger project to raise loans in order to commence production. The floor price has served its useful life and now only puts us at a commercial disadvantage to the Canadians, who are operating within a much freer, less regulated pricing system.

In the past the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has justified the Government's position on the basis of market limitations on uranium demand. If this is so, then let us deregulate the market, expose it to the international market, and let us see whether only three mines survive. Nobody has to help Pancontinental Mining Ltd, itching to get into the marketplace; nor does anybody have to have regard to CRA. Let them get in. Let them spend their money. Let them be accountable to their shareholders. But let us not cut them out by the Government's economically nonsensical policy. It must be remembered that the international market operates in quite lengthy time frames. New long-term contracts are entered into many years before the actual period of utilisation. The rate at which the utilities consume is no indicator of what the level of demand might be at any point. Demand is also influenced by political and strategic factors on the part of foreign governments. The West German initiative in buying large stocks of uranium from the Russians, not for its own needs but to exploit market conditions with United States buyers, is a dangerous omen.

Notwithstanding these market characteristics, which the Government overlooks or wishes would go away, Pancontinental has gone to extremes in order to accommodate the Government. It has offered to reshape the Jabiluka project and reduce its capacity of 3,000 tonnes of export per annum to 1,500 tonnes per annum in order not to create imbalances in what some perceive to be a tight international market at this time. All of this is to enable it to lock into the opportunities of the next decade. They are looking ahead. Under the present policy of restricted production we can produce only up to 7,500 to 8,000 tonnes of uranium by the year 2000. According to the latest Red Book and industry figures, uranium demand will reach between 53,000 and 61,000 tonnes in the year 2000. Some industry statistics even suggest that the cumulative gap between production and demand could be as great as 100,000 tonnes between 1989 and 1996.

Global demand for nuclear-powered electricity generation continues to grow. By the year 2000 nuclear power plants will generate 20 per cent of the world's electricity needs. If unleashed, the Australian industry could produce up to 20,000 tonnes at the critical moment, but if it is to seize the opportunity presented by increased demand and higher prices in the 1990s, industry must be given the go ahead now to enter into long-term contracts with the international marketplace. Nuexco, in its recent publication Prospects for Australian Uranium, indicated that by the late 1990s there will have been an increase of 50 per cent over the current long-term prices.

One of the first blows to the industry's international credibility was the coming to power of the Hawke Labor Government. In March 1983 it stripped such mines as Pancontinental's Jabiluka of its letters of determination, hence stopping it from entering into any negotiations with potential buyers. This was at a time when Jabiluka had already signed up 50 per cent of its annual production for sale. If the industry is going to capitalise on the window of opportunity opening up in the 1990s it must have its letters of determination renewed. If the Government were to unshackle the industry, by the year 2000 we would see up to 20,000 tonnes of uranium exported. This would amount to direct mining sales of $1.6 billion per year. If we were to move into the front end of the fuel cycle, we could earn between $3.7 and $7.6 billion per year for conversion and enrichment, storage and transport, disposal and treatment.

Moreover, the world demand for uranium, which in the words of the chairman of Pancontinental, Mr Tony Grey, is `marching ahead at a vigorous pace', is seeking out Australia as a supplier. South African and Namibian suppliers are being shunned for political reasons and the market is suspicious of the cartel-like overtones of the present sources of supply. The majority of world supply is tied up by three companies. There is demand for diversification of sources of supply. The failure to bring on stream such deposits as Koongarra and Jabiluka in the Northern Territory alone has already cost us $1.1 billion in lost rent. However, imagine the multiplier effect if we brought on stream such deposits as Jabiluka and Koongarra in the Northern Territory; Yeelirrie, Kintyre and Lake Way in Western Australia; Ben Lomond in Queensland, and Beverley and Honeymoon in South Australia. This would create roughly 5,000 direct and permanent jobs.

The fact is that the Government has abdicated its responsibilities in this area. At its last national conference in June 1988 in Hobart, it formed a uranium review committee. Even though this committee was officially formed last December, there was a six-month delay until it got the factional balance right. Now we are told that it will not report to the Labor Party until December of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the election.

—After the election, and let us not underestimate that fact. The report from this uranium review committee will take place after the next election. Again, the political cowardice of the Government is revealed for all to see.

SPEECH.PARA: What has been the effect of Australia keeping the uranium in the ground? It has had no effect at all on reducing sales. It has been a total failure. It is the biggest joke of all time overseas. The self-indulgence of it all, the complacency of Australia, is laughed at everywhere in the world, not least of all in France. The banning of uranium exports to France has not meant a pinch of salt to the French. All it has done has been to make the French more determined to test in our backyard.

The situation would be laughable if it were not so serious. I have set out the figures showing the importance to Australia of a sensible, rational, economically based uranium export policy. We should bear in mind that if we lose contracts today, as we are doing, we lose them for many years because our competitors are able to develop as a result. By not being in the market we are allowing our competitors to establish new mining operations which could last for 20 years. We are harming Australia for 20 years by giving our competitors a head start. We have done it in the past and South Africa and Canada have profited as a result.

It is of tremendous concern to the Opposition and to the Australian people at large that the Hawke Labor Government would so stupidly sell our interests down the drain. For this reason, I move the following second reading amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Government should be condemned for-

(1) imposing a discriminatory levy upon one operation alone at a time when Australia's uranium exporters are struggling to remain competitive in the international market and are already overburdened by excessive taxes and charges; and
(2) its ideological approach to the development of Australia's uranium industry which has resulted in an economically absurd `three mine policy'.

The amendment incorporates the two bases of the coalition's opposition to the Government's handling of the uranium policy. We will not be opposing this legislation, for it falls within a Budget measure, but we have made known loud and clear our opposition to every aspect of the Government's handling of uranium, not only because Australia's national interests are being sold down the drain, but also because the two mines that are still operating-bear in mind that Nabarlek has more or less ceased to operate as it once did-are being tied down severely by unnecessary costs and charges. In this instance it is poor old Ranger that suffers. It suffers because the Office of the Supervising Scientist has gathered unto itself a vast and unnecessary bureaucracy which duplicates much of the research and development undertaken by Ranger and monitored by the Northern Territory Government and a plethora of other government agencies. Does the Government really think that if it did away with the OSS, Ranger could get away with anything?-not that it would want to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—The Minister says yes. Let us put it on the record that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business has said yes. He can deal with ERA on that basis. We trust the Northern Territory Government properly to supervise the operations of mining companies within its boundaries. This Government has abdicated all responsibility for uranium mining. It does not care one iota about the effect on the standard of living. I commend our amendment and make clear to the Government our continued opposition to its absurd three-mine policy.
—Order! Is the amendment seconded?

—Yes, the amendment is seconded. I have a great deal of pleasure in seconding the amendment. It is an exceptionally good amendment. I commend it to the House and I hope that it will be considered by the Government in considerable detail. I reserve my right to speak.
—Order! The amendment is seconded. The honourable member will resume his seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only five minutes before dinner for my 20-minute speech. I would like to spend that five minutes having a go at the Opposition spokesman for science and energy, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). We have witnessed a theatrical, angry performance by him. He had his angry voice on this evening. He was firing away there, thumping the box, et cetera. It was typical of the honourable member for Gippsland. He will go outside and he will probably forget what he has said.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member said that the staff of the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS) stationed at Jabiru stand around all day, and then go out and collect water from the river and test it. I would have thought that was a pretty important part of their job. Those people should be commended for the work they do. They have to put up with living in a harsh climate, as do the workers at the mine and the people of Jabiru. Those scientists should be commended for the work they are doing in protecting and looking after our environment. Their work has been circumvented and dodged around. They cannot do a proper job because of the attitudes of Ranger, the Opposition, and the Northern Territory Government in particular.

The honourable member for Gippsland has just put offside hundreds of scientists who work for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and the Office of the Supervising Scientist who spend a long time in the field under harsh conditions making certain that their skills are practised and that what they do is put on paper and fed back to the Government or the nation. Through their work they improve and look after the environment. However, the honourable member for Gippsland disregards that. He seems to think that all scientists, no matter who they work for-OSS, CSIRO or even private industry-drink cups of tea and talk all day, and now and again wander off to a river somewhere or to their laboratories, put on their coats, do a bit of work, collect their money and go home. That is not correct.

The OSS was set up as a monitoring organisation, to make certain that the Ranger and Nabarlek mines did not impinge on or affect the environment in any way. It has done a fairly good job. I have criticised it. In about May last year I flew over Ranger and noted that the tailings dam was exposed; it was not covered in water. One of the original conditions was that it be covered. When I rang the OSS an officer said `Yes. It is a new idea we will have wet tailings. It will be okay'. When I pointed out the fact that birds often land in those radioactive tailings and then wander off to their nests and that the radioactivity can build up, the OSS said that it had not done any studies on that. I pointed out that the wind could dry out the slurry in the tailings dam which could then blow all over the park. The OSS answered that it was looking at that and that it was quite okay.

I also pointed out that I had been up there some years ago and had seen a trial plot through which were tracks of some sort of animal. Possibly a dingo had walked through the tailings. I have not found out the latest information but the practice of not putting any more water over the top of the tailings probably still exists. I do not believe that this is the right way to go about things.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your point?

—My point is that those tailings can get all over the park. Ranger has an input into what the OSS researches. Under some circumstances it could direct the OSS away from particular areas of research which may not be to Ranger's liking. I point out that Ranger does not own the OSS. It may pay for some of its operations but it does not own it, so it should not have any say in what areas the OSS does its research. The OSS should be free to do whatever research it wants. This is particularly important in relation to looking after the environment and making certain that these areas are not abused by a company which is well known for abusing and not practising proper engineering principles. I have talked about Ranger before in this place. I have pointed out the broken pipes, and the other things that it does wrong. We are talking about what is supposed to be a responsible firm.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dinner I was discussing the lack of ability of Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA), as shown by some of the things it has done in the past. The honourable member for Gippsland said that the company was very responsible and could look after its own research and development and its own checking in relation to uranium mining. One would have expected that the company, after working for many years in the Kakadu National Park, would be very environmentally conscious. However, late last year 500,000 tonnes of mineralised material containing uranium ore above the prescribed limit was wrongly placed in a rock waste dump outside the mine's restricted release zone. The Northern Territory Government described the incident as trivial. One would have to question the company's reputation as a responsible organisation after it made the mistake of putting in the wrong place 500,000 tonnes of rocks.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Gippsland said it was a shame that the company had to pay this tax for the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region and that it would affect Ranger's profit and decrease its sales overseas. He and many on the other side fail to mention the profits that ERA has made. In 1984, it made $57m; in 1985, $56m; in 1986, $50m; in 1987, $58m; and in 1988, $63m. That is not a bad sort of bonus from which to pay $4m for an organisation to supervise the company's spewing out of mine water. The people of Australia are entitled to receive such an amount from companies that take our mineral resources from the ground and make profits on them year after year. It is also interesting to note that last year a French nuclear fuel company, Cogema, bought into ERA.

The annual report of Energy Resources of Australia shows how safety conscious the company is. It received an above average grading for a five-star health and safety management system, awarded by an organisation called the National Safety Council of Australia. It is interesting that ERA should get an award from an organisation which just recently has got some adverse publicity. I just wonder how much the award cost the company.

It has been well documented in papers all over Australia that the Ranger mine has released water on quite a few occasions. I think it is still releasing water at present. According to Mr Coulter, the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy, the water from retention ponds at the Ranger mine is that good he would drink it. Another member of this House actually drank 2,4,5-T. I do not know how he is feeling these days; he does not come in here too often. I think he is a bit crook. If Mr Coulter reckons the water is so good, he is welcome to drink it. Senator Richardson has already spoken out loudly against this discharge of water. Ranger, with the cooperation and collusion of the Northern Territory Government, instead of releasing the water through a pipe into Magela Creek just releases it over the spillway. I am no scientist; I am only a practical turner and fitter. However, I imagine that the effect of releasing the water over the spillway into the creek instead of through a pipe would enable the company, if any adverse contaminants were found, to say that they came from the creek rather than from the mine. The company is treating the Australian population as fools. That is why I am glad that we are increasing the levy on the company to pay for the Office of the Supervising Scientist. We should increase it even more.

In 1988 the company set aside $5,288,000 for rehabilitation of the mine, and in 1987 it set aside $5,724,000. If the cost of rehabilitating the area is anything like the cost of rehabilitating the Rum Jungle area, for which taxpayers paid, it will be horrendous. We are not looking at a small hole in the ground or a small tailings dump. The area is huge and it will be radioactive and bad for the environment for years to come. We should up the amount of money the company puts aside for rehabilitation to make certain that we have in that trust fund an amount large enough to cover all the costs that will go into rehabilitating the area.

Preliminary OSS tests of the water being discharged from the Ranger mine into the Kakadu National Park indicate that there have been some toxic effects. Senator Richardson said on 4 March that he expected more definitive advice within the next few weeks. I have not seen such advice, but his office may have received it. Perhaps in the next day or so we will get a few more answers in relation to the problem with the water that is being released. One of the methods Ranger is using to get rid of excess water is spray irrigation. The company has published a document called Ranger and the Environment: An Update, in which it is stated:

In a further effort to minimize the volume of water held in RP2 before the wet season commences a method of spray irrigation was introduced a few years ago using water from this pond. A trial to investigate the environmental impact was carried out in 1985 and subsequently approval was given by the Supervising Authorities to extend the 1.8 hectare trial area to 35 hectares. Spray irrigation is now an integral part of the water management system. At present this is the only approved method of reducing the amount of excess water within the system and may only be carried out during the dry season.

In a Supervising Scientist paper called Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute Annual Research Summary for 1987-88 there is a section entitled `Land application of Retention Pond water'. It states:
Ranger has been disposing of water from Retention Pond No. 2-
it was also mentioned in the ERA document-

by spray irrigating a 33ha site between the mine and Magela Creek. The adoption of spray irrigation as a method of disposal of excess water is based on the proposition that the soil will retain the solutes in the applied water . . .
It goes on then with a fairly scientific explanation of the various minerals involved. Later the report states:
Field measurements of hydraulic conductivity indicated that the soils are highly permeable and that lateral flow of . . . Magela Creek could take as little as 9 months-
that is, the water being sprayed on this 33 hectares takes nine months to filter through the ground, instead of going straight in through the pipe or over the spillway-

(in the case of the minimum distance of 100 m from the irrigation area to Magela Creek-assuming a depth of the permeable aquifer of 80 m, a saturated volumetric water content of 0.25, the rate of arrival of water at the water table of 7.4 mm day-1, and water moving without any preferential pathways).

As I said, it takes just nine months for water to move from the irrigation area through the soil to Magela Creek. Another paper has been produced by the Supervising Scientist. It is called `Distribution and Genesis of Acid Sulphate Soils in the Magela Backwater Plains'. This deals with another area, but it is still in the same locality. If the ground in this area is opened up for mining, which is possible-I think Jabiluka is trying to open up this new mine-it will create cracks in the soil and clay alluvium in the dry season. The water on that will allow some strongly acidic compounds to run into the actual flood plain. If Jabiluka went ahead and opened up this new mine, and if there is a wet season, highly acidic water would be running into the flood plains further down the road. Who knows what it will do.

At present several compounds are actually going into the Magela Creek such as magnesium, sodium, calcium, manganese and sulphate. They are average sorts of chemicals and they do not cause too much harm, but they do alter the consistency of the water in the Magela Creek. These things must be looked at, but not by me. All I am trying to do is point the direction the scientific people should take in order to alleviate the problem. The uranium that goes into the soil from the spray irrigated area is taken up by the trees and bushes, et cetera. The radioactivity is also taken up by them. It is burned off every year. I do not know whether this is correct or whether it has been proven, but once this radioactivity gets into the trees and plants and if they are burned off, does it get into the smoke and is that transported all over the Kakadu National Park? I do not know. These are the matters that the scientists, especially the Office of the Supervising Scientist, should be looking at very closely.

The other area that concerns me in this whole uranium debate is the waste problem. About a year ago I was in the United Kingdom. I went to Wylfa, an atomic power station over there. Because I had never seen one and since I complain enough about it, I thought that I had better go and have a look at one of these stations. It is one of the oldest atomic power stations in North Wales and they want to close it down, but they do not know how to go about it. There are huge problems over there in that they do not know whether to dig the waste up, shift it or bury the whole lot under a pile of concrete. An organisation in the United Kingdom called Nirex is looking for places to dispose of nuclear waste. Naturally no-one wants it in his backyard and Nirex has a great problem trying to decide what it will do with this waste.

The whole uranium cycle has to be looked at closely. The people who dig it out of the ground must make certain that environmental controls are put in place by the Office of the Supervising Scientist, that the scientists are given enough money to carry out their job and that they are not under any threat of fear or favour from the Ranger uranium mine, or whoever pays that levy into the Government account, to actually pay the scientists. This matter has definitely got to be put aside so that the Supervising Scientist can have a say as to what direction the research takes and how the scientists are directed in relation to the projects they carry out. Ranger uranium mine should not have any say in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It goes without saying that I do not support the amendment which is proposed by the Opposition, but I do very strongly support the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989, which increases the export duty on uranium concentrate produced in the Alligator Rivers region of the Northern Territory from $1.02 per kilogram to $1.15 per kilogram.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) has pointed out that the increased rate recognises the view of the Government and indeed my own strong view that the costs associated with protecting the environment from the adverse effects of uranium mining should be borne by the industry carrying on that mining activity and not by the Australian taxpayer. In my view the House could not be considering at a more appropriate time the need for the monitoring of the effects of uranium mining on the environment of Kakadu National Park. Let me also make it very clear that I am not talking about an activity with which I am unfamiliar. I have visited Kakadu National Park on a number of occasions in the past 8 1/2 years since I have been the member for La Trobe. Members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, of which I am Chairman-the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), who made a very good speech before me, is also a member-deal with the protection of the environment. We have all visited the Ranger uranium mine operated by Energy Resources of Australia on at least one occasion in an official capacity and on numerous unofficial occasions. I have also visited the proposed Pancontinental Mining Ltd site of the Jabiluka mine which is situated adjacent to the wetlands of the Alligator Rivers region. Of course, the honourable member for Dunkley referred to that too.

The reason I say that this is a most appropriate time to consider the Bill is that the Ranger uranium mine, which is surrounded by Kakadu National Park, has recently released toxic water into a billabong in complete disregard of appropriate environment safeguards. I will quote from the Age newspaper of 4 March which indicates the seriousness of the situation. The quote is as follows:

Senator Richardson said the Office of the Supervising Scientist at Jabiru and the traditional owners of the site had not been informed of the release of water from retention pond four over a spillway into Djalkmara billabong until a few hours beforehand.
``Preliminary laboratory biological tests by the OSS indicate that there have been some toxic effects. I expect more definitive advice from them within the next week or so,'' he said.
``The release of this water . . . was authorised by the relevant Northern Territory authorities, but advice from the Office of the Supervising Scientist on the best method of release was ignored.''

He said the office had advised the mine operators that releasing water over the spillway was not acceptable because it allowed less control of the pollution and made it difficult to test the resulting toxicity levels.
``It is disturbing, it is strange, and remains unexplained why both the company and the Northern Territory authorities have suddenly decided to depart from this established procedure,'' he said.
``I am also concerned that the company is planning further releases from retention pond four via the spillway.
``The supervising scientists have advised me that if this process continues, the high standards of environmental protection in the Alligator Rivers region are threatened.

``The Commonwealth will take whatever action is necessary to prevent that heritage from being threatened. The wetlands of Kakadu will not be allowed to become a drain to be used at the convenience of either the company or the Northern Territory Government.''

I have quoted in full from the newspaper article because I view this matter with the utmost seriousness. In October 1986 as Chairman of the then House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, I tabled a report in the House on the Ranger uranium water management system. I will quote from the report. It states:

The Northern Land Council and the Northern Territory Environment Centre in discussions with the Committee were critical of the number of tailings line failures. The NLC expressed concern about `gross carelessness in areas where the Company should be most careful'. Both the NLC and the Environment Centre considered that the frequent spillages were in part due to Company attitudes and the lack of supervision and penalties. The Environment Centre argued that mine management has a poor attitude to environment protection and continually seeks least cost solutions and that after two or three spillages Ranger should have been required to close its operations and replace the pipeline. According to the Environment Centre the argument used by mine management that spillages of this nature happen in all mines is an argument for closure of the mine because of its location in a world heritage area.
I will give another quote here too which is very relevant. It states:

Ranger considered all the accidental releases to be minor and had caused no environmental damage. The Company advised that it had been quick to respond and none of the releases had reached Kakadu National Park and only a few had escaped from the restricted release zone. The company stated that spillages of this nature happened in all mines and are only reported because of the unique regulatory regime established for the operations of the project.

The Supervising Scientist commented in his 1984-85 annual report that no effects of the mining operations beyond the immediate mining site area at Ranger had been observable. The report noted that there have been occurrences within the mine site over the years which have indicated some laxity in operational control and have given rise to regulatory concern, but most incidents have been minor and have not resulted in adverse impacts on humans or the environment beyond the mine site.

I am trying to provide to the House a balance on these reports of accidental releases. It is true that the Office of the Supervising Scientist commented in the 1984-85 report that the accidental releases had no adverse impact on humans or on the environment beyond the mine site. However, it is clear to me that the Ranger uranium mine was operating in a fashion which presented grave dangers to the environment of Kakadu National Park, particularly as the Supervising Scientist had also commented that technical mishaps within the mine site over the years indicated some laxity in operational control. If anything, I think the Office of the Supervisory Scientist should have been much stronger in its criticisms. I think it has let the Ranger mine off very lightly in its reports over the years. As I will go on to say a little later, it has suffered for that.

Since that time similar spillages and other technical mishaps have occurred at the mine, and now that has been capped by the deliberate release of toxic water from the Ranger mine into a billabong, with the approval of the Northern Territory Government. I find it quite surprising that the Northern Territory Government is prepared to allow the Ranger uranium mine to pollute Kakadu National Park in this way. It seems that the Northern Territory Government is more concerned with the profits obtained from uranium mining than it is with the profits which could be earned from tourist operations in Kakadu National Park. That is a short-sighted policy. Indeed, it indicates an ignorance of the great value of tourism to the Northern Territory. As was pointed out in the 1986-87 annual report of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, the number of visitors to Kakadu National Park continues to grow rapidly. In 1986 some 131,000 people visited the park and in 1987 the figure was estimated to reach 220,000. That represents a remarkable increase of 52 per cent, with visitors' comments indicating a very high level of satisfaction with the natural beauties of the park. The National Parks and Wildlife Service was commended on its management of the park, despite a lack of resources. There is an increasing demand from visitors for information about the park. Park visitors are encouraged to join ranger-guided tours of the main art sites and many visitors have indicated on the visitors' survey forms and in letters of appreciation that the tours were among the most memorable and satisfying of their experiences. It is in those circumstances that I find it particularly disgraceful that the Northern Territory Government is prepared to allow the Ranger uranium mine to pollute the park with toxic waste from the mine operations.

As mentioned briefly at the beginning of my speech and detailed by the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, the increased levy imposed by the Bill will partially offset the special costs of environmental monitoring and research activities carried out by the Office of the Supervising Scientist, other Commonwealth agencies and agencies of the Northern Territory Government acting on behalf of the Commonwealth Government. At this point I would like to quote from the 1987-88 report of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, which indicates the duplicity and deliberate misrepresentations the Ranger uranium mine management and the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy are prepared to engage in in order to discredit the Office of the Supervising Scientist:

Remarks critical of OSS operations-particularly relating to the cost and relevance of its research program-have been made in a number of public forums during 1987-88. ERA/Ranger in particular has developed an aggressive policy to discredit the OSS and seek its disbandment. The intensity of this campaign seems to mount as the Government's export levy on uranium exports from the Region increases-
I suppose it will increase again now-

Much of Ranger's critical comment has been repeated by the Northern Territory, most notably by the Minister for Mines and Energy in an opening speech to the Mining, Petroleum and Suppliers' Conference, in Darwin in May 1988. The NT Minister echoed a number of the Ranger initiated arguments critical of the effectiveness of the Office, added a few of his own that had no more substance or cogency, and claimed that the OSS was not carrying out its designated functions and proposed `the disbandment of the largely negative and costly Office of the Supervising Scientist and its incorporation instead into a properly established (NT) academic institution to involve itself in complete nuclear studies'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be quite neutral, wouldn't it?
—Absolutely. Just imagine how neutral that would be. The report continued:

SPEECH.PARA: It would not be appropriate in this Report to counter such assertions in detail but some comment is warranted, not only because of the serious misrepresentations of fact, but also because of the confusion they engender in the community about the role of the Supervising Scientist.

Some of the criticism-e.g. claims that the OSS largely duplicates work that is or could be done by the Northern Territory and that there is little benefit to the uranium industry from the research carried out by OSS-reflects a continuing misunderstanding of the functions of the OSS.

The Northern Territory, though carrying out the day-to-day licensing of the mining operations, has not established the scientific resources necessary to ensure comprehensive protection of the environment of the Region to the standard required by the Commonwealth. It has no expertise in aquatic environmental toxicity and cannot, at present, credibly control the release of mine waste water to the environment without access to the competence existing within the ARRRI. Nor has it established an environmental protection agency independent of the regulating Department of Mines and Energy which has as a major objective the promotion of mining.

The most important environmental research and monitoring work in the Alligator Rivers Region has been carried out by the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute of the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the region. Incidentally, it is worth reminding honourable members that the Alligator Rivers region comprises an area of approximately 28,000 square kilometres, containing the catchments of the East, South and West Alligator Rivers, east of Darwin. So it is a very important area to be protected.

The area is of outstanding interest because of its unusual combination of largely uninhabited wilderness areas with attractive wild scenery and abundant flora and fauna incorporating many unique features. The region also contains a very large concentration of Aboriginal rock art of international significance. It is for those reasons that the Kakadu National Park gained its World Heritage listing. The Research Institute has now built up a significant databank of information about the flora and fauna of the region as a result of the 10 years of research work undertaken by the Institute staff. The honourable member for Dunkley indicated some of the valuable work that has been done and in previous speeches I have detailed the valuable research work undertaken by the Institute, which goes far beyond the immediate need to monitor and study the operations of uranium mining in the Alligator Rivers Region. Moreover, since I last spoke on these matters there has been a systematic campaign by the mining industry to denigrate the work of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in an attempt to reduce the funding provided to the office and thus bring about a reduction in the export duty.

I do not have time in this speech to deal with all the research work undertaken in the programs of environmental radioactivity, chemistry, biological testing, biological monitoring, plant ecology, geomorphology and environmental modelling of the Ranger uranium site and the Magela Creek system, but I would like to cite one area of research which is indicative of the extreme importance of the work of the Institute. I refer to the geomorphology program, the research objective of which is to identify and quantify the geomorphological processes relevant to the siting and engineering design of tailings improvements and rock structures in order to minimise the long-term impact on the environment. The cost of that has been mentioned by the honourable member for Dunkley.

The mill tailings and waste rock of the Ranger uranium mine which will be left over from the extended life of the mine will contain most of the radioactivity of the original ore body. The longer lived major residual isotope has a half life of about 80,000 years. That is how long this radioactivity will last: 80,000 years. Of course, it is true that because of the low radioactivity level of tailings they do not constitute an acute radiological risk. However, no individual would be able to live on a uranium mine site because exposure over a number of years would produce health risks.

In these circumstances it is imperative that the proposed tailings dump, which will be five square kilometres in area and 20 metres high, must be constructed in a manner which will not cause harm to the environment, particularly the environment of a World Heritage park-Kakadu. The large volume of the dump, the possibility of movement of the tailings into the adjacent national park through wind force or flowing water, and the long term radioactive risk, mean that the dump must be isolated and prolonged human contact prevented. In the past tailings piles at other mines have not been protected, but fortunately such practices are no longer acceptable. I wish to quote from the 1987-88 annual research summary of the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute which indicates the vital importance of the work of the Institute and the Office of the Supervising Scientist which manages the research work of the Institute:

The requirement to contain tailings for periods of the order of a thousand years, necessitates the documentation of any future processes, as well as contemporary processes, that will affect the stability of containment structures. A structure with an engineer design life of 200 years must be interpreted, in the real world, as having a low, rather than zero, probability of failure over the 200 years following its construction. To achieve this satisfactorily, the design would have to be proof against rare extreme destabilising events having a recurrence interval very much longer than 200 years. Thus, a structure that is to have a probability of failure of, for example, 2% over 200 years must be designed to withstand an extreme event (a storm and consequent flood, for example) expected to recur only once every 10 000 years-
perhaps a cyclone-

The objectives of the program are, therefore: 1) to identify and quantify processes that could affect tailings impoundments and other earthen mine-related structures in the long-term, and 2) to devise criteria and designs to optimise the rehabilitation of these structures so that potential detrimental effects associated with their degradation are such that public health and the environment suffer minimal detriment over some thousands of years.

This is the whole point of the work of the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the research institute which provides the research capabilities for the Office. The point of this Bill is to provide sufficient funds to enable the Office of the Supervising Scientist to continue its valuable work. The mining industry, the Ranger uranium mine and the Northern Territory Government are attempting to denigrate the work of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in order to ensure that it does not have this watchdog capability of ensuring that mines such as the Ranger uranium mine do not continue, as they are at present, to pollute the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —They want a toothless tiger.

—That is right, they want a toothless tiger. They want to make sure that the Office of the Supervising Scientist does not have the ability or the funds to be able to draw attention to the kind of technical failures which the Ranger uranium mine has been operating over a number of years.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fact that, as the honourable member for Dunkley mentioned, there are attempts to open up new mines in the Northern Territory. One of those mines is the site at Ja Ja, that is the Jabiluka mine, which is adjacent to the wetlands of Kakadu. I can only say that if an underground mine such as that were to be opened up, it would constitute very grave threats to the future of the Kakadu National Park. In these circumstances, it behoves us all in this House to draw attention to these potential dangers and to ensure that the Office of the Supervising Scientist has continual funding to carry out its very worthwhile operations. I commend the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to a number of points raised by the now absent, and almost habitually absent, honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). He painted such an optimistic picture of the prospects for uranium that I wonder what monks' retreat he lives in. Has he talked to nobody in the industry about the spot price for uranium in the past few months? Does he really see uranium as a nuclear El Dorado, to mix a metaphor? He seemed to call-but it could have been only his confusion-for an increase in the number of uranium mines, currently three. Has he spoken to the operators of these three mines? Are they enthusiasts for bringing new mines on stream?

SPEECH.PARA: I have some news for him. In February this year I was in the Northern Territory with the honourable member for that distinguished electorate. I had an opportunity to go back to Kakadu National Park to visit the Office of the Supervising Scientist, to visit the Ranger uranium mine to see what was happening there in regard to research work, and also to look at the other points that have been raised. I took the opportunity to visit the Coronation Hill site, which is currently the subject of an environmental impact statement.

The Government rejects the amendment of the honourable member for Gippsland. I want to repeat more or less what I said in my second reading speech. The levy, which applies only to exports of uranium concentrate produced in the Alligator Rivers region of the Northern Territory, is imposed to partially offset the special costs of environmental monitoring and research activities undertaken by the Commonwealth to protect the Alligator Rivers region. The increase in the level of the levy reflects the Government's position that the costs associated with protecting the delicate environment of the Alligator Rivers region from the potential adverse effects of uranium mining should be borne as far as practicable by the industry carrying out those operations, and not by the ordinary taxpayer. It is a manifestation of a user pays philosophy.

Notwithstanding the comments made by the honourable member for Gippsland, I think that the correct rationale for the three mines policy was contained in a statement made by my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in this House on 23 February 1988, which canvassed the Government's current view on the matter-as he said quite correctly, a view that is being reviewed by the uranium review committee of the Australian Labor Party that should report late this year. The international community, through the World Heritage Commission, listed Kakadu National Park and it is, of course, a protected area. The Government is determined to ensure the highest standard of protection of that region, including the Kakadu National Park, and to be confident in the assurances it gives to the world that the whole region is being protected. Accordingly, some form of independent, credible scientific advice is required.

I find it extraordinary that the honourable member for Gippsland is generous enough to concede that the research work could perhaps be done, although obviously he thinks that there are too many people around monitoring the water and so on, but that somehow it could be done if two preconditions are met. The first is that it is scattered and that it is done somewhere else, somewhere off-site; and, secondly, that it should be carried out by a whole collection of other entities without something that has international standing and has the credibility that is required and the backing of the Commonwealth Government. I find that position quite absurd. We believe that the legislative functions and responsibilities of the Office of the Supervising Scientist are a necessary corollary to its listing as part of the World Heritage catalogue. It is to this end that the moneys raised by the levy are aimed.

There are several examples of research programs where the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the mining companies do collaborate. For example, in identifying and quantifying geomorphological processes relevant to the siting of tailings, impoundments-a technical word that is not mine-and other stabilised earth and rock structures. Given the long-80,000-year-half-life of residual isotopes, it will be necessary to stabilise these for hundreds of years. That is when long term geomorphological processes become relevant. The atmospheric transport of radon and radon daughters in the vicinity of the mine is another example. Very sophisticated techniques have been developed to assess the impact of mining on radon and radon daughter levels and public exposure in Jabiru. Other prominent areas of research include: background biological research to assess the effects of mining on the Magela Creek system; the development of creekside and in situ monitoring systems; and biological testing to develop prospective methods of assessing the toxic risks of mine waste water to aquatic organisms in order to specify safe dilution levels of these waters for discharge into streams. Once more I commend the Bill to the House and ask the House to reject the amendment.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: If Qantas is going to spend $6 billion and if it is all to be raised by debt, we will see a succession of these Bills.
