They are empty words which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is not capable of moving upon. This is despite the fact that he recognises the need to do it: the Treasurer (Mr Keating) knows it has to be done; the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) knows it has to be done; and, I dare say, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table, knows it has to be done. Had the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) been successful in becoming the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support when the job was available the other night, he would have been a strong advocate of privatisation. I know that the honourable member went very close indeed. Such are the benefits of the factional system that the best man got the job in spite of where he lives!

I return to the subject before the House, which is a very serious issue. The Government has said for some time that it is totally committed to micro-economic reform and that it will do everything it can to encourage and develop Qantas as a commercially viable organisation. Let us go back to May of last year. In the May statement the Government made great play about how it was going to restructure the economy and how various things were going to be done. As a result of that May statement, Qantas was subjected to further controls. I remind honourable members that Qantas is a public company, not a statutory authority. It could be listed on the stock exchange if the Government wanted to address the rightful issue. The further controls that were applied to Qantas related specifically to industrial relations and the coordination there. I will have more to say about the consequences of that in terms of the operations and safety standards that Qantas is able to maintain. More controls were imposed on its financial targets. There was, of course, a control imposed on the appointment of its chief executive officer.

All of this was done in the name of deregulation, micro-economic reform and making the operation more commercial. The net result was the imposition of more restrictions and regulations. We can go back even further to 1984 and actions of the then Minister for Transport. There has been a virtual parade of Ministers for transport around here. I remind the honourable member for Macarthur that his time will probably come because the current Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support is the fourth in a very short period of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —She will be good.

—I hope so; I have some good questions for her. Her predecessor was, of course, the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch). Before him there was a former Attorney-General from South Australia. He had the job for a while. Before that there was a former full blown Cabinet Minister who was given the job for a while as a junior Minister. We have had a succession of Ministers. That probably explains why there is no coherent and comprehensive aviation policy. I know that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) is preoccupied with lots of other issues. These include how he can stop the proposals of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) for radical reform of communications and how he can achieve micro-economic reform on the waterfront without actually doing anything. It is no wonder that there has been very little attention given to aviation and, of course, this important issue of Qantas.

SPEECH.PARA: It amazes me that the Government does not attach more importance to aviation. I am told, using the figures of Qantas, that it is one of Australia's largest earners of foreign exchange. Last time I saw any balance of payments figures we had a problem there. It is fairly significant and is likely to continue for some time. I would have thought that this Government would be very keen to do anything that it could to increase the capacity of an Australian enterprise to earn more foreign exchange and more dollars to help finance that deficit for us. All the Government does is place more and more impediments in the way of the operations of Qantas.

In the current calendar year Australian airlines will spend about $2 billion on new aircraft. This is associated with the expansion of air travel in this country. Basically, that expansion, although in some ways domestically generated-Expo undoubtedly had an impact on that-has resulted from a major growth in international tourism involving this country. To that extent, Qantas has on order some six Boeing 747-400s and a Boeing 767-300. I am told that if the Boeing aircraft company can deliver on time these aircraft will be delivered this calendar year. There is some doubt about whether they will be delivered on time. The cost of those aircraft is $1.62 billion. It will all be financed by debt. It will all have Commonwealth guarantees on it.

What I have not mentioned in terms of the restrictions imposed on Qantas is that it is now subject to Loan Council approval. If that is not a double standard, I do not know what is. The Government talks about commercial terms for Qantas. Do honourable members think that Alan Bond would be asked to go before the Loan Council? Maybe he is a bit closer to some members of the Labor Party than others. If the Government expects Qantas to get out and mix it with 36 other airlines-that is how many other airlines fly into this country-does it not think that it should untie the hands of Qantas and level up the playing field? Does the Government not think that the airlines should, at least, trade on the same basis as the other airlines? Let me say to the Government that it is actually building a disaster. Just as this Government for six years did nothing about Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and, in fact, decided to reverse the decision to build another runway, let the crisis build and sat on its hands, it has been sitting on its hands for six years in terms of Qantas.

The Government has been letting the debt levels rise. Honourable members do not have to take my word for it. Listen to the words of the Chairman of Qantas, Mr Jim Leslie. Last year, when announcing Qantas's record profit level-the highest profit in the 68 years of the company's operations-he said that the airline's debt was reaching an unacceptably high level, which would `place the company at risk if a downturn occurred in the market'. Since that statement was made, how much more money has Qantas borrowed? This is the second Bill we have dealt with in this place this year. This Bill is for several hundred million dollars, as was the previous Bill. Yet last year, prior to those loan raisings, the Chairman said that the debt was too high and the company was at risk. What is the Government going to do about it?

When Mr Leslie was announcing that profit he went on to say that eight out of 10 of Qantas's competitors flying into this country were privatised wholly or partially. If one looks at those which are not, one will probably find that they come from communist or socialist countries. In recent years increasingly governments around the world have come to understand that there is a need to get out of the airline business, to sell off their shareholding in the national flag carrier. But of course this Government, which is reactionary when it comes to micro-economic reform, has done nothing. Right now is the best time to privatise Qantas. There are no objections to it. It is the Opposition's policy to privatise Qantas. It is the policy of Cabinet to do it, but it is scared of the ALP Caucus. Qantas staff are in favour of it, as is the Australian public. If one intends to float a company one should do so while that company is trading well. Qantas has high profit levels. If the Government floated the shares now it would get a substantial premium and maximise the capital raisings available from the float. That would mean that capital would be raised in the cheapest possible way for Qantas. The timing is right now. If the Government procrastinates and dallies, it may miss the opportunity, just as it will probably look at selling off Australian Airlines at the worst possible time.

As I said, the majority of clear thinkers in the Labor Party, who unfortunately are at the mercy of a ragtag mob in Caucus, do not have the political guts to push this issue through which they have to do. Look how they procrastinated and mucked around on the question of Sydney Airport. Just look at how that decision was taken. There was meeting after meeting. First of all there was to be a decision before Christmas, then it was to happen in February. Then we had several meetings and more submissions. We sat all night and we tied our stomachs in knots while the whole country sat around waiting for this Government to decide where it was going to pour some concrete. That is what it came down to. The Government could not take that decision in spite of the fact that the overwhelming weight of objective and expert advice was saying `build the third runway'. Look at the trauma the Government went through. This is the best Labor front bench since the war yet it could not decide where to pour a slab of concrete. No wonder it is having problems with Qantas.

At the Australian Labor Party's National Conference in Hobart, the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans-another person I missed out on the earlier list-spoke about the realities of Qantas in the Australian air traffic market. He pointed out that without additional investment Qantas's market share would drop to 28 per cent. Currently it is 44 per cent. He went on to say that it needed about $600m by way of a capital injection. These are direct quotes; they are probably in the transcript of the conference proceedings that were handed out to industry, because at that stage the Government was determined to prove to industry and business leaders around the country that it was made of the right stuff and would take the right decision. Since then we have seen nothing of any right decision. Senator Evans said, and it is absolutely appropriate today:
There is Buckley's chance of the Government providing that $600m.

Buckley's; and that is as true today as it was then. He went on to say that every 5 per cent loss in market share suffered by Qantas-say from around 44 per cent to 28 per cent-represents a $100m loss in our foreign exchange earnings. As I said, we have a major problem. What will our deficit be this year? Twelve billion dollars? Can we afford to hand away $100m every time Qantas's market share drops because the Government will not challenge the left wing on what is essentially a rational and correct position? It is essential that the Government come to grips with this problem because if it does not, Qantas will be put in a very precarious situation and Australia will suffer as a result.

I said at the beginning of my remarks that this Government does not have the capacity to deal with a commercial enterprise such as Qantas operating in an extremely competitive and rapidly growing section of the world economy. I pointed out that as a result of the so-called liberalisation of the Government's approach to business enterprises, Qantas had been placed under even more restrictions in terms of industrial relations. The consequences of this Government's wages policy have been a disaster for Qantas and Qantas passengers. It has become so bad that the Chief Executive of Qantas wrote to his major business travellers to apologise for the problems that Qantas was having, saying, `If you experienced difficulties and delays on Qantas flights in recent months, it was not all our fault. All we can do is tell the Government what the problem is and hope and pray that it will do something about it'.

But, of course, the Government is not prepared to do anything about it. The Chief Executive of Qantas was alluding firstly to the problems of Kingsford-Smith Airport and the lack of capacity there. I have already referred to the sort of trauma the Government went through in taking that decision. It is not over yet. I think it would be appropriate to mention the nice little charade that the Government is involved in at the present time-an 18-month timetable for the development of the environmental impact statement. Today in this very place the Minister for Transport and Communications said:
We need to take our time on this environmental impact study to ensure that there is every opportunity for the public to contribute.

What he forgot to say when he was providing that answer was that the study will be on public exhibition for one month only. The honourable member for Macarthur is shaking his head. Is that time period to be changed then?

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that at all.

—I am sorry. The timetable that I have-and I would like the Minister to make a statement on it so that the issue can be debated; it would be a good idea if he did-states that the period for public display will be one month. It is the most vague timetable for any environmental impact study I have ever seen and, given that I know of and have seen a lot of the work that has been done for this study and the research that has been done by the Government's own authorities, I find it incredible. But let us come to grips with why it takes 18 months to prepare the environmental impact study.

—I suggest that the honourable member for Richmond come to grips with the legislation. I am very relaxed about the way in which the debate is proceeding but if he can focus it a little upon financial matters of the loan guarantee Bill I would be pleased.
—I think the congestion at Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport-and obviously you are not aware of the delays, Mr Deputy Speaker-is very relevant to the financial position of Qantas.
—Order! I am not suggesting that the honourable member for Richmond debate the point; I am merely suggesting that he focus upon the legislation. I ask him to do that.

—I make the point that this legislation is raising money for Qantas. Qantas loses a lot of money because it has to operate out of a congested airport. Since that loss of money has a direct impact on additional funding, I think that it is entirely relevant. As every member of this House knows, the Qantas base is Sydney Airport. We are talking about the need for reform and, as honourable members will be aware, an amendment has been circulated in my name. I think it is relevant to read it for the benefit of the House. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House calls on the Government to recognise the urgent need to provide additional capital resources for Qantas and overcome ideological objections to the sale of shares in the airline to its staff and the Australian public'.

I think that is entirely relevant to the whole question of aviation policy in Australia. But as I said, the Chief Executive of Qantas wrote to its best customers and apologised by saying, `It is not our fault, it is the Government's aviation policy'. As I have said, there is a need to recognise that Qantas is a public company, it should be treated as such and it should be allowed to trade as a public company.

I began my remarks by talking about the wages policy and the impact that it had. The wages policy has meant that Qantas has not been able to employ an appropriate number of skilled metal trades workers because it is uncompetitive in the marketplace. It has been forced to jump through more hoops over its wages policy than could possibly be imagined. Some of the correspondence that has flowed between the Minister's office and Qantas would make very interesting reading on the front page of a newspaper one day-and it will probably end up there-because it makes a complete mockery of this Government's so-called commitment to micro- economic reform in allowing Qantas to trade in a flexible manner in commercially competitive terms. It is a complete joke.

But the consequence of that has been very serious for this airline. It is cancelling flights at present. There is a lack of equipment and a lack of serviced planes. It is sending its aircraft overseas to be serviced because it does not have the staff to do it here in Australia. The standard of that service is not up to the standards that Qantas has prided itself on for years. As an aside: recently certain members of this place travelled overseas on a Qantas flight. Do honourable member know why that flight was delayed 24 hours? Do they know that the official reason given by Qantas for that delay was that the airline had had the aircraft serviced by another company-and I will not mention that company-and it was not satisfied with the standard of that service; therefore it was not prepared to fly it. Why was Qantas having it serviced overseas? It was because of the wages policy, the industrial relations restrictions that have been imposed upon it. Those restrictions have been imposed irrespective of the consequences for Australian travellers and the standards of that airline. No doubt all honourable members in this House would be aware that recently Qantas had an aircraft on approach to Cairns that lost the leading edge of a flap. That substantial piece of metal fell off and landed on the ground. Thankfully it was in a fairly sparsely populated area approaching Cairns. Had it happened on approach to Sydney it could have had a serious consequence. That aircraft had also recently been serviced by someone other than Qantas.

This Government's approach to Qantas and its refusal to overcome this stupid ideological objection to privatising it is throwing it on the mercy of whatever deals it can do around the international marketplace. As a result, an airline that we are all proud of, an airline that has an international reputation second to none in terms of safety, is encountering difficulties and maintaining that record and that standard of service that we should all reasonably expect it to continue to provide into the future and that is a direct result of this Government's non-existent policies on aviation and the privatisation of the airline. I think this Government really stands condemned. But the point of this debate here tonight is to highlight the absolute necessity to provide a sound and commercially viable capital base for this great Australian enterprise, an enterprise that has the complete support of every Australian. Australians would all genuinely like to be shareholders in Qantas and they should have the opportunity to buy shares in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are.
—They are now.

—The left wing of the Australian Labor Party owns shares in it at present; that is who controls Qantas. I heard an interjection from the Government benches to the effect that Government members are shareholders. Let me tell them that the average Australian would like Qantas to be sold and so would the employees of Qantas. Honourable members opposite should undertake a survey. All the shares are currently owned by the Commonwealth Government. Who determines how that voting power will be used? The mob that sits opposite, the left wing of the Labor Party. They are not even participating in the debate. They are not even in the chamber. The left wing controls the shares in Qantas, not the right wing and not Centre Unity. It has hijacked Qantas and that is why the mighty right wing cannot do anything about it. The mighty right wing is absolutely powerless to do anything about it. Of course, it just makes a mockery of anything Government members say in terms of micro-economic reform. Where is it? What are we doing?

SPEECH.PARA: We have just lost the Chief Executive of Australian Airlines. James Strong resigned today. This Government was busy advertising his job around the place; is it any wonder that he was probably susceptible to an offer from someone else? The reality is that, until this Government decides what the future of Australian Airlines is, what sort of success will the Government have in attracting a first class replacement for Mr Strong? What sort of top executive will walk into an airline, which is heading for deregulation under some sort of guise which will not work-honourable members opposite all know that it will not work-without the Government spelling out clearly what its intentions are as the major shareholder? Before he takes the contract he has a right to go and see the Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will refer to the Bill before the House. We are not discussing Australian Airlines.

—We are discussing the need to privatise Qantas. Of course, the same circumstances that apply to Qantas apply to Australian Airlines. Would honourable members opposite like me to talk about the Chief Executive of Qantas because the same thing applies? Honourable members opposite know what this Government has done to Qantas. It has imposed further restrictions on the ability of the Board of a public company to hire a chief executive. The question that must be asked is: Who is ultimately responsible for Qantas? Is the board of directors responsible for Qantas's operations, or does the Minister assume full responsibility? If the Government is to impose restrictions it implies that the Minister is to assume full responsibility. So, heaven forbid, when we have a crisis with Qantas is the same Minister who reserves the right and the power to determine who the Chief Executive of Qantas is going to walk into this House and say, `I am responsible'? Of course he is not. It is a total double standard. The Government wants its cake and it wants to eat it too, but it will pay a high price for it. Unless something is done about Qantas it will lose the market share and the company will be put in a very precarious position, as the Chairman has said.
—You didn't adduce that argument for Australian when they're getting an increased market share.
—The Minister for Employment and Education Services who is seated at the table, has invited me to talk about Australian Airlines. Can I do it, Mr Deputy Speaker?
—I would prefer you to stick to the Bill before the House.

—With reluctance I will not address the question of Australian Airlines; I will not remind the Minister that we supported the conversion of the corporation into a public company to facilitate his privatisation of it; I will not remind the Minister that it is our policy to sell the shares in it; and I will not remind the Minister that it also needs about $300m in capital.

SPEECH.PARA: For the benefit of everybody in the chamber at present let me also say that the options are to increase taxes, to reduce expenditure, or to privatise. So where will the cuts be? Tell us where the cuts will be to finance Qantas. Is the answer that this Government will not finance Qantas? Is the answer that this Government will deregulate international air travel into Australia because the demand for seats into Australia will continue to increase? If this Government does not do something about it, through providing capital for Qantas to expand its equipment so that it can provide more seats, we will have an increasing demand and there will be a need to have more flights into Australia. Will we have more foreign carriers coming into Australia, or will we build a wall around Australia, which is a classic response from the left wing, and say, `There are only so many thousands of seats available into this country. We will not have any more capacity. If Qantas cannot have it under our restrictive policies no-one is coming in. You cannot come here and spend your foreign exchange because we cannot come to grips with a basic decision in Caucus'?

If honourable members opposite thought that the runway decision at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport was difficult for this Government I would really like to be a fly on the wall when it finally gets round to talking about this one. I just think that the Government is incapable of addressing the realities of commercial life in Australia today. Honourable members opposite think that they can wheel out the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that he will say, `Everything will be fine, trust me', and Qantas's problem will be fixed. But, unfortunately, Qantas trades in the real world. It is for that reason that we, on this side of the chamber, have an unequivocal commitment to providing for the privatisation of Qantas, to selling shares in Qantas to its staff and to the Australian public and to letting it trade with both hands untied, competitively, in a growing international market. The Government has really been revealed as the laughing stock for its total and continuing failure to come to grips with a pressing problem. For six years this Government has been in power and for six years it has done nothing on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Yes, I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a little tempted to read back into Hansard my contribution to the Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill 1988, dated 12 October 1988, because it simply followed the speech made at the time by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) on a similar proposition; that is, that the Government go guarantor for the purchase of aircraft by Qantas Airways Ltd. However, as my prior contribution would certainly address all the issues the honourable member for Richmond has raised tonight-he did not go to anything different, except the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport decision-I will refrain from doing that. However, I refer him to my previous speech on the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to raise some other issues. First, in his contribution the honourable member for Richmond started at, and came back to, the proposition that Qantas should be privatised, with shares sold to the public and indeed to those people who worked in Qantas. He was suggesting therefore that Qantas was by no means a public company. I suggest to him, as I have done in the past, that it is a public company; it is owned and operated on behalf of the people of Australia. They are the shareholders now.

The other factor is that there seems to be a view within the Opposition that because a government enterprise is making a profit and is being run well, it should not reside with government. I think there can be absolutely no argument that Qantas is being run well. I refer again to some figures on that aspect of Qantas's operation so that honourable members might reflect on them. The Qantas annual report 1977-88 offers some very interesting reading for those who have the opportunity to look through it.

The first point that needs to be made-and, to his credit, the honourable member for Richmond did refer to the excellent profit recorded by Qantas last year-relates to that profit figure. On operations for 12 months in 1988 its profit was $153.3m. For a company that is supposedly in dire straits, in need of massive capital injections, that is not a bad starting point. One should consider the figures over a longer period. Let me take the year 1982, about which I reminded the honourable gentleman last year in this debate. If one looks at the profit from about 1982, and then works one's way through, one finds that in 1982 there was no profit for Qantas, in fact, there was a loss of $20.2m. In 1983 there was a loss of $47.4m. Suddenly an amazing thing happened in Australia: there was a change of government. Immediately in 1984 the profit for Qantas was $58.3m. Qantas went from a loss of $47.4m in 1983 to a profit of $58.3m in 1984. The profit continued to rise, and in 1987 it reached $104.3m. As I have indicated, in 1988 for the 12-month period it was $153.3m

I suggest, and I hope that even the honourable member for Richmond and the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) would agree with me, that Qantas has done an excellent job in turning an untenable situation around. It has done so without necessarily relying on massive injections of funds, either from the Government or from the private sector. I am on the Caucus transport and communications committee and I have no doubt that the Opposition has similar policy committees. I have no doubt that Qantas representatives have been along and spoken to them about its capital needs, its debt-equity ratios, and so on. We have all heard the same points. My colleague the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) will talk at some length on that issue shortly. Interestingly, we have seen Qantas continuing to make these great profits and at the same time expanding its operations in this area. For example, last year we saw a bid to purchase some 25 per cent of Air New Zealand, a bid which has been successful. For a company that someone on the other side might suggest is going to the wall, I would say that that clearly demonstrates just the opposite.

The question of the Sydney decision was raised by the honourable member for Richmond, who made one or two points about it. I remind him that the environmental impact statement (EIS) procedure is going to be controlled by the Government in terms of what has to be done. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) will be putting forward the guidelines for that. I also remind the honourable gentleman that for the Badgerys Creek environmental impact statement, when consideration was given to alternative sites-one of which we all remember was Wilton in my electorate, which some still suggest should have been the chosen site for a second airport-part of that examination also looked at Badgerys Creek once it was chosen as the appropriate location. It took 21 months to gather information.

Having worked with the New South Wales Department of the Environment and Planning for eight years, having been involved in the preparation and examination of a number of environmental impact statements, I can say that despite the assertion by the New South Wales Premier, Nick Greiner, that three months is an adequate period to deal with something as complex as an EIS for a third runway at Mascot, that is simply not feasible. One has to consider the collection of fill and where it is to come from; the environmental damage that could result from taking sand out of the Botany Bay bed or from further out to sea. One has to consider the implications of a major traffic study in that area. One has to consider the implications in a socio-economic sense. These procedures take time. I am sorry to say to Mr Greiner and to those on the other side of the House that the period this Government has identified as necessary really is appropriate.

The second issue relating to the EIS is that the timetable for public scrutiny, with great respect to the honourable member for Richmond, did not say that it would allow one month alone for public comment on the EIS or for public participation in the decision-making process. Rather, it said there would be a minimum of one month. Certainly, as I understand it this Government will be guaranteeing that there will be much more than one month for the consideration of objections and for the EIS process for the third runway at Mascot. I would be most surprised if it is anything less than three months.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I heed the warning you gave to the honourable member in his contribution that the focus of this Bill is not on these extraneous matters but on the fact that we are endeavouring to authorise the Treasurer (Mr Keating), on behalf of the Commonwealth, to guarantee the repayment of loans and interest on funds raised by Qantas to purchase three Boeing 747-400 aircraft and associated spare parts and equipment. As we are aware, this is a new series of aircraft utilising new technology. Its strategic value lies in the flexibility and competitive advantage inherent in the extra long-range capability. Therefore, the aircraft are going to operate essentially on two of our most relevant tourist markets: the kangaroo route, that is, Sydney-Singapore-London; and the Pacific route between Sydney and Los Angeles.

The honourable member for Richmond indicated the importance of tourism, in an economic sense, to the future growth of Australia and, indeed, to Mascot and the Sydney region generally. He is absolutely correct. The information that I have suggests that inbound tourism, as measured by short term visitor arrivals, reached almost 2.22 million in the year ending November 1988. That is a substantial number of visitors coming into Sydney. It is an increase of almost 28 per cent over the previous 12 months. We all know that Australia is now a tourist destination for many people. We have encouraged that. I have heard the Opposition spokesman on tourism, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), commenting on how the cost of hotel rooms in Sydney is now starting to bite and frighten people away. I do not think that is necessarily reflected by the figures at this stage, although I have some sympathy for his views.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you should. It's expensive to stay there, isn't it?

—It is when one is working on committees as a humble backbencher. The figures certainly indicate that Sydney is the destination preferred by most people coming into this country. Therefore, we have to provide for that. We must provide the infrastructure for Australia's national carrier, Qantas, to ensure that people are able to come here.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, Qantas is not the only company that is going to purchase these sorts of modern generation aircraft. Its major competitors will be doing the same. Therefore, we cannot afford to be left behind. Our Government, through this Bill, will guarantee the borrowings. But we will limit that guarantee of borrowings for three aircraft to $US385m, or its equivalent in foreign currencies, which represents 85 per cent of the total project cost. It is important to have it understood that we are guaranteeing that purchase.

This raises another issue which the honourable member for Richmond noted-the balance of payments problem. As we have seen, a great contribution to Australia's balance of payments problem has been the purchase of capital equipment like these new generation jets. By adding $US385m to our current account deficit, it obviously does something which is not in Australia's interest other than providing an opportunity for more tourists to be brought into this country, and hopefully offsetting the deficit problem.

The other thing I wanted to concentrate on tonight in regard to this Bill is something which my colleague on the other side of the House did not raise-the method of acquiring these aircraft. I raised this in the debate last year on the purchase of other aircraft by Qantas. I am Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. We are presently investigating the use by Australian companies of tax havens to minimise tax responsibilities in Australia. Last year I commented on an article in the Sydney Morning Herald which was the subject of some consideration at the time. The article was entitled `You own the airline, Japanese own the Jumbos'. To refresh the minds of honourable members on the issue, the article described how Qantas uses a very complex arrangement whereby it buys aircraft from Boeing, sells the aircraft to Japan and buys the aircraft back from Japan through banks in tax havens. That in no way minimises the tax requirement in Australia, but it takes advantage of tax laws in Japan, to Australia's benefit.

This issue has been raised in our Committee and has been the subject of answers to questions by no less a person than the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Trevor Boucher. He clearly indicated to our Committee that this process is a matter for the Japanese revenue people and not for Australia, because no tax minimisation is associated with the process in Australia. There is nothing legally wrong with the process. But it raises the issue once again of the use of tax havens for operations involving a quasi-government enterprise.

Given the degree of concern in the community now about tax haven uses by private organisations and public companies listed on the stock exchange, I suspect that this issue will receive some airing. But I point out that this arrangement is commonplace in the world of transport. I repeat that it does not in any way impinge upon Australian taxation laws. If there is a problem with it, it is up to the Japanese Government to worry about it. It is a minimisation process in Japan's tax laws. As I have indicated, the Australian Taxation Office does not believe that it is an appropriate matter for Australia. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has also investigated this matter and concurs with the statement I have just made.

It is appropriate that this legislation be supported by the Parliament. As I have indicated, I do not think that the second reading amendment is appropriate, given the circumstances. Speakers from the other side will follow me in this debate and will go to the basic premise that Qantas is a company that is ripe for privatisation simply because it is successful. Every public company that is successful is in the sights particularly of the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), who has put his Party's position on this matter very clearly. We on this side of the House reject such propositions-in deference to the left, right and centre left wings of the Party, I might say to the honourable member for Richmond.

As was the case with the legislation last year, this legislation is important in that it allows Qantas to continue to compete effectively in a very important tourist market for Australia. It will enable us to buy new generation jet aircraft and the equipment that goes with them. It will enable us to continue to receive a very large influx of tourists from an important market segment, both Europe and the United States. I welcome the fact that Qantas is taking that initiative and is competing very hard out there in the marketplace. Qantas is to be congratulated. As I have indicated, the method of acquiring those aircraft is something with which no one in this place should unduly concern himself.

I have mentioned the debt position, but will now quote other figures to clarify the situation. In 1986 Qantas's total assets were of the order of $1.6 billion. TALK.START.PARA: —What about Woolworths and Coles? Do you want to make some comparison?

We must look at the consequences of that and weigh them up in relation to what the company will face if there is an economic downturn. As I said before to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Macarthur, we do not all live in up periods. I only have to quote the years 1979, 1980, 1981, 1982 and 1983 in which the company made very small profits or substantial losses. Those times will return.

SPEECH.PARA: Having put that to one side, let me just go quietly across to what has happened to Japan Air Lines (JAL) since it moved from a government operation to a private enterprise. I will quote from an article in Euromoney of February 1989. It states:

The complete privatisation of Japan Air Lines in November 1987 was a mixed blessing for the company's finance department. JAL no longer carries a government guarantee when it raises funds, and its rating has consequently slipped from triple-A to double-A.

But the company was also released from the requirement of seeking approval from both the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Transport every time it borrows money. Sometimes the bureaucracy involved was stifling, according to Kazuhiko Fujiyama, staff vice-president at JAL's finance department. Anything new, such as a convertible mortgage arrangement with a US bank to finance a real-estate acquisition, might take at least six months to be cleared by the MoF.

JAL's new-found freedom will be valuable. ``Over the coming three years we need to raise a tremendous amount, so we will have to a look at every corner of the capital markets . . . JAL plans to invest some . . . ($5.6 billion) over that period. Of that total, around . . . ($3.4 billion) will be raised from the capital markets, and around . . . ($1.6 billion) of that overseas.

The choice between domestic and international borrowings will be made, as a rule, according to the proposed use of the funds. Cargo and airport facilities at Narita and Osaka will be financed with domestic borrowings . . .
Japanese yen financing is best for airport facilities that don't produce direct income-
that is another speciality of this Government-
They need stable long-term money . . .
On it goes about JAL's financial commitments. The article continues:
Eight months after privatisation, the airline successfully issued additional stock, and more recently it raised . . . ($1.6 billion) in the domestic commercial paper market in two tranches.

That is what has happened to JAL, which is a very direct and very important competitor of Qantas, every day of the week in Australia. It shows what it has been able to do since it has moved away from the clutches of government. It has been able to go out and raise money, buy its aircraft, expand its services and meet the requirements. No-one in the world today will deny that JAL is a very competitive and good airline to be on.

TALK.START.PARA: —And highly profitable.

—It is a highly profitable airline, as the honourable member for Fadden has said. That in itself stands in my mind as a very stark reminder of what we must be doing in Australia in addressing the position of Qantas. It is a company which has enormous potential and is one which we are all intensely proud of. It is a company which, over the years, has made a dramatic contribution to the whole of Australia and in current times is a very big earner of foreign exchange. It has representation across the world. Because of those facts alone it should be given a fair go. A fair go is certainly not a part of the anti-privatisation push within the Labor Party. Unless Qantas is given access to the capital markets of the world it will certainly perish in an economic decline. It cannot take full advantage of its recent associations with Air New Zealand and other airlines around the world unless it is given the appropriate amount of money to do so. Quite clearly that is not going to come from this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We, in government, make quite a clear commitment to it. We will privatise Qantas, let there be no doubt about that. It is something which is desired by the company. We will do that for a number of reasons: because it is better for the consumer as he will get a better deal, it is better for the company employees because they will be shareholders in that company, they will have a pride in that company and they will know what they are doing. They will be involved in the management of that company which will be properly financed. It will not be answerable to the Department of Finance in Canberra, it will be answerable to the shareholders of that company, the citizens of Australia and the citizens who are taking a role in it. More importantly than anything else, it will be secured in its capital base against the fall of any future economic regime within the world. Its equity to debt relationship will be addressed. Its return on equity will become a significant factor. Its profit on sales will become measured, from which Qantas will grow. Its interest cover will be known and its return on assets will become a significant factor in the future. Indeed, given a fair go, Qantas will become one of the great airlines of the world.

. . . sale of shares in the airline to its staff and the Australian public.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously there is a need to ensure that additional capital is available to Qantas to enable it to expand, but that is what the Bill before the House is all about. The purpose of the Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill is to authorise the Treasurer (Mr Keating), on behalf of the Government, to guarantee the repayment of loans borrowed by Qantas for the purchase of new aircraft-in this instance three Boeing 747-400 aircraft, new technology aircraft. I admit that the purchase of these aircraft is vitally important to maintain Qantas's dynamic expansion program. Recently I had the pleasure of meeting Roger Robertson, the director of corporate planning in Australia, who came to Rockhampton to talk about promoting our region through Qantas.

Qantas has an exciting story to tell. It is certainly a great emblem for development and advancement in this country. There has been an almost 28 per cent increase in inbound traffic and Qantas is taking on a $5 billion to $6 billion fleet expansion program over the next five years. It plans to increase that fleet from 33 to 50. That is a massive expenditure program in anyone's mind. During the last financial year-the honourable member for Ryan talked about a 15-month period, and that is correct-Qantas carried 4.3 million passengers. To November 1988 inbound tourism reached 2,220,000 people. Its earnings during that period were $3.8 billion. When one sees what Qantas does for our country one starts to realise what a major contributor it is to Australia's balance of payments. Its net earnings in foreign currency during that period were $1.2 billion-that is, $1,200m. By way of comparison, the figure for the previous financial year was $444m. The increase was almost threefold; yet the Liberal and National parties say, `Sell it up. Sell up a great contributor to this country's balance of payments. Sell up an enterprise that is booming'. The time it did not boom was between 1978 and 1982, under the Liberal-National coalition.

Qantas is now Australia's No. 2 exporter. Looking at the top 500 across this country, it rates No. 2. Its overseas revenue for the 15-month period was $2.5 billion. We are talking about a massive industry-a massive earner of foreign moneys. It employs directly 15,000 people and tens of thousands of other people are employed indirectly or get their income from working in and around its activities. It is a great spender in promoting our country. If one adds the wages, office facilities and all the activities in which Qantas is involved in promotion internationally, one finds that it spends $300m a year promoting Australia. It has 80 sales offices in 30 different countries. It is targeting the issues. It realises the expansion that is taking place in the Japanese and Asian markets. It is spending $6m on an Asian language program. Most people would not even be aware of the sort of contribution that Qantas makes. Five million dollars is being spent on upgrading the language skills of Qantas staff, particularly Asian languages, and another $1m is being spent in Australian schools to get our young students to learn foreign languages.

Qantas is heavily involved in all sorts of skills training areas, including the hospitality and catering industry and the engineering industry. It has apprenticeships galore throughout that 15,000 work force. One knows the advantages of having worked in the management area of Qantas, of how that finds one well for other activities in the private sector. Qantas is the leader in tourism, both wholesaling and retailing. It has a well recognised reputation that has been built up over many years-not by idiots who do not know how to run a company-for safety and standards.

Most members of parliament have the privilege of travelling, as many other Australians do, and when they travel they hear people praise Qantas for its safety, and service standards. It has a wonderful reputation and it is important that that reputation be maintained. As the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) said, it is important that it is able to compete through its aircraft quality. We know that other carriers that serve Australia are also introducing the Boeing 747-400s. So Qantas must maintain its share of the market. It must have aircraft with that extra long range capability to service Europe, the London-Australia trip, and the Los Angeles-Sydney trip. It must spend money doing that. I believe that all honourable members, regardless of their ideology, will say that the $US385m, which is what those aircraft will cost is money well spent, because it will maintain Qantas's competitive base.

Qantas is working for Australia and it should be allowed to continue to do so. It ought not to be allowed to fall into the hands of some foreign interests. One hears the National Party in Queensland expressing concern because the Japanese are moving in and taking over aspects of the beef industry. This industry, this company, this firm, Qantas, would be grabbed up by the private sector, and why? It would be grabbed up not only because of its potential but also because of what it is achieving right now. We all understand that there can be the tough times. There certainly were under the Liberals and Nationals between 1978 and 1982. But there are also the good times, and this country needs to gain the maximum benefit from those good times. It should have a national carrier. It ought to have an aircraft industry that works for Australia and promotes it. That is exactly what Qantas is doing.

Qantas is sophisticated in its activities, monitoring tourist demand changes and understanding that people want lengthened holiday times and more than one destination. Qantas is in there doing it. As I said, recently Roger Robertson, the director of corporate planning for Australia, came to central Queensland with Ray Jeppson, the State Manager of Qantas. The head of the Asian desk has also been because Qantas is looking for new destinations. It realises that the Asians and the Japanese want to see more than just Sydney and Ayers Rock: they want new experiences. Qantas heads of management travel around this country working with local entrepreneurs, sorting out and testing the tourist baskets that exist and promoting regional Australia as an international tourist destination.

I welcome what Qantas is doing. I want to see continued support for it. I do not want to see Qantas sold up and become nothing more than something owned by the Japanese, the Swiss or the Americans. That is where the money would come from. The Opposition talks about attracting billions of dollars in investment, but from where? Its own spokesmen admit that this country does not have the required savings. We must encourage more domestic savings. Where will the money come from? If the Opposition gets its way, because of its rules it will come from overseas investors. That is what it wants to do. It is happy to open the floodgates of foreign investment in this country. It has an official policy to do away with the Foreign Investment Review Board. If the Opposition gains office-I dread the day that that ever happens-Australia will suffer.

It is important that capital be available. That is what the Bill is all about. It is important that Qantas be able to compete and continue to expand its activities in Japanese areas. I am told that there are now 15 flights a week from Japan. Qantas is moving to improve the number of Asian tourists coming to this country. It is making sure that Australia is an attractive destination and that people know about it. It is spending money doing it. Three hundred million dollars is a lot of money in tourist promotion and that is what Qantas is spending. I applaud it on its initiatives, the way it uses the flying kangaroo as an Australian emblem and for doing so proudly. It is important that Qantas maintain its pace in its development and expansion. It is important that it be able to compete. However, at this point it is clear that the right measure is to ensure that the loans that Qantas undertakes can be guaranteed. That is what the Bill is all about and I welcome it. I urge full support for it. I urge that the rather insidious amendment put forward by the Opposition be rejected. As I have said, it is not a matter of coming up with some idea to sell shares to the staff and the Australian public. It is really a matter of Elderising or placing Qantas in Bondage.
