TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that the hype we just heard from the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) would do Qantas Airways Ltd's public relations department proud indeed. I would like to draw the facts to the honourable member's attention and to that of the House because they point to the tragedy that is now facing Qantas. This year international tourism will grow in terms of this country by 23 per cent. To meet that extra demand Qantas had a plan to develop its capacity by 15 per cent. That figure has now been revised and Qantas has dropped it back to 10 per cent. The reason is that it does not have the aircraft to handle the increased business.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate that has been ensuing in this House tonight is very much about the future of Qantas and its capacity to compete around the world as a major international carrier. At the moment Qantas is under all sorts of pressure. Qantas itself has stated that it wants by the mid-1990s to have a fleet exceeding 50 aircraft, but as recently as a fortnight ago the Chairman of Qantas, Mr Jim Leslie, for whom I have the utmost regard, was still calling on the Government to `Please privatise us-please give us the funds that we so desperately need to be able to go out and buy the equipment and to be able to go into the international market and compete'.

I am concerned about the capacity of Qantas to be able to compete into the future. In a matter of days Qantas begins seven flights a week, one stop, Australia-London, and that is good; but Qantas has massive competition on that route. Already the non-stops to the United Kingdom and to Europe are either in hand or are planned by British Airways, Singapore Airlines, Malaysian Airline System, Thai Airways International, Cathay Pacific, Lufthansa and KLM. In the Pacific, Qantas has even greater competition, with one of the biggest carriers in the free world, United Airways Inc., going into one-stop and non-stop services there. Air New Zealand-and admittedly Qantas has a small holding in that airline-also will be in on that, and of course United Airlines is seeking more rights. Why is that happening? It is happening because Australia is the major destination.

It is all very well for the honourable member for Capricornia and other speakers in this debate to talk about this tremendous growth in tourism, but I believe that we are only just now scratching the surface. It is all very well for the honourable member to start talking about the boom in Japanese traffic. The plain facts are that Qantas has had to curtail its plans to operate to Fukuoka and also has cancelled an extra service into Tokyo. That has been brought about simply by the fact that Qantas has not got the aircraft or capacity to handle that business.

There are desperate problems in Qantas in terms of servicing. From last year Qantas has contracted six foreign airlines to perform work on its 747 and 767 aircraft, which has cost Qantas an additional $10m. Two 747s went to United, others to Air France and to Air Lingus. Another is going to KLM Royal Dutch Airlines. The 767s are being handled by Air New Zealand, and Singapore Airlines is now undertaking maintenance of Qantas aircraft. Qantas is at desperation level in terms of company structure, staff and the capacity to be able to pay for new aircraft, and we are still just scratching the surface of the available international tourism.

There are two countries in the Asian- Pacific region that offer as much hope as the Japanese market has been offering us in terms of increasing the number of tourists into Australia and thus the money spent here. For how many years now have negotiations been going on with the Republic of Korea? Korea now allows its nationals to go overseas on holiday. The Republic of China on Taiwan is in exactly the same situation. Both of those countries are desperate to get air services into Australia. Despite the fact that there is no direct traffic, they are still coming. In Taiwan alone there is a potential market for Qantas worth in the vicinity of $55m a year in profits from the Chinese coming into Australia for holidays. That figure would be even greater out of the Republic of Korea. Yet little if any progress has been made in the negotiations for new routes in that area. Those areas are most important to us.

Further, one has to look at the great expansion that is now starting to come out of Europe, especially from northern Europe in the form of visitors coming here from Scandinavia, West Germany, Switzerland and France. Going farther south, the Spaniards comprise one of our great potential markets for international visitors into Australia. In those places we have no direct international air routes and even if Qantas wanted them, it would not have the aircraft to service those routes, yet Qantas should be very much in that market.

What is happening now around the world is that the mega-airlines are fast being formed, and Qantas has to get into the big league if it is to survive. Already Qantas is competing against mega-carriers United and Continental on the Pacific route. Arrangements have been made between United and British Airways, which is a massive conglomeration and a massive computer reservation service to compete against. Will Qantas be squeezed out of those markets? If we do not privatise Qantas, if we do not give it the available capital, will Qantas be reduced to a regional carrier? That is a matter of major concern to me because I believe that that is what will happen if Qantas is not allowed to expand.

The story behind the Qantas fleet problems relates not only to its capacity to be able to expand into these new markets. Qantas, like so many of the major international carriers, is now starting to have some problems with the age of its fleet. It was reported quite recently that a great number of Qantas's 747s are now over 10 years old. There are Qantas 747s flying around the world now at 16, 17 and 18 years of age and, frankly, they are probably getting towards the end of their useful life. They are the old 200 series; there is one 100 series aircraft still in the fleet. No doubt those aircraft will have to go very shortly. Qantas has a two-fold problem-the expansion problem and the replacement problem. It might be said that Qantas still stacks up pretty well against some of the overseas carriers. I suppose that it does, bearing in mind that the average age of the Qantas fleet of 9.62 years compares quite favourably with North West Airlines at 15.47, or Eastern Airlines at 15.11, or United at 14.87, or Trans World Airlines at 15.29. One of the areas from which Qantas gets some of the greatest competition relates to the Asian carriers. For example, Singapore Airlines has the newest and most efficient fleet in the world at 4.50 years; Thai International, which also competes fiercely with Qantas, is at 6.1 years; Japan Air Lines, recently privatised, at 9.14 years; Cathay Pacific, one of Qantas's bigger competitors, at 8.8 years.

What has happened is that the airlines to which I have specifically pointed are interesting because they are in the private sector and in recent years have had the capacity to upgrade their fleets. They have had the capacity to get into airline deals which have made their operations in many respects much more efficient than some of the traditional carriers I have just mentioned. That will be a problem for Qantas, which has got to join the Asian carriers and get a mega-bloc in this part of the world, or-and this is what worries me-be relegated to just a major regional carrier. For the sake of Australia, the latter would be a great mistake indeed.

Qantas has some expansion plans into Australia and it must have such plans. When a thing is hot, it is hot, and if the international tourism boom is to continue into Australia, we must make sure that we have the capacity to be able to handle it. I think that the Government probably has two choices. It can go on the privatisation road as soon as possible to get that capital injected into Qantas, or we shall have to loosen up the international air regime that determines landing rights in Australia to allow more and more foreign carriers to come in here.

Qantas has always argued that it should have an equal share. I do not think that it is always possible to have an equal share of the incoming market, but Qantas has to have a fair share. It will not have a fair share if we do not allow one of those two things to happen-either to expand the fleet dramatically or to loosen up on the international regulations that govern the other international carriers coming into Australia.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, this is a most critical time for Qantas. It is a time when if it does not expand it has the capacity to lose its position as one of the major international carriers in the world. It is a critical time for Australian tourism. When we are booming we have to try to maintain that boom, because many millions of dollars have been invested in infrastructure and tourism in Australia. It is up to those international airlines to bring that traffic in, to make the most of that investment and, indeed, to provide many of the jobs that are available to young Australians through the ever-expanding tourist industry.

The Bureau of Industry Economics figures should be repeated in this place time and time again. Every time we increase the net number of international visitors coming into Australia by 25,000, we create another 1,400 jobs for young Australians. It is the tourist industry, and only the tourist industry, that has the capacity to provide long term employment for young people in this country. At a time when that industry is booming, at a time when there are hundreds of thousands of jobs now available in the hospitality area, at a time when Qantas is earning massive amounts of foreign capital for this country, at a time when tourism is our second biggest foreign income earner and at a time when we have this massive international debt, it would seem to me to be absolutely crazy to cut that industry and that growth off at the knees.

What must be done is that Qantas must be allowed to expand. There is only one way in which that expansion can take place, and that is by the privatisation of that company and the injection of the capital that is needed, of up to $6 billion. Governments can never fund that. The real decision that this Government has to make is whether it is fair dinkum about the future of Qantas, whether it is fair dinkum about the growth of international tourism into Australia and whether it is fair dinkum about being able to provide jobs for our young people. This Bill is about more than just guaranteeing three Boeing 747-400 series aircraft; it is very much about the future of young Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with some of the comments made by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) in his contribution tonight but, of course, not with his argument that the only way in which young Australians will get jobs from having foreign tourists entering Australia is by allowing the privatisation of Qantas Airways Ltd. I do not accept that argument. I will explain a little later tonight why I do not agree with that proposition advanced by the Liberal and National parties.

SPEECH.PARA: Listening to the honourable member for Fadden telling us about his concerns about Qantas ending up as a rump of an airline in our part of the world, listening to the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) reminding the House of the maintenance problems which Qantas has had, like most other airlines, over a long period and listening to the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) telling us about the financial difficulties which he sees for Qantas, one would almost think that Qantas was in great trouble. In fact, at one stage tonight I wrote down that, after listening to the shadow Minister for transport and aviation, the honourable member for Richmond, telling us about bits falling off Qantas aeroplanes and all the other terrible problems that he believes that Qantas is going through, one would think that Qantas had the financial strength of the National Safety Council of Australia and the safety standards of some Dodgy Brothers Airways.

The Opposition tonight has simply set out to talk Qantas down. It has set out to discredit Qantas in the eyes of this Parliament and of Australians, who rightly are very proud of its achievements in a very competitive part of the international marketplace. We might simply start by asking, `What has Qantas achieved in recent years?'. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, would be aware that in the life of the previous Government Qantas did not have a very attractive story to tell. It was not a success story. In 1980, for example, Qantas made a loss of $16m. In 1981 it made a loss of $17m. In 1982 it turned the corner and recorded a great profit of $1 1/2m! That was a great profit for an organisation the size of Qantas! Then, of course, we had the change of government but with the restrictive policies of the Fraser Government still inhibiting the operations of Qantas. It recorded a further loss of $71m in 1983. What is the position today? It does not experience losses of $15m, $16m or $17m today. Last year Qantas made a profit of $153m. That profit will go towards re-equipping Qantas and making sure that it can continue to compete with the world's best.

We should not forget that not only does Qantas make a very healthy profit but it earns substantial amounts of foreign exchange for Australia. Given the difficulties which our economy faces with balance of payments problems, it is very important that we acknowledge that last year Qantas earned $2,500m in foreign exchange. That is something which can be compared with, perhaps, the maritime industry. Very few of Australia's goods that are shipped overseas are shipped in Australian ships. Because we do not have a shipping industry based in Australia which can compete with the rest of the world, a great deal of foreign exchange goes out of Australia and we lose that revenue.

If we listened to those opposite, if we followed the Opposition's path and allowed Qantas to be privatised, with the people of Australia no longer able to have any say in what happens to Qantas, sure enough, year by year we would end up with the Bonds and the Elliotts buying up all the shares of Qantas. Those people would move their operations to the Cook Islands, the Cayman Islands or these other offshore operations and would put their personal profits ahead of any consideration as to what is best for Australia and in Australia's interests. Mr Elliott has made it clear on many occasions that, if he believes that he can make a bigger profit in some offshore country, if he believes that he can make more money by brewing beer in England or in Scotland than in Australia, he will take his operations offshore.

I do not believe that the majority of Australians or of Qantas employees want people like Mr Elliott owning Qantas. Qantas has achieved a great deal for our country. The way Qantas can continue to make a substantial profit and earn substantial amounts of foreign exchange revenue is to ensure that the Australian people, through the Australian Government, continue to own it. That does not mean that we cannot ensure that Qantas has the flexibility to compete in the international marketplace. But we must concede that Qantas has been doing very well lately. At the moment Qantas spends more than $240m a year overseas promoting tourism to Australia. If Mr Elliott or Mr Bond owned Qantas, how would we know that they would spend those amounts of money to promote tourism to Australia? They would simply look at maximising their profits. If it meant that Qantas could make greater profits flying to some other country, nothing would stand in their way.

Earlier tonight Opposition members said that Qantas cannot maintain its fleet and that it has to send planes overseas because we have a disastrous wages policy in this country. The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) nods his head in agreement, reinforcing the Opposition's opinion. The honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) also lends his support to that argument. What is the Opposition saying to us? I suspect that the Opposition today does not want a prices and incomes accord between government, business and the trade union sector. The Opposition thinks that is something which restricts the market forces. The Opposition appears to be saying that it wants a deregulated labour market system in Australia. It wants a system where there is no centralised wage fixing, where there is no accord and where there are no national wage case guidelines. What would be the outcome of that today?

TALK.START.PARA: —They would be paid more.

—It might mean that Qantas engineers earned a bit more money, but we would have a wages explosion. The Qantas engineers might get a little bit more money today, but they would be paying more in the supermarket tomorrow and on the day after we would be facing massive increases in unemployment. I would have thought that Opposition members would have learned the lessons of the wages breakout in 1981, when Malcolm Fraser was in so much of a hurry to fly off to the wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer in London that he could not afford to tough out a battle with a certain trade union. He gave in to that union's demands and walked away from the centralised wage fixing system we had in that year. What was the outcome? There were massive increases in wages and, as a result, massive increases in prices. Ultimately there were massive increases in unemployment and a recession-the biggest we have had since the Depression.

SPEECH.PARA: What does the Opposition tell us we should have now in our current tight labour market with very high levels of growth-the perfect circumstances for a wages breakout? It wants a return to 1981 and the wages breakout.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. Do what other countries do.

—The honourable member shakes his head and disagrees. How can he believe that wages will not break out if there is no restraint upon them? Such a breakout would be led by people such as the Overseas Telecommunications Commission employees and the Qantas engineers. I believe that this Government has been very responsible in insisting that all employees must have wage increases negotiated under the national wage case guidelines. That means that those Qantas engineers, their union and Qantas management must explain that they are entitled to these increases because they have worked out ways to improve productivity. I thought that that was the Opposition's stated wages policy-that people would only get a wage increase if they could prove that they could work more productively. Under the current national wage case guidelines we have a system which says that workers must produce evidence of an improvement in productivity in order to get their wage increase. The Opposition claims that that is restrictive and is inhibiting market competition.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members do not want any increases based on productivity. What they want is a free-for-all. They want a system like the one that exists in the United States, where the wages of those engineers who work for the airlines are not set by certain market forces, as they would have us believe. Take, for example, Continental Airlines. A few years ago a certain entrepreneur got control of Continental Airlines. What did he do? He declared the airline bankrupt, sacked every employee and then offered wages contracts at greatly reduced rates. He told would-be employees, `You either accept those lower wage rates or you have the sack and you will never work again in this industry'. That is what market forces do in the US; it is happening again to another US airline at this very moment. If honourable members opposite talked to the pilots and the maintenance officials of Continental Airlines who lost their jobs because they refused to work for subsistence wages, they would realise the effects of the sort of market forces that they want to operate in Australia's international airline. I know that the engineers who work for Qantas can see through the Opposition's arguments because they meet people who used to work for Continental and they know what happens when the likes of Elliott and Bond gain control of an airline. They sack the employees and offer subsistence wages.

Since the honourable member for Gilmore is in the chamber, I wish to refer to a statement that he made in the recent debate on the third runway at Sydney Airport and the proposed second Sydney international airport at Badgerys Creek. On 24 February he issued a press release which said:
. . . the tourist industry in Australia could look forward-
that is, with the third runway at Sydney Airport-
to a loss of opportunity and an erosion of the recent gains the industry had made.
That is, if the Government had then decided to go to Badgerys Creek. The press release went on to say:
He emphasised that this was due to the Federal Labor Government's refusal to make a sensible commitment to a third runway at Mascot and to deal co-operatively with the NSW Government on the issue.

The honourable member was adding further weight to this bogus argument that the current traffic movements at Mascot are inhibiting our overseas tourist industry. That is the crux of the argument that people such as him have put forward. That displays the fact that the shadow Minister for tourism does not understand the limiting factor on international jets arriving at Sydney Airport. It is not the runway. International flights into Mascot make up only 16 per cent of aircraft movements at that airport so it is certainly not restricted runway capacity that is the limiting factor. If the shadow Minister for tourism understood his area of interest he would know that the difficulty has been the terminal at Sydney. That is the choke point for international tourist arrivals and departures at Sydney. This Government has already spent a lot of money putting new baggage handling facilities into the existing terminal. It is adding extra gateways at the terminal and spending many hundreds of millions of dollars on a new international terminal at Mascot. The honourable member for Gilmore was probably not aware that the terminal is the choke point which is limiting further expansion of international tourism in Australia. It is not the runway. Perhaps he will go back and study this area a little more closely.

Some honourable members, and other overseas airlines, have been criticising Qantas for seeking to protect its interests on its international routes. We heard this again tonight from the honourable member for Fadden, who has a great deal of expertise in this area. I acknowledge that. The honourable member for Fadden suggested that the Government and Qantas had been holding up negotiations with the Republic of Korea. I took a note of his words and he said that for years the Republic of Korea had been trying to negotiate access to the Australian market. That is true. Of course Korean Air Lines would have loved to have been on the Australian route many years ago. The essential question to ask is what benefit would that provide for Australia. Usually we negotiate these agreements only if Qantas can get some of the tourist market from that country. Until recently overseas travel by citizens of the Republic of Korea was restricted. So what was the benefit to Australia in allowing Korean Air Lines to travel on our routes if the citizens of the Republic of Korea were not allowed to travel overseas? Our Government rightly held off until Korean citizens were allowed to travel overseas. I agree with the honourable member for Fadden that this is an area of great potential for growth and I understand that Qantas and Korean Air Lines are very close to establishing direct flights between our two countries. I hope that area will expand in the years to come.

You would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, of the great battle that we have had with the United States of America over flights between Australia and that country. Of course the US airlines are great believers in deregulation of their domestic aviation market but they are not that keen on deregulation and open skies for international competitors such as Qantas. Qantas and the Australian Government had to fight for many years before finally winning an agreement last year for a fair deal for Qantas in the US market. Through the efforts of people such as the then Minister for Transport and Aviation, the present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris), who took a tough line with the Americans, we were able to ensure that Qantas now has direct access to three additional gateways in the US. Qantas also has on-carriage rights into Canada, Europe, and other places in the US. I hope that Qantas and the Australian Government will continue to defend very strongly their interests, and therefore Australia's interests, on all of these routes, whether it is within the Asia-Pacific region or on the kangaroo route. We should ensure that our airline is maximising its profits and its returns to the Australian people.

I believe that the legislation before the House will allow the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to advance Qantas a substantial sum of money so that it can purchase the most modern and up to date jumbo jets available. I believe that all members of the House will support this and I think it is a pity that the Opposition once again has sought to use this debate to launch upon the people of Australia its arguments as to why Qantas Airways Ltd should be privatised.

As the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) explained very clearly to this House, if the Opposition were elected to government and decided to abolish all foreign investment review controls, how would we know who would end up owning shares in Qantas? Even if only Australian entrepreneurs were able to purchase large amounts of Qantas shares, how could we know that at some future date some Liberal government would not allow foreign investors to purchase our international airline? All we need to do is to look to the US to see what has happened when entrepreneurs such as Elliott and Bond have taken control of an airline such as Continental. The employees get sacked. They get offered subsistence wages and, unless they are prepared to cop them, they are out of a job. That is not something which the people of Australia or Qantas should accept.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Floods: Parkes Electorate-Road Funding-Trucking Industry-Australia Day-Retirement of Mrs Joan Frost

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dorothea Mackellar, in her vivid description of her feelings towards Australia, as a 19-year-old, penned these famous lines in 1904:

SPEECH.PARA: I love a sunburnt country,
A land of sweeping plains,
Of ragged mountain ranges,
Of droughts and flooding rains.

That latter reference to flooding rains is what I wish to speak about tonight. Over the last few days a tremendous amount of water has been dumped over eastern Australia. Although it has received scant attention in the media compared with Lismore and other coastal flooding, a great deal of that rain fell in my electorate of Parkes. Regrettably, it fell to excess in an area around Nyngan, Coolabah and Warren. While great losses have been caused to cotton crops in the Warren, Trangie and Bourke areas, a 40 kilometre by 100 kilometre area in the vicinity of Nyngan is where the greatest losses and tragedies have occurred, primarily to livestock. Around 80 to 100 properties have been affected. Twenty to 30 properties have suffered large stock losses and about 12 or more properties are in very serious difficulty.

As I ring around these properties the sad story that comes through is that 2,000 sheep are lost here, 3,000 there and 4,000 on another property. One property has lost 6,000 sheep. Who knows at this stage what the total is? It certainly runs into tens of thousands. That is heartbreaking enough, but the real tragedy is that the 40,000 or more sheep that we have so far been able to identify that are still alive will all be dead before the week is out unless help arrives. I am not just talking about sheep huddled on island mounds along with kangaroos, pigs and snakes-if those sheep are fed and if the water does not rise they will survive-I am talking about the tens of thousands of sheep standing in water eight to nine inches deep and up to shoulder height deep. Of course, if the water were any deeper these sheep would have already drowned.

This water presents a problem. The length of the fleece is critical here because wool is hydroscopic. As it absorbs the water these fleeces can weigh an extra 20, 30 or 40 pounds and that weight will pull the sheep down over a period. Some of these sheep have been standing in water now for 3 1/2 days. If they stand for another 3 1/2 days nearly all of them will be dead. Of course, if they are pregnant, as many are, the situation is worse and if they are near lambing they can run into problems like pregnancy toxaemia. We have to get feed to these sheep quickly. Feeding sheep in water is a problem. Some may not even feed and the feed will have to be repeated every three days. Of course, after seven to 10 days of standing in water the feet of these sheep become very soft and the hooves rot off. As the sheep are standing in black soil, when they move the black soil will suck off their hooves. Blowflies will also become a problem. Today up in this region the temperature was 27 to 29 degrees centigrade. With fly strike the maggots will be eating many of these sheep alive before the week is out.

We must get these sheep to higher ground. Army ducks have been suggested but apparently they are useless because they can only work either on firm ground or in water five feet deep or more. So many of the farmers up there have been using small flat-bottomed boats which only hold about four to 10 sheep and, of course, the sheep are very heavy to get into these boats. Here is a typical story: I just rang Alan Gadsby at Mulgawarrina. He, his family and helpers spent all day shifting 2,700 sheep 1 1/4 miles from the waist deep water they were standing in through to water which is only eight or nine inches deep. Twelve of them drowned but he still has 10 miles to go before he can get them to ground. Obviously they will have to be lifted by helicopter. Something like a Chinook helicopter that can lift six tonnes would be marvellous if it could gather up these sheep in nets and take them those 10 miles to safety. I appeal to the office of the Minister. If this is thought to work will the Minister provide these helicopters? I know that the Minister has been good and that he is sending a Chinook up there tomorrow. That can cart 160 bales at a time to sheep that need feeding.

Lastly, I would like to say that the spirit of the people in this area has just been magnificent-not only the owners but also the local shires, the pasture protection boards, the local media and the people in the town. I hope that the spirit of these people in the Nyngan district who are in this desperate plight will carry them through. Perhaps they might just dwell on Dorothea Mackellar's other lines:
Core of my heart, my country!
Land of the Rainbow Gold,
For flood and fire and famine,
She pays us back three-fold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), who has been talking about the problems that he has been experiencing in his electorate following the recent rains and the floods that they are now causing. I would like to take a few moments of the time of the House to relate some of the problems that are being experienced in my electorate because of the standard of roads throughout the electorate and, in particular, the standard of the Hume Highway between Goulburn and Yass. Between Goulburn and Yass on that now infamous stretch of highway a substantial number of people have been killed in recent weeks and a larger number of people have been seriously injured in motor accidents. I think there was a stage where, over a period of 10 weeks, 13 people had been killed on that section of highway between Goulburn and Yass and, of course, many others were injured.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason this is happening today is due to lack of funds to complete the improvement of the Hume Highway to a dual carriageway for its entire length from Sydney to Melbourne. When the Australian bicentennial road development scheme was initially set up under the ministry of Ralph Hunt in the Fraser-Anthony Government, the Hume Highway was supposed to be a dual carriageway for its entire length from Sydney to Melbourne by the year 1988. Unfortunately, due to a lack of road funding by this Government that has not been completed. Today places such as Goulburn, Yass, the Cullerin ranges and Gunning are still experiencing tremendous difficulties with an increasing amount of traffic passing through those areas. Of course, that has now led to this horrific number of accidents occurring on that leg of the highway.

As a result of the lack of road funding throughout Australia, we are finding now that many local shires and municipal areas are unable to maintain roads adequately. For example, I have a shire in my electorate that, for the last three years, has not been able to carry out one inch of bitumen road in road construction. The reason is that the Federal Government has not been able to provide any extra funds for it to carry out any extra work. As a consequence, that district is falling behind. As I drive through that area quite regularly I am noticing now that the older bitumen surfaces are starting to break up substantially. As a result, I suspect that, unless a significant improvement in road funding occurs in the next year or two, that shire will be faced with the dilemma of having to tear up that bitumen surface to return it to dirt which is cheaper to maintain and to enable it to maintain that road in a safer condition. There is certainly nothing worse than driving on a very pot-holey, poorly maintained bitumen surface. I think it is even more dangerous than a dirt road because at least on a dirt road one is driving more carefully and slowly.

That is the situation that we currently face in our country areas of Australia. It is being faced by country motorists despite the fact that we are paying more than 27c per litre in taxes at the petrol bowser each time we purchase a litre of petrol. Motorists are interested to find out that approximately 5c of that 27c is going towards road funding. Unfortunately, that is a totally inadequate amount of funding. When Labor first got into government back in 1983 an amount of $1,250m was being allocated towards road funding by the Federal Government. Here we are, six years later in 1989, with $1,205m being allocated towards road funding by this Federal Government.

We have seen the present Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) putting out statements trying to add to the Federal Government's road funding allocation-funds being spent on roads by local councils and by State governments- and trying to bodgie the figures to indicate that road funding has increased over the period of the last six years. In fact, road funding has deteriorated in real terms to the tune of 30 to 40 per cent. It is for that reason that shires throughout my electorate are now faced with the dilemma of having to tear up bitumen roads to return them to gravel because they are easier and cheaper to maintain and possibly safer to drive on. Of course, that is also the reason why we are finding that we now have horror stretches of highway such as the ones between Goulburn and Yass on the Hume Highway which are leading to a tremendous increase in the number of deaths and serious accidents on that highway. Unfortunately, this will not change unless we have a government that is prepared to allocate more of the taxes that motorists pay at the petrol bowser towards road improvements.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—Until that happens, we are going to see more and more of these accidents occurring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), I simply ask and I thank the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) for his help with this question: How much does the honourable member for Gilmore believe should be allocated in Federal expenditure on roads?
—More than you are putting in.

—He says more than we are putting in. He has gone a little further than the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). When the Leader of the Opposition was asked that question, he said he could not say whether spending on roads would be increased or decreased under a coalition government. Members of the Opposition in this Parliament day after day say that government spending is too high and that if the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) were Minister for Finance they would cut back Federal spending across the board. They would cut it back for pensioners, for expenditure on hospitals, for expenditure on everything, including roads. That is the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Gilmore can come in here and pander to his own electorate by pretending that if a coalition government were elected then all of the problems in his electorate, including the Hume Highway problem, would be solved. We all know that he has to make his speech for his electorate, but the truth is that the Opposition is advocating the opposite. It wants to cut taxes; it wants to cut government spending; it wants less spending on roads. That is the truth of the matter.

The honourable member brought to the attention of the House the recent tragic fatalities on the stretch of the Hume Highway between Goulburn and Yass. The Hume Highway, of course, is a lot better now than it was in 1974, when the national highway program commenced, under the Government of which you were a member, Madam Speaker. I believe that anyone who has driven between Sydney and Melbourne in recent days knows how much money has been spent on that highway in constructing dual carriageways. Yes, better roads do save lives, and we still have a lot of very bad roads, including parts of the Hume Highway, which need improvement. That will take money and some time. I believe it is dangerous for organisations such as the National Roads and Motorists Association to suggest that it is the roads that are causing these deaths and accidents. The statistics show that in most cases the accidents are caused by driver error-people driving faster than is recommended for the road conditions. If people believe that the roads are at fault in all these accidents perhaps they get a little reckless.

One other area to which I think Federal and State governments need to pay more attention is the number of deaths caused by heavy vehicles. Madam Speaker, you may not have seen an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 25 March which suggested that it is now common practice for a large number of truck drivers to take drugs which they have nicknamed `speed' to keep them awake when they have been driving for very long periods.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amphetamines.

—I thank the honourable member for Chifley for his pharmaceutical advice. By taking these drugs the drivers are able to stay at the wheel for a longer time than they are legally entitled to. The article also suggests that truck drivers are registering log books in several different States so that if they are pulled up by a policeman they can produce one of several different log books showing that they have not breached the guidelines on the number of hours they have been at the wheel when in fact they have. By pulling out different log books, they can avoid being caught.

SPEECH.PARA: There are now many accidents being attributed to these heavy vehicles, with an increase of over 30 per cent in the last 12 months in fatalities associated with heavy vehicle accidents. I believe there has been such a massive increase that we now need to look at making it compulsory for trucks to have installed some form of tachograph which records the speed of the truck and can be inspected at random by the police and by the Department of Motor Transport to ensure that drivers are not breaching the guidelines. Of course, many truck drivers borrow large amounts of money and are forced to drive for long periods so that they can keep their businesses afloat. However, we cannot allow the people of Australia to face unacceptable levels of accidents on our roads simply because some truck drivers have over-extended themselves in seeking to finance businesses. I hope all honourable members will take on board this idea of a tachograph and that those opposite will consider it in future debates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity tonight to talk about Australia Day. It has been of great concern to me, and certainly to a number of my constituents, that perhaps Australia Day is not understood well by Australians and is not treated with the importance it deserves. I point out that Australia Day actually commemorates the beginning of European settlement in Australia, when Governor Phillip landed at Sydney Cove on 26 January 1788.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past, when the date for Australia Day has fallen on a day other than a Monday, the holiday has been held on the Monday following 26 January in order to create a long weekend. However, in 1988, the year of Australia's bicentennial celebrations, the holiday was held on the actual day, Tuesday, 26 January. There was talk of continuing this practice in subsequent years. Unfortunately, that did not happen in 1989. In fact, in some States, including my own, Australia Day was actually celebrated on a day which enabled a long weekend, although in Sydney it was celebrated on 26 January.

I think the importance of the day is such that we should have 26 January as a public holiday and a day on which European settlement in Australia can be celebrated. This does not mean that we neglect the fact that the Aboriginal people were here 40,000 years before the Europeans came. Nevertheless, we are all proud to have been able to settle in this country, not least myself-I came here as a migrant in 1961-and I think it is therefore quite proper for us to celebrate that day.

The history of the day is that it was first proclaimed a public holiday in 1838, which was the fiftieth anniversary of the founding, but some sort of celebration had been held in Sydney at least as early as 1817 or 1818. Different names, including Anniversary Day and Foundation Day, were used in different States, but eventually the other States followed the lead given by Victoria in 1931 when it adopted the name Australia Day, a title long-advocated by the Australian Natives Association. In 1946 the Australia Day Council was formed in Melbourne to foster national appreciation of the day's significance.

As I said, a number of my constituents in La Trobe are very worried about the fact that Australia Day is not duly recognised or even understood by many Australians. I have with me a letter from Kate Hardie, a pupil of St Michael's School in Berwick. She writes to me as follows:
Dear Sir,

My name is Kate. I am a grade six student from St Michael's School Berwick. Our class conducted a survey about Australia Day in the Berwick area. The results were very bad indeed. Only 40% of adults and 25% of children interviewed knew who brought the first fleet to Australia. Our class was disappointed by these low percentages to answer such simple Questions. That is why our class have decided to write letters to important people around Australia in hope that maybe they can inform more Australians about our national day. You too could help by maybe putting articles in newspapers.
Thank's for you time.
Yours sincerely
Kate Hardie.

I think that is a very good letter and Kate has put the situation very well. I know that other honourable members in the House listening to this speech will agree with the point I have made. I should say that whilst I have some difficulty in getting articles in the newspaper, I do not have difficulty in getting up and putting the points of other honourable members in the House. I have done so on this occasion. I have brought it to the most important place-the Federal Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be in every newspaper in the country.

—The honourable member is right. It is important for school children to be aware that we are prepared to ensure that Australia Day is given the importance it deserves in the community. We will all do our best to ensure that that happens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to report to the House an incident that occurred when, as the member for Wakefield, I attended a meeting of the Mid-North Local Government Association held at Spalding, in about the centre of my electorate. The Chairman of the Mid-North Local Government Association is Brian Hern, the district councillor of Angaston. He was more than a little indignant-and so was the entire Association-at a letter the Association had received, signed by the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown). The Minister had apparently written to all local government associations expressing his concern about the Australian Automobile Association's and the State automobile associations' criticism of the Government's road funding program.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that Councillor Hern, the Association and the Association's President, who was also at that meeting, were indignant at the Minister's letter was that the Minister's letter contained allegations and assertions which were quite inaccurate. One does not have to go very far in rural electorates such as mine to find ample evidence of the rundown of Australia's road infrastructure under the funding being made available by this Government to sustain what little road work is currently occurring.

It was most appropriate that the meeting should have been held in Spalding. I have made the point to the Government in this House before that of all stretches of road in Australia, that most neglected and most justifiably needing work is the stretch of road that runs from the Riverland town of Morgan to Spalding in the mid-north of my electorate. If one looks at this stretch of road on the map, one appreciates that for anyone travelling from Sydney to Perth, it is the only unsealed stretch of highway.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much do you want? Will you put a figure on it?

—I am not particularly interested in taking a figure on it. I am interested in making the valid point that this stretch of road, which was progressively being sealed, is currently being allowed to run down. Anyone travelling from Sydney to Perth entering South Australia and reaching the Riverland town of Morgan is forced to run south of Eudunda, almost into the Adelaide environs, if that person wants to stay on a sealed road. The attraction of sealing the stretch of road that runs from Morgan to Spalding is that it would allow Sydney to Perth traffic to stay on a sealed road without having to run south into the Adelaide area.

SPEECH.PARA: The crazy situation currently facing the Mid-North Local Government Association is that this stretch of road, over which a grader can be run, bringing it up to tolerable conditions, is, as soon as it is brought into condition, torn apart by truckies who find it such an attractive route that they use it. Because it is unsealed it promptly falls into disrepair.

Much has already been made by a previous speaker on the other side, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), of his concern about the way truck drivers treat other road users. What truck drivers need is not more regulation but the opportunity to work in a more deregulated environment. What forces truck drivers to put in the hours that make them hazardous drivers is the reality of the interest rates, the fuel costs and the tyre costs forced on them by this Government. Frankly, the truckies of Australia would be much better served if the stretch of road that currently runs from Morgan to Spalding were sealed and serviced so that they are able to make the trip from Sydney to Perth without having to venture further south into South Australia than they would normally choose.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable members to the imminent retirement of Mrs Joan Frost, who has loyally served this Parliament and previous parliaments continuously since 1952. Joan began her career as a casual waitress during the first session of the Twentieth Parliament and worked in the dining rooms in casual and sessional capacities until 1968, when she became senior waitress in charge of the Members' Dining Room. Joan continued as senior waitress for 10 years until she became a full time office assistant in 1978. Her career culminated in her frequently acting as food service manager from 1983 onwards. She was substantively promoted to that level in 1988.

INTERJECT.PARA: Her 37-year record of service to the Parliament forms part of a longer family tradition. Her father was chef at the Hotel Canberra for many years and catering manager of the Parliamentary Catering Service until his retirement in 1965. Her late husband Reg, originally a bellboy at the Hotel Canberra, subsequently became a barman in the Members' Bar before becoming a Senate attendant. Their four children also did some casual catering work in the old Parliament House. Honourable members may wish to make their personal farewells to Joan at a reception being held in her honour in the Members' Guests' Lounge at 18.30 on Wednesday, 5 April 1989. I am sure that you will all join with me in wishing Joan well for a long, happy and well merited retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was shocked by the remarks of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), particularly his remarks about wanting to deregulate the trucking industry. I am sure that he would be happy only if truck drivers were taking more amphetamines and the police were totally abolished. He has no understanding whatsoever of the pressure that the truck drivers are under in trying to speedily complete their trips. I feel for these truck drivers. Whilst I think it is fair enough to marshal out some of the blame for our road toll to truck drivers, I think we also have to look at their employers and at the terms and conditions of the contracts they sign which often force them into taking these unnecessary risks.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) has also spoken on roads, a very important issue and an issue on which the Federal Government has every bit of credibility. The Opposition has none. The Opposition advocates that tax cuts should be fully paid for by cutting expenditure, yet Opposition members have the hide to get up in this House and say that the Federal Government should be doing more for roads--

TALK.START.PARA: —In their electorates.

—In their electorates. But they advocate that Federal expenditure should be reduced significantly. What utter hypocrisy! They defend the position of the National Roads and Motorists Association (NRMA), which has no credibility on this issue whatsoever. The NRMA has taken the most political stand. It does not say in my electorate `Why does the State Government not nominate the F4 freeway as a national arterial road? If it did so, we would not have the toll that Mr Greiner is going to give us. We have Liberal State candidates saying that the Labor Government wants to put a toll on this road, but what has happened? Twelve months after the Liberals are elected they are putting a toll on it, which is completely unnecessary.

SPEECH.PARA: The motorists of western Sydney are going to pay a toll, and not because there are not sufficient funds. I have spoken to the Minister about this. They will pay the toll because the State Government will not nominate the freeway as a national arterial road. It wants to embed in motorists' minds the idea that New South Wales should be dotted with tollways.

TALK.START.PARA: —Market forces.

—That is market forces, as the honourable member says. We believe that where there are Federal funds for roads, motorists should not bear the burden of double taxation. Therefore, there are no tolls on Federal roads. That is why a toll was recently removed. It was inconsistent with Federal policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me get back to the NRMA. What is this organisation, which is running a vicious campaign on roads, doing about its householder insurance for people who have suffered floods? People in my electorate have suffered floods three times in less than 18 months. What is the NRMA doing to those individuals? It is terrorising them. It is refusing to pay out. It is refusing to insure them. What a despicable record!
